0408284.eventHeadline: Standard Chartered PLC, 2013 Earnings Call, Mar 05, 2014
0408284.transcript_text1:
Well, good morning, London, and good afternoon to Hong Kong and to Mumbai.
2013 has been a challenging year for the industry and for Standard Chartered. While our clients have remained very active, the overall outcome for the group has not been as good as we would have liked. When this time last year we announced another strong set of results, we said we were not complacent and would continue to refresh our strategy to ensure the group is able to adapt to the changing environment. As we stated at the Investor Day in November, the annual strategy review confirmed that we are in markets where there remain good opportunities for profitable growth. And the new organization structure will ensure that the group is best placed to take advantage of these opportunities by supporting clients and customers in a more seamless way, providing them with access to a broad range of products and services. Now Peter is going to talk about this in more detail, but first, let me comment on the board's perspective.
The board remains intensely focused on shareholders' interests, and this was at the top of our minds last year. The business has grown substantially over the last decade, and the board continues to view Standard Chartered as an exciting growth story over the medium to long term. We remain focused on delivering profitable, sustainable growth that is within our risk appetite. The board aims to grow the amount we return to shareholders each year, and this year, we are recommending a final dividend of $0.572, resulting in a total annual dividend increase of 2%. We have increased the amount of dividend paid to our shareholders each year for well over a decade.
Ensuring the business continues to focus on the returns that are generated for shareholders each year is a top priority for the board, as is maintaining our well-capitalized, highly liquid and diverse balance sheet. Since 2010, we have organically grown our balance sheet, increasing loans and advances to customers by 21%, and yet we still have the same Core Tier 1 ratio at the end of 2013 that we had at the end of 2010. Richard will go into further detail, but we are confident in our ability to achieve capital-accretive growth whilst supporting our clients and the creation of wealth across our markets.
Let me at this point, though, comment briefly on how we remunerate our people, most of whom are not located in the U.K. Consistent with past practice, we reward for good performance, as well as taking into account of how our people deliver long-term sustainable and profitable business. Reflecting our performance in 2013, the bonus pool is down on the prior year by 15%. And we are returning to shareholders by way of dividends around twice as much as we are paying out in bonuses, as this slide clearly shows. Overall, our staff costs are broadly flat compared to last year. This slide also shows how much we're paying out in corporate taxes. That includes the U.K. bank levy, which has increased substantially again this year.
Finally, I would like to comment briefly on the board-level changes we set out in January when we announced the reorganization of the group. Steve Bertamini will step down from the board at the end of this month after more than 5 years leading Consumer Banking. I would like to thank Steve for the very considerable contribution he has made to the business over that time and wish him every success in the future. And sadly, we'll also be saying farewell to Richard Meddings, as this is likely to be his last full year's results presentation. Richard has been on our board for 11 years, and his contribution to the business has been immense. As a colleague and as a friend, I know he will be greatly missed. I'd also like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mike Rees, who many of you already know, as he takes up his new role as Deputy Group CEO next month. Mike will be available to take questions later in the meeting.
So while 2013 has been a challenging year, I believe we remain in good shape to support our clients and customers, and the opportunities for the business remain compelling. We will continue to support the growth of trade and wealth across our markets and continue to drive value for our shareholders, from our competitive strengths and from the opportunities we see in the markets we know so well.
At the same time, our focus on conduct has intensified. We expect the right behavior at all times, as being Here for good is firmly embedded in our DNA. We're therefore confident that we are well positioned to drive further value for our shareholders over the coming months.
Now on that note, let me hand over to Richard.

---

Thank you, John. Good morning, London, and good afternoon, Hong Kong and Mumbai.
2013 was a challenging year both for us and for the industry, with margin and spread compression, volatile financial markets and, for us, Korea which remains difficult. We've responded to these challenges by consistently supporting our customer's growth and by managing costs and risks tightly. We have recently sharpened our strategic focus and flexed our financial framework to strike the right balance between growth, returns and managing for capital accretion.
As with our previous results, we exclude from all of our commentary, own credit adjustments, the impairment of goodwill in Korea and the 2012 settlement with the U.S. authorities. On this basis, profit before tax for the year is down $560 million or 7% to just under $7 billion, driven by a number of factors, including continued challenges in Korea where operating profit is down nearly $530 million, with Consumer Banking contributing $326 million of this fall, Peter will discuss Korea in more detail; material margin compression in Transaction Banking following a significant influx of liquidity into our markets, causing a drag to income of nearly $400 million; and as guided concerning the second half of the year, surrounding the effects of QE tapering as well as increased and, to an extent, unclear, regulation impacting Financial Markets where income fell by $564 million half-on-half, with the fourth quarter 19% lower than the third. The performance pressure in this business, which we highlighted in our pre-close, has since been reflected by other major banks in their recent trading updates. Finally, Principal Finance performed poorly, down over $200 million year-on-year.
A number of these headwinds are easing as we enter 2014. And there were, of course, some very strong performances in the year, including Hong Kong but also in most countries in Africa, the MESA region and India, and also in Mortgages and in Corporate Finance. In response to the challenges, we have been extremely disciplined in managing costs, with expenses for the year only 1% higher than in 2012 at $10.2 billion. And we've achieved this despite inflationary pressure of 4% to 5% across our footprint; continuing our investment programs; absorbing a 63% increase in the underlying cost of the U.K. bank levy, now $266 million; significant increases in regulatory and compliance costs, up some $160 million on 2012; and a one-off VAT-related charge in Korea of $54 million. As we saw our income trajectory slow during the year, we managed our costs assertively.
Now let me draw out several key aspects of our performance. Group income of $18.7 billion was 1% down on 2012, but with 25 markets each now contributing income of over $100 million. As I mentioned earlier, costs remained tightly controlled and were up only 1%. Reflecting a strong but lower profits performance, we have reduced the bonus pool by 15% across the group, and this impact will mainly be borne by the more senior executives. Total impairment has increased 25%. Within this, loan impairment has increased 35%, driven in the main by continued elevated impairment levels in the unsecured Consumer Banking portfolio.
The group delivered profit before tax of nearly $7 billion and normalized earnings of almost $5 billion, down 8%. Normalized return on equity was 11.2% and normalized EPS was $2.04, down 9%. Our balance sheet remains in excellent shape, highly liquid and well diversified. And finally, we remain well capitalized by any measure, both compared to our peers and looking out to 2019, but more on this later.
Moving to our performance by business, and starting with Consumer Banking.
Consumer Banking's performance is in line with our pre-close guidance. Income grew 2% year-on-year, although it fell 5% in the second half. This reflects slower Wealth Management income, the initial impact of derisking the unsecured book and regulatory cooling measures, which dampened Mortgage volumes. Expenses were well controlled, increasing by only 1% year-on-year, delivering positive jaws of 1%. Headcount in Consumer Banking reduced by 7%. Total impairment increased 45%, as guided. And as a result, Consumer Banking operating profit fell 11%.
Korea has continued to have a material impact on the Consumer Banking performance, driven by a difficult operating environment where industry-wide returns on equity have fallen below 3%, continued elevated levels of impairment and the impact of our selective derisking of unsecured products, including the planned sale of the consumer finance businesses. As a result of these challenging conditions, Consumer Banking in Korea made an operating loss of $162 million, which is $326 million lower earnings than the prior year. If you were to exclude Korea, Consumer Banking income was actually up 5%, with profits up 8%, driven by Hong Kong, MESA, India and the Africa region.
Turning to income by product.
Mortgage income was up 10%, reflecting 14 basis points of margin improvement and with Hong Kong a significant driver. Deposit income was down 7% year-on-year, particularly in Hong Kong, Korea, India and China, with margins down 12 basis points to 71 basis points.
Wealth Management income was up 2% year-on-year, although income in the second half was down by 11%. Market uncertainty impacted sentiment, particularly in equity products, representing about 1/3 of Wealth Management income and which were down 17% half-on-half. Hong Kong remained our largest market for Wealth Management, growing income 9% and, together with MESA, which grew income 11%, offset weaker performances in Singapore, Korea and other Asia Pacific.
Income in Credit Cards and Personal Loans increased 5% year-on-year and was broadly flat half-on-half. Selective growth in markets like China, the U.A.E. and Africa was offset by a continued derisking in markets like Korea where we have reduced the credit card and personal loan book by 18% year-on-year to just over $5 billion.
SME income was up 3%, with lower deposit income offset by good growth across lending, FX and trade and working capital as we continue to finance the growth of our SME customers.
Moving to impairment. Consumer Banking loan impairment increased by 53% or $360 million, with Korea accounting for over 40% of the increase. We have taken action in Korea by tightening underwriting standards, changing customer acquisition strategies and exiting customer segments more prone to filing under the Personal Debt Rehabilitation Scheme. Outside of Korea, loan impairment increased by 47% year-on-year, reflecting previous asset growth and the seasoning of the unsecured portfolio, plus some $53 million of lower debt sales. As previously guided, we have taken steps to derisk our unsecured book across the group. Given the slower growth in unsecured assets going forward, we would expect loan impairment from seasoning to moderate in the second half of this year.
Looking now at Wholesale Banking.
Wholesale Banking income is down 2%, which is slightly lower than our expectation at the time of the pre-close, arising from delayed deal execution in Principal Finance as well as continuing weak financial markets conditions. Within this, client income, which represents 86% of Wholesale Banking, was up 4%, and own account income was down 25%.
The operating environment was impacted by a number of factors during the year. Most of these factors were either temporary or cyclical, including the high levels of liquidity in our markets, the persistently low interest rate environment, uncertainty over the pace and timing of QE tapering and indiscriminate deterioration in sentiment on emerging markets in the second half. Other factors like regulatory change impacting derivative markets were more structural in nature.
Expenses were very tightly controlled, increasing only 1% year-on-year, with lower staff costs offsetting increased regulatory expenses. Furthermore, expenses were down 2% in the second half with reduced variable compensation as business performance fell, as well as tight control over hiring and BAU costs.
Total impairment rose 5% year-on-year. And within this, loan impairment was up 12%, representing 39 basis points of Wholesale Banking customer loans and advances. Other impairment was down 19%. As a result, profit before tax for Wholesale Banking is down 4%.
Looking at income in more detail by product.
Within Transaction Banking, Trade income was down 4% and cash and custody income was down 5%, driven by margin compression of 27 basis points or 19% in Trade and 15 basis points or 16% in cash. We saw strong growth in both average trade balances, up 21%, and cash, up 11%. Importantly, margins are showing signs of stabilization, albeit at levels still lower than that of the first half of last year.
Corporate Finance continued to perform strongly, with income up 13% on 2012. As highlighted in the pre-close, despite some delay in deal execution in the second half, income growth remains broad based, with around 70% annuity in nature and with a strong pipeline as we entered 2014.
ALM income was down 10% year-on-year and down 16% half-on-half, reflecting fewer derisking opportunities in the second half and the continued low interest rate environment. Weak equity markets resulted in lower revaluation gains in our Principal Finance investments, and income was down 43%. Although we saw challenging market conditions in 2013, the comparator for 2014 has eased.
Looking at Financial Markets in a little more detail on the next slide. Income in Financial Markets was flat year-on-year at $3.65 billion, as strong volume growth was offset by spread compression. Within this, client income was up 7% and own account income down 25%. Market conditions deteriorated in the second half, as I mentioned earlier, and as a result, Financial Markets income overall was down 27% on the first half. Rising yields on emerging market bonds and directional uncertainty in the markets led to lower own account income. This impacted our Rates business in particular where income dropped by 1/3 compared to a strong first half. Negative emerging market sentiment also impacted income from our financial institution clients, although income from corporates remained robust, albeit in line with usual seasonal trends.
Our foreign exchange business performed well, with income up 11%, driven by cash FX and FX options, supported by our continued strength in offshore renminbi. Cash FX volumes were up 21%, offsetting spread compression of 12%. And in Rates, volumes were also up 20%. Our equities business made reasonable progress, partially offsetting lower commodities income.
Moving to impairment. Total impairment in Wholesale Banking was up 5% year-on-year, driven by a small number of exposures in India and Africa. These exposures drove an increase in gross nonperforming loans, up by some $900 million or 22% on 2012. This represents just over 2% of Wholesale Banking loans and advances, consistent with the levels seen in recent years. The cover ratio, given these exposures, has declined slightly to 48%, but this increases to 60% after including collateral at a forced sale value. The net at risk remains well within our observed historic recovery rates. We are also seeing signs of improving potential recovery levels and, in particular, against a number of nonperforming loans in our MESA region.
The portfolio continues to perform well, and early alerts are stable. We are not seeing any new areas of stress, but we remain watchful in India and also on the potential impact of lower commodity prices more generally.
Turning to the management of risk and the shape of our portfolio. Let me just repeat some of the characteristics of our balance sheet that perhaps get taken for granted but are material points of differentiation from our peers. In Consumer Banking, the book has a continuing bias towards secured lending, with 82% of the book being either fully or partially secured at an average loan-to-value on our Mortgage book of 48%. We continued to derisk the Consumer unsecured portfolio, with Credit Cards and Personal Loans balances down 6% year-on-year. Consumer Banking 30- and 90-day delinquency rates are stable, as are Wholesale Banking early alerts.  As in earlier periods, a significant majority of "past due but not impaired" balances as of the balance sheet date were cured in the following month.
Our portfolios are very diverse. Energy, our largest Wholesale Banking industry concentration, is around 20% of corporate exposures and, as we've shown you before, is in itself highly diversified. We maintain a short-dated Wholesale Banking book, with 64% of the book maturing in under 1 year, reflecting our Trade bias. Trade assets have the lowest propensity to loss of any Wholesale Banking asset category, with an empirical default rate of around 2 basis points.
Wholesale Banking is highly collateralized, with $197 billion in gross total collateral which is held at conservative forced sale values. Stick positions are down by 26% to $1.5 billion, representing less than 1% of Wholesale Banking loans and advances to customers. And finally, we continue to distribute assets successfully, with primary distribution in the year up 9% and loan sales up 29%. The portfolio is therefore diverse, short tenor, highly collateralized and showing no material signs of stress.
Moving to the group's balance sheet.
Liabilities. Our strong and disciplined management of the balance sheet provides us resilience and allows us to take advantages of opportunities for growth. Looking at liquidity: The balance sheet remains highly liquid with an AD ratio of 76%. 52% of customer deposits are in current and savings accounts. We have a liquid asset ratio of 30%, with over $200 billion of the balance sheet in cash or near cash. We remain a strong provider of net interbank liquidity. And we continue to exceed by a substantial degree the Basel III net stable funding ratio and the liquidity coverage ratio, and some years ahead of the required implementation dates.
Turning to assets. Our loan book remains well diversified by geography, industry, counterparty and product. Loans and advances to customers were up 4%, as we continued to support our clients and customers. Risk-weighted assets grew 7%, driven in the main by asset growth, regulatory consolidation of Permata Bank and credit migration. As you can see, Wholesale Banking represents 75% of group risk-weighted assets and grew at 9%, whilst Consumer Banking remained flat.
Now given the recent market focus, I would like to spend some time setting out the strength of our capital position.  
Let me deal with Basel II first. The group's Core Tier 1 ratio was 11.8% at the end of 2013, the same as it was in 2010 and up some 40 basis points since the half year, the product of risk-weighted asset discipline and the phasing of operational risk, risk-weighted assets and dividend payments. Tier 1 was 13.1%, and total capital, 18%. In addition, we currently estimate our PLAC or primary loss absorbing capacity at 23%, again very robust compared to our peers'. Since our 2010 rights issue, we have very evidently self-funded balance sheet growth and the continued payment of a growing dividend. Our Core Tier 1 ratio has remained at 11.8% whilst growing risk-weighted assets by $77 billion at a CAGR of 10% and declared over $5.5 billion in dividends.
Turning to Basel III. On 1st of January 2014, our Basel III common equity Tier 1 ratio is 10.9% on a transitional basis and rises to 11.2% on an endpoint basis. And it's not just our core equity Tier 1 that's strong. For total capital, we are again strong in absolute terms and relative to our peers. We've been active issuers of Tier 2 capital during 2013, with total capital reaching 18%. These issuances showed strong appetite for our credit and an ability to issue across markets and currencies.
So we are well capitalized today in absolute and relative terms on all metrics, including core equity Tier 1, total capital and PLAC. In addition, our leverage ratio stands at a very strong 4.7% at the year end.
We believe it will be helpful for more capital guidance to be given to the market, in particular around the interplay of the various capital buffers and, most importantly, the minimum capital levels for each individual institution. To help clarify, this slide sets out how we see Standard Chartered's capital position against minimum known requirements, which informs the guidance we have received from the PRA.
We begin with a 4.5% minimum core equity Tier 1 requirement common to all banks, a 2.5% capital conservation buffer common to all banks. It is primarily against this buffer that the Pillar 2B or PRA buffer will be assessed and where we are conservatively positioned. A 1% GSIB buffer applicable to Standard Chartered. And a 0.4% Pillar 2A core equity Tier 1 requirement, which is subject to annual review by the PRA. This totals to a known capital stack of 8.4% core equity Tier 1 capital ratio for Standard Chartered, and let's call this our capital stack.
At 10.9% core equity Tier 1, we are already significantly and materially above our capital stack, and by some 250 basis points. We are therefore substantially above the known threshold, with capacity for additional buffers. We are also today already significantly and materially ahead of the target ratios the PRA has guided us to achieve and by 2019.
On this next slide, let's look at the broader industry. It is crucial to understand that capital requirements will differ for each bank. This is the new regulatory model. The PRA's Pillar 2A guidance is different. GSIB buffers are different. Countercyclical buffers and sectoral capital requirements will be different to reflect each bank's unique business model and risk profile. Capital requirements are not uniform, nor should they be. As recent peer results demonstrate, there are variances in the end-state capital levels, with targets ranging from above 10% to 12% or above. When you think about a bank's capital strength, it is not how high the current ratios are or what the target capital ratios are. It is by how much they are above their own capital stack. Let me give you 2 examples.
First, the GSIB capital requirements range from 0 to 2.5%, according to the different systemic risk profiles of each institution. The GSIB requirement for us at 1% is between 1% and 1.5% lower than that of other U.K.-based international banks. We were also included in the 1% category not because the calculation methodology required it but through a supervisory override. This is therefore conservative. Second, Pillar 2A guidance naturally varies from bank to bank, as it reflects the PRA's intention to capture idiosyncratic risks not included in Pillar 1. These include pension, interest rate, credit concentration and operational risks. You will note from other disclosures that this Pillar 2A buffer can be very different between banks. Our current core equity Tier 1 Pillar 2A guidance of some 40 basis points is demonstrably less than a number of our U.K. peers simply because we do not carry any material U.K. pension risk.
To summarize. Our known minimum is 8.4%. The minimum requirement for other banks is very different given they're often higher GSIB or other requirements or a Pillar 2A guidance. Our current buffer above the capital stack of some 250 basis points is clearly very strong compared to peers and positions us very well to manage future regulatory capital demands as they evolve. The laws governing the countercyclical or systemic risk buffers are not yet finalized, but when we stand back and we compare the diversity of our balance sheet and our risk profile against the 250 basis point buffer, we believe we are very strongly positioned with our current capital to absorb any capital add-on that we can see today whilst continuing to support the growth of our clients and customers.
Next slide. Now despite this, the U.K. regulatory sentiment towards capital levels is clear. And there will be further model adjustments, which we currently estimate could be in the range of 30 to 50 basis points for us in 2014. And it is against this backdrop that we introduced the fifth metric to our financial framework: a commitment to gradually accrete capital over time. Whilst we expect risk-weighted assets to be up in 2014 with the introduction of Basel III and expected model changes, we intend to mitigate this by driving capital-accretive profitable growth through the fifth metric; by more assertive tail management of our existing portfolio; and by divesting certain risk-weighted assets, intensive assets and non-core businesses. The combined impact of these latter non-core disposals is expected to be some 10 to 15 basis points benefit to core equity Tier 1 in 2014. Since our Investor Day last November, we have already released $3 billion of risk-weighted assets from low-returning client relationships in Wholesale Banking, which we will look to redeploy into high-returning relationships. As we look into 2014, we have identified over $10 billion in further reductions, over 1/2 of which will be achieved in the first half.
Finally and although we currently have no immediate issuance plans, the regulations now clearly strongly incentivize banks to hold up to 1.5% of risk-weighted assets as additional Tier 1 rather than common equity Tier 1. Given this, we will seek the necessary regulatory and shareholder approvals to enable us to issue these instruments in the future. Now I've spent some time on this, but hopefully, it gives you a much clearer picture of the strength of our capital position both of itself and relative to peers.
So let me conclude, and turning first to outlook. Our outlook for 2014 is, as you know, one of modest growth. Market and trading conditions are more volatile and difficult than a year ago. Whilst current performance momentum is ahead of the second half of last year, performance in this first half will remain challenged both at an income and at a profit level.
And finally, as this is my last Full Year Results Presentation for Standard Chartered, if you will allow me just to reflect on aspects of the bank of which I am very proud. This is a bank underpinned by excellent foundations, a hugely robust balance sheet, well capitalized, highly liquid, diverse in both assets and liabilities and disciplined by a financial framework that balances growth and returns. We serve customers and clients in the growth markets of the world and have, since the financial crisis, almost doubled our lending to our customers, increasing that lending by some $190 billion doing what a bank should do. And this is an organization full of really great people.
And I also wanted just to take the opportunity to thank you, our investors and analysts both in the room or listening via the webcast or dial-in. For the past 11 years on the board, 7 as Finance Director, and through quite remarkable period of utter change for the industry, I have really appreciated your support both personally and for the bank. I've valued our relationship and tried to answer all of your questions. I've usually enjoyed the conversations we've had. And I've also learned a great deal from all of you. So thank you.
And let me now hand over to Peter.

---

Thank you, Richard. Good morning, London, and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and Mumbai.
As you've heard, 2013 was a tough year. We faced margin pressures in a number of key businesses and markets. Regulatory requirements and the bank levy put upward pressure on costs. Various factors drove a sharp increase in unsecured loan impairment. And much more negative sentiment towards emerging markets affected valuations and transaction closing in Wholesale Banking. And we took goodwill impairment on our business in Korea given the severity of the challenges facing us and the industry as a whole in that market. And as a result, we slipped from our trajectory of record income and profits, posting lower income and profits for the first time in over a decade. And our share price fell, reflecting both our own performance and investor sentiment towards our markets.
 
This is not what we aspire to achieve. So as we saw the challenges mount and our momentum slow, we took action to mitigate the impact and to adapt to the changing environment. Some of the things we've done are unashamedly tactical, putting even tighter controls on spend and headcount, derisking certain portfolios, but the more fundamental changes relate to our strategy and how we are organizing ourselves and deploying our resources to deliver the sustainable, profitable growth and returns that drive shareholder value. That's what I want to focus on today.
But first, let me tell you how we're looking at the world. I don't need to tell you that investor sentiment towards emerging markets turned sharply from May last year and remains quite negative and jumpy. At least as far as our markets are concerned, we think this is a quite short-term, perhaps somewhat overblown, phenomenon. The longer-term attractions of Asia, Africa and the Middle East remain compelling. In fact, we expect our markets to do better in GDP growth terms in 2014 than they did in 2013, with aggregate growth rising from 2.8% to 3.5%. And the underlying drivers of economic growth across the emerging world, demographics, urbanization, rapid growth in the consuming middle class, investment in infrastructure, remain very strong. By 2030, Asia alone will add just over 2.2 billion people to the consuming middle class, taking its share of the global total to about 66%, 2/3. And when I talk to our clients, it's clear that there is some disconnect between the dynamics of global financial markets and the drivers of the real economy. Our clients see much, if not most, of their growth coming from the emerging world and particularly from Asia. They see a robust recovery in the U.S. and even a weak recovery in Europe as huge positives for Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
Of course, there are economic and political risks. Some of our markets face difficult political and social transitions that could have a significant impact on business confidence. India and Indonesia face important elections this year, which will determine the pace of future reforms and GDP growth. Reshaping China's economy will create stresses, the tensions in the South China Sea pose risks. And while we're not directly exposed, we're obviously watching events in Ukraine very carefully, alert to potential lock-ons. So while it may make perfect sense for investors to rebalance their portfolios to capture the rebound in the West, the resulting negative impact on emerging market indices and valuations risks disguising the fundamental attractiveness of these markets.
In addition to the issues specific to our markets, we face some broader challenges. One is the ongoing torrent of regulatory change. The Basel III agenda is nearing completion, which is a considerable achievement and one we welcome, but this risks being undermined by a profusion of unilateral initiatives and interpretations. What the global economy needs now is consistency and stability in the international financial framework.
A second big challenge, which affects the entire industry, is to rebuild trust and credibility. Put bluntly, society expects more of us. We must raise the bar on conduct so that every employee looks to comply with the spirit, not just the letter of the laws and regulations, in everything they do. In 2013, we launched a multipronged program to address this challenge. We have substantially increased resources devoted to conduct issues. We've invested in systems to enhance our controls and reduce the risk of manual errors. We've relaunched our code of conduct, requiring every member of staff to complete mandatory in-depth training and personally commit to the code. We've sharpened the way we link performance assessment and reward to personal values and behaviors. We recognize that we haven't got everything right in the past and that we've got a lot of work to do in this arena, but we are determined to raise the bar to make doing the right thing a front-of-mind imperative for everyone in the bank. That's what Here for good is all about.
The third challenge is technology. As a fundamentally digitizable industry, every aspect of banking can be transformed by technology, yet this is as much an opportunity as a threat. Through technology-driven innovation, we can empower our clients, cut costs, improve risk management, reinvent every aspect of the business. The trick is to make it happen rather than to have it happen to us. At our annual strategy board last June, we took stock of the strategy, asking tough questions about the growth potential in our markets, our ability to win market share, the impact of the more challenging regulatory and market environment. Since capital and investment spend are going to be even scarcer resources, we wanted to sharpen our focus, get really clear on what we should be investing in, where we should cut back. Our answer, which we set out for you in November, was go to the core of what we are all about. We bank the people and companies driving investment, trade and the creation of wealth across Asia, Africa and the Middle East. That's the essence of who we are. We're not trying to bank everybody, but we do want to bank those that are making things happen. We're focused on investment, trade and wealth. We're sticking to the markets we know so well: Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
From this core statement, we distilled, first, a set of 5 strategic aspirations that flesh out how we will grow the core, and I'll put a bit more color on some of these in a moment; second, a set of 5 tests we're applying to more peripheral businesses to ensure we reinforce the core, I'll show you how we're using these; third, a significant reorganization of our regions, business and functions to ensure alignment to the strategy and to streamline the way we work; fourth, our flexed financial framework, which now has 5 metrics, including both positive jaws and capital accretion, we'll use this to explain our performance and ensure we're balancing the imperatives of near-term delivery against longer-term strategic progress; and finally, our, as it happens, 5 priorities for 2014, these are used to set personal and team objectives across the bank, ensuring that everybody is marching to the same tune.
So what you have here is an overarching framework that links strategy to performance and to the way we run the bank and to our immediate priorities. Let me expand a little on each of the elements.
In November, we set out these 5 strategic aspirations that crystallize what we want to achieve in growing the business. Our strategy revolves around relationships, not products, not transactions. We've shown you before the success we've had in deepening relationships with our biggest clients, yet we think we have scope to do much more, particularly by focusing on the next 500 clients. And we could do better in building similarly deep relationships with our smaller corporate, Private Banking and retail clients. This is one of the key reasons why we are reorganizing the business, combining Wholesale and Consumer Banking to create 3 client segment groups and 5 product groups under Mike Rees, who is sitting up here today and will join us in answering questions.
For example, by creating the commercial client segment, we'll make it much easier to focus on the needs of mid-sized corporate clients. Such middle-sized companies are a huge part of the economies in which we operate, up to 60%, and represent a rapidly growing component of the banking revenue pool, yet up to now, we have failed to make the most of this opportunity. We've fragmented our efforts between Wholesale and Consumer Banking and generate less than 10% of our total income from this important client segment. Now we will take a much more integrated approach. Through targeting high-growth and exporting industries and being more efficient in onboarding, we'll grow the client base by leveraging our network and full product capability. We'll make ourselves more relevant and deepen relationships. And when these clients get bigger, we'll transition them up to our Corporate and Institutional client segment, much easier now that we are organized as one global business.
Also, grouping our commercial clients with our Private Banking business will massively facilitate cross-referral. The new commercial segment will start with about 50,000-or-so clients, mainly entrepreneurial family-owned groups that are the perfect target market for Private Banking. Yet up to now, a very small proportion have become Private Banking clients an obvious opportunity. Indeed, the scale of the Private Banking opportunity across our markets is enormous. Today, there is some $10 trillion of assets under management, AUM, from high-net-worth individuals in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. By 2017, this number should more than double.
And we start with a very good platform with $58 billion in AUM, good product capabilities, experienced relationship managers and a network of advisory and booking centers, but we can scale up and enhance our offer, leveraging our client franchise and network more effectively. A great example is the Africa-to-London corridor, which we are superbly positioned to serve given our extensive African footprint and London advisory and booking center.
But the greater emphasis we're putting on Private Banking is just one element of the way we are stepping up our efforts in the Wealth Management arena. Given the pace of individual wealth accumulation across our markets and the relatively early stage in the development of these markets, there's a huge opportunity to provide our retail and Private Banking clients with Wealth Management products and services. This is already a substantial business for us, generating income of $1.3 billion in 2013, but this is only the beginning. Our aspiration is to more than double assets under management by 2020 to $300 billion. That's why we're elevating Wealth Management from being a product group within Consumer Banking to sit alongside our well-established Wholesale Banking product groups in the new structure, like Corporate Finance, Transaction Banking and Financial Markets, which are already all much bigger.
Turning to trade and payments. This is at the heart of what Standard Chartered is all about. We are already a top 2 trade bank by SWIFT data. Our goal is to be #1. We continue to win market share, with average trade assets up by 21% in 2013 against market growth of around 6%. Of course, Trade income was affected by the sharp fall in margins, but we are clearly well placed to benefit as margins stabilize. And we're taking advantage of the shift towards companies using the renminbi for trade and payments.
From virtually nothing in 2009, some 16% of China's trade, just over $730 billion, is now settled in renminbi. By 2020, we think this will more than quadruple to over $3 trillion. To give a sense of the pace at which the renminbi is being internationalized: The Standard Chartered Renminbi Globalization Index, which measures all aspects of offshore renminbi activity, went up 84% in 2013, whilst our own international renminbi payment flows were up 122%. And new things are happening all the time. In December, we launched renminbi clearing in London via a joint venture with Agricultural Bank of China. Last month, we executed the first renminbi cross-border sweeping transaction for a company based in the new Shanghai free-trade zone.
To create the capacity to achieve our strategic aspirations, we need to sharpen our focus. We've therefore been systematically subjecting those businesses that are underperforming or less aligned to our core strategy to 5 tests, asking tough questions about their strategic relevance, alignment with Here for good and sustainable economics. As a result, we are exiting or reconfiguring a number of smaller businesses. And just as important is being more selective about our client relationships. We're exiting or reshaping relationships, both big and small, which offer no prospect of attractive returns, making clear to our clients that, to be sustainable, our relationships have to be economically attractive for both sides. And this has made for some tough conversations. We're also continuing to take action on our most underperforming or problematic businesses, above all, Korea.
As Richard said, our business in Korea had an extremely challenging 2013, with profits down, before the goodwill impairment, $527 million to a loss of $13 million. Much of this was due to a sharp fall in Consumer Banking performance given elevated levels of impairment, up 66%, and income falling by 12%, partly as a result of selective derisking of the unsecured book and the charge we've taken on the prospective sale of 2 small subsidiaries. Weak underlying trading performance was exacerbated by a one-off tax-related charge of $54 million and the non-repeat of last year's property sales which had contributed income of $74 million. Against this, one positive factor was the continued strength of our network income relating to Korean clients, a significant and growing revenue stream of over $200 million.
Of course, we weren't alone in encountering difficulties in Korea. 6 of the 7 major banks saw income and profits fall by double-digit rates, and average ROE was below 3%, the lowest for a decade. As the sixth largest player in the industry, we can't entirely escape the dynamics of the industry, yet neither can we tolerate such underperformance since it creates such a drag on the performance of the bank as a whole, so we are continuing to take action on multiple fronts. There's no silver bullet, but we're shrinking the businesses while very selectively investing to support the areas of most opportunity.  In 2013, we reduced risk-weighted assets in Korea by 7%. In 2014, we will reduce it further.
We're simplifying the structure selling off more consumer finance and savings bank subsidiaries, and we'll reduce the number of legal entities from 9 to 3. We're reducing costs as fast as we can given the constraints, with staff numbers down by nearly 400 year-on-year. We're consolidating the branch network, down by 24 during 2013, as we increasingly interact with our clients through digital means. We're redeploying capital in Wholesale Banking from locally oriented clients towards clients that can benefit from our network. And we're selectively derisking the unsecured book in Consumer Banking and putting greater emphasis on Wealth Management. As a result of these actions, our business in Korea will be smaller, more profitable, more focused on where we can play to our strengths, but given the constrained context, we cannot achieve this transformation as swiftly as we would like. Korea will continue to be very challenging through 2014.
In November, we showed you what we described as our flexed financial framework, setting out the metrics we would aspire to deliver over the next couple of years. As we've said before, these are aspirations. And we don't expect that we will always be able to deliver against all of them, we clearly haven't in the past, but they give you a sense of what it is we're setting out to achieve. We said we did not expect to deliver double-digit income growth over the next couple of years given various pressures, not least Korea. However, we haven't abandoned double-digit growth as a longer-term aspiration. Given the scale of the opportunities in our markets, we believe this remains a stretching but realistic aspiration. Of course, we're not going to compromise our risk appetite or strategic discipline to chase growth. If market circumstances only support somewhat slower growth, that's what we will deliver.
To protect the earnings momentum in an environment of slower income growth, we're shifting from a stance of broadly neutral cost-income jaws towards aiming to deliver positive jaws, i.e. costs growing more slowing than income. This will be challenging given inflationary and regulatory pressures, the bank levy and the measures we're trying -- we're taking to constrain RWA growth. And we must also keep creating the capacity to keep investing for growth. This means we must generate several hundred millions of dollars of productivity benefits every year. We did this in 2013 and we intend to keep doing it. Delivering positive jaws should help us towards our aspirations for earnings per share growth even at sub-double-digit rates of income growth. This in turn will help us continue to improve returns on equity. We already deliver returns above our cost of capital, and we'll continue to look to improve returns whilst also paying out a good level of dividends, as we have consistently done.
In November, we also introduced our fifth metric of growing profits after tax faster than RWA. As Richard has said, we have broadly funded our RWA growth through retained earnings and we are in a strong position in terms of capital ratios, yet given the ongoing uncertainty about regulatory expectations, we think it makes sense to manage for a positive capital trajectory to give us greater flexibility and resilience.
So what are our priorities for 2014? They flow very naturally from our strategic aspirations and financial framework. First, to deliver profitable and capital-accretive growth. After a disappointing performance in 2013, we are determined to get back to delivering the kind of results you expect from us. This won't happen automatically or overnight. Given the weakness of our Q4 performance, we anticipate that the first half of 2014 will prove challenging, but we are confident that the actions we are taking will give us the platform to deliver sustained and profitable growth.
Second, to make tangible progress on our 5 strategic aspirations. Here is where the reorganization will make a difference because it will enable us to put a sharper focus on the key strategic priorities, optimizing the deployment of capital and investment spend.
Third, to innovate, digitize and simplify to improve productivity and effectiveness. For us to simultaneously deliver positive jaws and keep investing for growth, we have to be delivering significant productivity improvements every year, and that requires constant innovation, a bias towards digitizing everything we can and a relentless focus on simplifying and streamlining the way we work. Here again, the reorganization will help. We can strip out some duplications and drive greater standardization.
Fourth, to raise the bar on conduct, demonstrating that we are Here for good. This is a strategic imperative.
And finally, to accelerate the next generation of leaders. The reorganization gives us a real opportunity to do this.
2013 was not a great year for the bank. 2014 will inevitably bring its own challenges, but we are very clear on what we have to do. We're making changes to adapt to the new realities. We have a strong balance sheet and we have great client relationships and superb capabilities.
I'd like to take this opportunity to thank all our staff for their hard work, commitment and professionalism during 2013. I'd particularly like to thank Richard for all he has done in his 11 years as a director, including 7 by my side as Finance Director. And I'd like to thank Steve for his leadership in transforming our Consumer Banking business over the last 5 years. And finally, I'd like to thank you, our analysts and investors, for your support through these turbulent times.
I guess, well, Ben and Julian will now take any questions in Hong Kong. Sunil and Anurag will do the same in Mumbai. John, Richard, Mike and I will take your questions in London. Thank you.

: John Peace (Executives)
Well, good morning, London, and good afternoon to Hong Kong and to Mumbai.
2013 has been a challenging year for the industry and for Standard Chartered. While our clients have remained very active, the overall outcome for the group has not been as good as we would have liked. When this time last year we announced another strong set of results, we said we were not complacent and would continue to refresh our strategy to ensure the group is able to adapt to the changing environment. As we stated at the Investor Day in November, the annual strategy review confirmed that we are in markets where there remain good opportunities for profitable growth. And the new organization structure will ensure that the group is best placed to take advantage of these opportunities by supporting clients and customers in a more seamless way, providing them with access to a broad range of products and services. Now Peter is going to talk about this in more detail, but first, let me comment on the board's perspective.
The board remains intensely focused on shareholders' interests, and this was at the top of our minds last year. The business has grown substantially over the last decade, and the board continues to view Standard Chartered as an exciting growth story over the medium to long term. We remain focused on delivering profitable, sustainable growth that is within our risk appetite. The board aims to grow the amount we return to shareholders each year, and this year, we are recommending a final dividend of $0.572, resulting in a total annual dividend increase of 2%. We have increased the amount of dividend paid to our shareholders each year for well over a decade.
Ensuring the business continues to focus on the returns that are generated for shareholders each year is a top priority for the board, as is maintaining our well-capitalized, highly liquid and diverse balance sheet. Since 2010, we have organically grown our balance sheet, increasing loans and advances to customers by 21%, and yet we still have the same Core Tier 1 ratio at the end of 2013 that we had at the end of 2010. Richard will go into further detail, but we are confident in our ability to achieve capital-accretive growth whilst supporting our clients and the creation of wealth across our markets.
Let me at this point, though, comment briefly on how we remunerate our people, most of whom are not located in the U.K. Consistent with past practice, we reward for good performance, as well as taking into account of how our people deliver long-term sustainable and profitable business. Reflecting our performance in 2013, the bonus pool is down on the prior year by 15%. And we are returning to shareholders by way of dividends around twice as much as we are paying out in bonuses, as this slide clearly shows. Overall, our staff costs are broadly flat compared to last year. This slide also shows how much we're paying out in corporate taxes. That includes the U.K. bank levy, which has increased substantially again this year.
Finally, I would like to comment briefly on the board-level changes we set out in January when we announced the reorganization of the group. Steve Bertamini will step down from the board at the end of this month after more than 5 years leading Consumer Banking. I would like to thank Steve for the very considerable contribution he has made to the business over that time and wish him every success in the future. And sadly, we'll also be saying farewell to Richard Meddings, as this is likely to be his last full year's results presentation. Richard has been on our board for 11 years, and his contribution to the business has been immense. As a colleague and as a friend, I know he will be greatly missed. I'd also like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mike Rees, who many of you already know, as he takes up his new role as Deputy Group CEO next month. Mike will be available to take questions later in the meeting.
So while 2013 has been a challenging year, I believe we remain in good shape to support our clients and customers, and the opportunities for the business remain compelling. We will continue to support the growth of trade and wealth across our markets and continue to drive value for our shareholders, from our competitive strengths and from the opportunities we see in the markets we know so well.
At the same time, our focus on conduct has intensified. We expect the right behavior at all times, as being Here for good is firmly embedded in our DNA. We're therefore confident that we are well positioned to drive further value for our shareholders over the coming months.
Now on that note, let me hand over to Richard.

: Richard Meddings (Executives)
Thank you, John. Good morning, London, and good afternoon, Hong Kong and Mumbai.
2013 was a challenging year both for us and for the industry, with margin and spread compression, volatile financial markets and, for us, Korea which remains difficult. We've responded to these challenges by consistently supporting our customer's growth and by managing costs and risks tightly. We have recently sharpened our strategic focus and flexed our financial framework to strike the right balance between growth, returns and managing for capital accretion.
As with our previous results, we exclude from all of our commentary, own credit adjustments, the impairment of goodwill in Korea and the 2012 settlement with the U.S. authorities. On this basis, profit before tax for the year is down $560 million or 7% to just under $7 billion, driven by a number of factors, including continued challenges in Korea where operating profit is down nearly $530 million, with Consumer Banking contributing $326 million of this fall, Peter will discuss Korea in more detail; material margin compression in Transaction Banking following a significant influx of liquidity into our markets, causing a drag to income of nearly $400 million; and as guided concerning the second half of the year, surrounding the effects of QE tapering as well as increased and, to an extent, unclear, regulation impacting Financial Markets where income fell by $564 million half-on-half, with the fourth quarter 19% lower than the third. The performance pressure in this business, which we highlighted in our pre-close, has since been reflected by other major banks in their recent trading updates. Finally, Principal Finance performed poorly, down over $200 million year-on-year.
A number of these headwinds are easing as we enter 2014. And there were, of course, some very strong performances in the year, including Hong Kong but also in most countries in Africa, the MESA region and India, and also in Mortgages and in Corporate Finance. In response to the challenges, we have been extremely disciplined in managing costs, with expenses for the year only 1% higher than in 2012 at $10.2 billion. And we've achieved this despite inflationary pressure of 4% to 5% across our footprint; continuing our investment programs; absorbing a 63% increase in the underlying cost of the U.K. bank levy, now $266 million; significant increases in regulatory and compliance costs, up some $160 million on 2012; and a one-off VAT-related charge in Korea of $54 million. As we saw our income trajectory slow during the year, we managed our costs assertively.
Now let me draw out several key aspects of our performance. Group income of $18.7 billion was 1% down on 2012, but with 25 markets each now contributing income of over $100 million. As I mentioned earlier, costs remained tightly controlled and were up only 1%. Reflecting a strong but lower profits performance, we have reduced the bonus pool by 15% across the group, and this impact will mainly be borne by the more senior executives. Total impairment has increased 25%. Within this, loan impairment has increased 35%, driven in the main by continued elevated impairment levels in the unsecured Consumer Banking portfolio.
The group delivered profit before tax of nearly $7 billion and normalized earnings of almost $5 billion, down 8%. Normalized return on equity was 11.2% and normalized EPS was $2.04, down 9%. Our balance sheet remains in excellent shape, highly liquid and well diversified. And finally, we remain well capitalized by any measure, both compared to our peers and looking out to 2019, but more on this later.
Moving to our performance by business, and starting with Consumer Banking.
Consumer Banking's performance is in line with our pre-close guidance. Income grew 2% year-on-year, although it fell 5% in the second half. This reflects slower Wealth Management income, the initial impact of derisking the unsecured book and regulatory cooling measures, which dampened Mortgage volumes. Expenses were well controlled, increasing by only 1% year-on-year, delivering positive jaws of 1%. Headcount in Consumer Banking reduced by 7%. Total impairment increased 45%, as guided. And as a result, Consumer Banking operating profit fell 11%.
Korea has continued to have a material impact on the Consumer Banking performance, driven by a difficult operating environment where industry-wide returns on equity have fallen below 3%, continued elevated levels of impairment and the impact of our selective derisking of unsecured products, including the planned sale of the consumer finance businesses. As a result of these challenging conditions, Consumer Banking in Korea made an operating loss of $162 million, which is $326 million lower earnings than the prior year. If you were to exclude Korea, Consumer Banking income was actually up 5%, with profits up 8%, driven by Hong Kong, MESA, India and the Africa region.
Turning to income by product.
Mortgage income was up 10%, reflecting 14 basis points of margin improvement and with Hong Kong a significant driver. Deposit income was down 7% year-on-year, particularly in Hong Kong, Korea, India and China, with margins down 12 basis points to 71 basis points.
Wealth Management income was up 2% year-on-year, although income in the second half was down by 11%. Market uncertainty impacted sentiment, particularly in equity products, representing about 1/3 of Wealth Management income and which were down 17% half-on-half. Hong Kong remained our largest market for Wealth Management, growing income 9% and, together with MESA, which grew income 11%, offset weaker performances in Singapore, Korea and other Asia Pacific.
Income in Credit Cards and Personal Loans increased 5% year-on-year and was broadly flat half-on-half. Selective growth in markets like China, the U.A.E. and Africa was offset by a continued derisking in markets like Korea where we have reduced the credit card and personal loan book by 18% year-on-year to just over $5 billion.
SME income was up 3%, with lower deposit income offset by good growth across lending, FX and trade and working capital as we continue to finance the growth of our SME customers.
Moving to impairment. Consumer Banking loan impairment increased by 53% or $360 million, with Korea accounting for over 40% of the increase. We have taken action in Korea by tightening underwriting standards, changing customer acquisition strategies and exiting customer segments more prone to filing under the Personal Debt Rehabilitation Scheme. Outside of Korea, loan impairment increased by 47% year-on-year, reflecting previous asset growth and the seasoning of the unsecured portfolio, plus some $53 million of lower debt sales. As previously guided, we have taken steps to derisk our unsecured book across the group. Given the slower growth in unsecured assets going forward, we would expect loan impairment from seasoning to moderate in the second half of this year.
Looking now at Wholesale Banking.
Wholesale Banking income is down 2%, which is slightly lower than our expectation at the time of the pre-close, arising from delayed deal execution in Principal Finance as well as continuing weak financial markets conditions. Within this, client income, which represents 86% of Wholesale Banking, was up 4%, and own account income was down 25%.
The operating environment was impacted by a number of factors during the year. Most of these factors were either temporary or cyclical, including the high levels of liquidity in our markets, the persistently low interest rate environment, uncertainty over the pace and timing of QE tapering and indiscriminate deterioration in sentiment on emerging markets in the second half. Other factors like regulatory change impacting derivative markets were more structural in nature.
Expenses were very tightly controlled, increasing only 1% year-on-year, with lower staff costs offsetting increased regulatory expenses. Furthermore, expenses were down 2% in the second half with reduced variable compensation as business performance fell, as well as tight control over hiring and BAU costs.
Total impairment rose 5% year-on-year. And within this, loan impairment was up 12%, representing 39 basis points of Wholesale Banking customer loans and advances. Other impairment was down 19%. As a result, profit before tax for Wholesale Banking is down 4%.
Looking at income in more detail by product.
Within Transaction Banking, Trade income was down 4% and cash and custody income was down 5%, driven by margin compression of 27 basis points or 19% in Trade and 15 basis points or 16% in cash. We saw strong growth in both average trade balances, up 21%, and cash, up 11%. Importantly, margins are showing signs of stabilization, albeit at levels still lower than that of the first half of last year.
Corporate Finance continued to perform strongly, with income up 13% on 2012. As highlighted in the pre-close, despite some delay in deal execution in the second half, income growth remains broad based, with around 70% annuity in nature and with a strong pipeline as we entered 2014.
ALM income was down 10% year-on-year and down 16% half-on-half, reflecting fewer derisking opportunities in the second half and the continued low interest rate environment. Weak equity markets resulted in lower revaluation gains in our Principal Finance investments, and income was down 43%. Although we saw challenging market conditions in 2013, the comparator for 2014 has eased.
Looking at Financial Markets in a little more detail on the next slide. Income in Financial Markets was flat year-on-year at $3.65 billion, as strong volume growth was offset by spread compression. Within this, client income was up 7% and own account income down 25%. Market conditions deteriorated in the second half, as I mentioned earlier, and as a result, Financial Markets income overall was down 27% on the first half. Rising yields on emerging market bonds and directional uncertainty in the markets led to lower own account income. This impacted our Rates business in particular where income dropped by 1/3 compared to a strong first half. Negative emerging market sentiment also impacted income from our financial institution clients, although income from corporates remained robust, albeit in line with usual seasonal trends.
Our foreign exchange business performed well, with income up 11%, driven by cash FX and FX options, supported by our continued strength in offshore renminbi. Cash FX volumes were up 21%, offsetting spread compression of 12%. And in Rates, volumes were also up 20%. Our equities business made reasonable progress, partially offsetting lower commodities income.
Moving to impairment. Total impairment in Wholesale Banking was up 5% year-on-year, driven by a small number of exposures in India and Africa. These exposures drove an increase in gross nonperforming loans, up by some $900 million or 22% on 2012. This represents just over 2% of Wholesale Banking loans and advances, consistent with the levels seen in recent years. The cover ratio, given these exposures, has declined slightly to 48%, but this increases to 60% after including collateral at a forced sale value. The net at risk remains well within our observed historic recovery rates. We are also seeing signs of improving potential recovery levels and, in particular, against a number of nonperforming loans in our MESA region.
The portfolio continues to perform well, and early alerts are stable. We are not seeing any new areas of stress, but we remain watchful in India and also on the potential impact of lower commodity prices more generally.
Turning to the management of risk and the shape of our portfolio. Let me just repeat some of the characteristics of our balance sheet that perhaps get taken for granted but are material points of differentiation from our peers. In Consumer Banking, the book has a continuing bias towards secured lending, with 82% of the book being either fully or partially secured at an average loan-to-value on our Mortgage book of 48%. We continued to derisk the Consumer unsecured portfolio, with Credit Cards and Personal Loans balances down 6% year-on-year. Consumer Banking 30- and 90-day delinquency rates are stable, as are Wholesale Banking early alerts.  As in earlier periods, a significant majority of "past due but not impaired" balances as of the balance sheet date were cured in the following month.
Our portfolios are very diverse. Energy, our largest Wholesale Banking industry concentration, is around 20% of corporate exposures and, as we've shown you before, is in itself highly diversified. We maintain a short-dated Wholesale Banking book, with 64% of the book maturing in under 1 year, reflecting our Trade bias. Trade assets have the lowest propensity to loss of any Wholesale Banking asset category, with an empirical default rate of around 2 basis points.
Wholesale Banking is highly collateralized, with $197 billion in gross total collateral which is held at conservative forced sale values. Stick positions are down by 26% to $1.5 billion, representing less than 1% of Wholesale Banking loans and advances to customers. And finally, we continue to distribute assets successfully, with primary distribution in the year up 9% and loan sales up 29%. The portfolio is therefore diverse, short tenor, highly collateralized and showing no material signs of stress.
Moving to the group's balance sheet.
Liabilities. Our strong and disciplined management of the balance sheet provides us resilience and allows us to take advantages of opportunities for growth. Looking at liquidity: The balance sheet remains highly liquid with an AD ratio of 76%. 52% of customer deposits are in current and savings accounts. We have a liquid asset ratio of 30%, with over $200 billion of the balance sheet in cash or near cash. We remain a strong provider of net interbank liquidity. And we continue to exceed by a substantial degree the Basel III net stable funding ratio and the liquidity coverage ratio, and some years ahead of the required implementation dates.
Turning to assets. Our loan book remains well diversified by geography, industry, counterparty and product. Loans and advances to customers were up 4%, as we continued to support our clients and customers. Risk-weighted assets grew 7%, driven in the main by asset growth, regulatory consolidation of Permata Bank and credit migration. As you can see, Wholesale Banking represents 75% of group risk-weighted assets and grew at 9%, whilst Consumer Banking remained flat.
Now given the recent market focus, I would like to spend some time setting out the strength of our capital position.  
Let me deal with Basel II first. The group's Core Tier 1 ratio was 11.8% at the end of 2013, the same as it was in 2010 and up some 40 basis points since the half year, the product of risk-weighted asset discipline and the phasing of operational risk, risk-weighted assets and dividend payments. Tier 1 was 13.1%, and total capital, 18%. In addition, we currently estimate our PLAC or primary loss absorbing capacity at 23%, again very robust compared to our peers'. Since our 2010 rights issue, we have very evidently self-funded balance sheet growth and the continued payment of a growing dividend. Our Core Tier 1 ratio has remained at 11.8% whilst growing risk-weighted assets by $77 billion at a CAGR of 10% and declared over $5.5 billion in dividends.
Turning to Basel III. On 1st of January 2014, our Basel III common equity Tier 1 ratio is 10.9% on a transitional basis and rises to 11.2% on an endpoint basis. And it's not just our core equity Tier 1 that's strong. For total capital, we are again strong in absolute terms and relative to our peers. We've been active issuers of Tier 2 capital during 2013, with total capital reaching 18%. These issuances showed strong appetite for our credit and an ability to issue across markets and currencies.
So we are well capitalized today in absolute and relative terms on all metrics, including core equity Tier 1, total capital and PLAC. In addition, our leverage ratio stands at a very strong 4.7% at the year end.
We believe it will be helpful for more capital guidance to be given to the market, in particular around the interplay of the various capital buffers and, most importantly, the minimum capital levels for each individual institution. To help clarify, this slide sets out how we see Standard Chartered's capital position against minimum known requirements, which informs the guidance we have received from the PRA.
We begin with a 4.5% minimum core equity Tier 1 requirement common to all banks, a 2.5% capital conservation buffer common to all banks. It is primarily against this buffer that the Pillar 2B or PRA buffer will be assessed and where we are conservatively positioned. A 1% GSIB buffer applicable to Standard Chartered. And a 0.4% Pillar 2A core equity Tier 1 requirement, which is subject to annual review by the PRA. This totals to a known capital stack of 8.4% core equity Tier 1 capital ratio for Standard Chartered, and let's call this our capital stack.
At 10.9% core equity Tier 1, we are already significantly and materially above our capital stack, and by some 250 basis points. We are therefore substantially above the known threshold, with capacity for additional buffers. We are also today already significantly and materially ahead of the target ratios the PRA has guided us to achieve and by 2019.
On this next slide, let's look at the broader industry. It is crucial to understand that capital requirements will differ for each bank. This is the new regulatory model. The PRA's Pillar 2A guidance is different. GSIB buffers are different. Countercyclical buffers and sectoral capital requirements will be different to reflect each bank's unique business model and risk profile. Capital requirements are not uniform, nor should they be. As recent peer results demonstrate, there are variances in the end-state capital levels, with targets ranging from above 10% to 12% or above. When you think about a bank's capital strength, it is not how high the current ratios are or what the target capital ratios are. It is by how much they are above their own capital stack. Let me give you 2 examples.
First, the GSIB capital requirements range from 0 to 2.5%, according to the different systemic risk profiles of each institution. The GSIB requirement for us at 1% is between 1% and 1.5% lower than that of other U.K.-based international banks. We were also included in the 1% category not because the calculation methodology required it but through a supervisory override. This is therefore conservative. Second, Pillar 2A guidance naturally varies from bank to bank, as it reflects the PRA's intention to capture idiosyncratic risks not included in Pillar 1. These include pension, interest rate, credit concentration and operational risks. You will note from other disclosures that this Pillar 2A buffer can be very different between banks. Our current core equity Tier 1 Pillar 2A guidance of some 40 basis points is demonstrably less than a number of our U.K. peers simply because we do not carry any material U.K. pension risk.
To summarize. Our known minimum is 8.4%. The minimum requirement for other banks is very different given they're often higher GSIB or other requirements or a Pillar 2A guidance. Our current buffer above the capital stack of some 250 basis points is clearly very strong compared to peers and positions us very well to manage future regulatory capital demands as they evolve. The laws governing the countercyclical or systemic risk buffers are not yet finalized, but when we stand back and we compare the diversity of our balance sheet and our risk profile against the 250 basis point buffer, we believe we are very strongly positioned with our current capital to absorb any capital add-on that we can see today whilst continuing to support the growth of our clients and customers.
Next slide. Now despite this, the U.K. regulatory sentiment towards capital levels is clear. And there will be further model adjustments, which we currently estimate could be in the range of 30 to 50 basis points for us in 2014. And it is against this backdrop that we introduced the fifth metric to our financial framework: a commitment to gradually accrete capital over time. Whilst we expect risk-weighted assets to be up in 2014 with the introduction of Basel III and expected model changes, we intend to mitigate this by driving capital-accretive profitable growth through the fifth metric; by more assertive tail management of our existing portfolio; and by divesting certain risk-weighted assets, intensive assets and non-core businesses. The combined impact of these latter non-core disposals is expected to be some 10 to 15 basis points benefit to core equity Tier 1 in 2014. Since our Investor Day last November, we have already released $3 billion of risk-weighted assets from low-returning client relationships in Wholesale Banking, which we will look to redeploy into high-returning relationships. As we look into 2014, we have identified over $10 billion in further reductions, over 1/2 of which will be achieved in the first half.
Finally and although we currently have no immediate issuance plans, the regulations now clearly strongly incentivize banks to hold up to 1.5% of risk-weighted assets as additional Tier 1 rather than common equity Tier 1. This is a bank underpinned by excellent foundations, a hugely robust balance sheet, well capitalized, highly liquid, diverse in both assets and liabilities and disciplined by a financial framework that balances growth and returns.
