: Peter Sands (Executives)
Thank you, Richard. Good morning, London, and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and Mumbai.
As you've heard, 2013 was a tough year. We faced margin pressures in a number of key businesses and markets. Regulatory requirements and the bank levy put upward pressure on costs. Various factors drove a sharp increase in unsecured loan impairment. And much more negative sentiment towards emerging markets affected valuations and transaction closing in Wholesale Banking. And we took goodwill impairment on our business in Korea given the severity of the challenges facing us and the industry as a whole in that market. And as a result, we slipped from our trajectory of record income and profits, posting lower income and profits for the first time in over a decade. And our share price fell, reflecting both our own performance and investor sentiment towards our markets.
 
This is not what we aspire to achieve. So as we saw the challenges mount and our momentum slow, we took action to mitigate the impact and to adapt to the changing environment. Some of the things we've done are unashamedly tactical, putting even tighter controls on spend and headcount, derisking certain portfolios, but the more fundamental changes relate to our strategy and how we are organizing ourselves and deploying our resources to deliver the sustainable, profitable growth and returns that drive shareholder value. That's what I want to focus on today.
But first, let me tell you how we're looking at the world. I don't need to tell you that investor sentiment towards emerging markets turned sharply from May last year and remains quite negative and jumpy. At least as far as our markets are concerned, we think this is a quite short-term, perhaps somewhat overblown, phenomenon. The longer-term attractions of Asia, Africa and the Middle East remain compelling. In fact, we expect our markets to do better in GDP growth terms in 2014 than they did in 2013, with aggregate growth rising from 2.8% to 3.5%. And the underlying drivers of economic growth across the emerging world, demographics, urbanization, rapid growth in the consuming middle class, investment in infrastructure, remain very strong. By 2030, Asia alone will add just over 2.2 billion people to the consuming middle class, taking its share of the global total to about 66%, 2/3. And when I talk to our clients, it's clear that there is some disconnect between the dynamics of global financial markets and the drivers of the real economy. Our clients see much, if not most, of their growth coming from the emerging world and particularly from Asia. They see a robust recovery in the U.S. and even a weak recovery in Europe as huge positives for Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
Of course, there are economic and political risks. Some of our markets face difficult political and social transitions that could have a significant impact on business confidence. India and Indonesia face important elections this year, which will determine the pace of future reforms and GDP growth. Reshaping China's economy will create stresses, the tensions in the South China Sea pose risks. And while we're not directly exposed, we're obviously watching events in Ukraine very carefully, alert to potential lock-ons. So while it may make perfect sense for investors to rebalance their portfolios to capture the rebound in the West, the resulting negative impact on emerging market indices and valuations risks disguising the fundamental attractiveness of these markets.
In addition to the issues specific to our markets, we face some broader challenges. One is the ongoing torrent of regulatory change. The Basel III agenda is nearing completion, which is a considerable achievement and one we welcome, but this risks being undermined by a profusion of unilateral initiatives and interpretations. What the global economy needs now is consistency and stability in the international financial framework.
A second big challenge, which affects the entire industry, is to rebuild trust and credibility. Put bluntly, society expects more of us. We must raise the bar on conduct so that every employee looks to comply with the spirit, not just the letter of the laws and regulations, in everything they do. In 2013, we launched a multipronged program to address this challenge. We have substantially increased resources devoted to conduct issues. We've invested in systems to enhance our controls and reduce the risk of manual errors. We've relaunched our code of conduct, requiring every member of staff to complete mandatory in-depth training and personally commit to the code. We've sharpened the way we link performance assessment and reward to personal values and behaviors. We recognize that we haven't got everything right in the past and that we've got a lot of work to do in this arena, but we are determined to raise the bar to make doing the right thing a front-of-mind imperative for everyone in the bank. That's what Here for good is all about.
The third challenge is technology. As a fundamentally digitizable industry, every aspect of banking can be transformed by technology, yet this is as much an opportunity as a threat. Through technology-driven innovation, we can empower our clients, cut costs, improve risk management, reinvent every aspect of the business. The trick is to make it happen rather than to have it happen to us. At our annual strategy board last June, we took stock of the strategy, asking tough questions about the growth potential in our markets, our ability to win market share, the impact of the more challenging regulatory and market environment. Since capital and investment spend are going to be even scarcer resources, we wanted to sharpen our focus, get really clear on what we should be investing in, where we should cut back. Our answer, which we set out for you in November, was go to the core of what we are all about. We bank the people and companies driving investment, trade and the creation of wealth across Asia, Africa and the Middle East. That's the essence of who we are. We're not trying to bank everybody, but we do want to bank those that are making things happen. We're focused on investment, trade and wealth. We're sticking to the markets we know so well: Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
From this core statement, we distilled, first, a set of 5 strategic aspirations that flesh out how we will grow the core, and I'll put a bit more color on some of these in a moment; second, a set of 5 tests we're applying to more peripheral businesses to ensure we reinforce the core, I'll show you how we're using these; third, a significant reorganization of our regions, business and functions to ensure alignment to the strategy and to streamline the way we work; fourth, our flexed financial framework, which now has 5 metrics, including both positive jaws and capital accretion, we'll use this to explain our performance and ensure we're balancing the imperatives of near-term delivery against longer-term strategic progress; and finally, our, as it happens, 5 priorities for 2014, these are used to set personal and team objectives across the bank, ensuring that everybody is marching to the same tune.
So what you have here is an overarching framework that links strategy to performance and to the way we run the bank and to our immediate priorities. Let me expand a little on each of the elements.
In November, we set out these 5 strategic aspirations that crystallize what we want to achieve in growing the business. Our strategy revolves around relationships, not products, not transactions. We've shown you before the success we've had in deepening relationships with our biggest clients, yet we think we have scope to do much more, particularly by focusing on the next 500 clients. And we could do better in building similarly deep relationships with our smaller corporate, Private Banking and retail clients. This is one of the key reasons why we are reorganizing the business, combining Wholesale and Consumer Banking to create 3 client segment groups and 5 product groups under Mike Rees, who is sitting up here today and will join us in answering questions.
For example, by creating the commercial client segment, we'll make it much easier to focus on the needs of mid-sized corporate clients. Such middle-sized companies are a huge part of the economies in which we operate, up to 60%, and represent a rapidly growing component of the banking revenue pool, yet up to now, we have failed to make the most of this opportunity. We've fragmented our efforts between Wholesale and Consumer Banking and generate less than 10% of our total income from this important client segment. Now we will take a much more integrated approach. Through targeting high-growth and exporting industries and being more efficient in onboarding, we'll grow the client base by leveraging our network and full product capability. We'll make ourselves more relevant and deepen relationships. And when these clients get bigger, we'll transition them up to our Corporate and Institutional client segment, much easier now that we are organized as one global business.
Also, grouping our commercial clients with our Private Banking business will massively facilitate cross-referral. The new commercial segment will start with about 50,000-or-so clients, mainly entrepreneurial family-owned groups that are the perfect target market for Private Banking. Yet up to now, a very small proportion have become Private Banking clients an obvious opportunity. Indeed, the scale of the Private Banking opportunity across our markets is enormous. Today, there is some $10 trillion of assets under management, AUM, from high-net-worth individuals in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. By 2017, this number should more than double.
And we start with a very good platform with $58 billion in AUM, good product capabilities, experienced relationship managers and a network of advisory and booking centers, but we can scale up and enhance our offer, leveraging our client franchise and network more effectively. A great example is the Africa-to-London corridor, which we are superbly positioned to serve given our extensive African footprint and London advisory and booking center.
But the greater emphasis we're putting on Private Banking is just one element of the way we are stepping up our efforts in the Wealth Management arena. Given the pace of individual wealth accumulation across our markets and the relatively early stage in the development of these markets, there's a huge opportunity to provide our retail and Private Banking clients with Wealth Management products and services. This is already a substantial business for us, generating income of $1.3 billion in 2013, but this is only the beginning. Our aspiration is to more than double assets under management by 2020 to $300 billion. That's why we're elevating Wealth Management from being a product group within Consumer Banking to sit alongside our well-established Wholesale Banking product groups in the new structure, like Corporate Finance, Transaction Banking and Financial Markets, which are already all much bigger.
Turning to trade and payments. This is at the heart of what Standard Chartered is all about. We are already a top 2 trade bank by SWIFT data. Our goal is to be #1. We continue to win market share, with average trade assets up by 21% in 2013 against market growth of around 6%. Of course, Trade income was affected by the sharp fall in margins, but we are clearly well placed to benefit as margins stabilize. And we're taking advantage of the shift towards companies using the renminbi for trade and payments.
From virtually nothing in 2009, some 16% of China's trade, just over $730 billion, is now settled in renminbi. By 2020, we think this will more than quadruple to over $3 trillion. To give a sense of the pace at which the renminbi is being internationalized: The Standard Chartered Renminbi Globalization Index, which measures all aspects of offshore renminbi activity, went up 84% in 2013, whilst our own international renminbi payment flows were up 122%. And new things are happening all the time. In December, we launched renminbi clearing in London via a joint venture with Agricultural Bank of China. Last month, we executed the first renminbi cross-border sweeping transaction for a company based in the new Shanghai free-trade zone.
To create the capacity to achieve our strategic aspirations, we need to sharpen our focus. We've therefore been systematically subjecting those businesses that are underperforming or less aligned to our core strategy to 5 tests, asking tough questions about their strategic relevance, alignment with Here for good and sustainable economics. As a result, we are exiting or reconfiguring a number of smaller businesses. And just as important is being more selective about our client relationships. We're exiting or reshaping relationships, both big and small, which offer no prospect of attractive returns, making clear to our clients that, to be sustainable, our relationships have to be economically attractive for both sides. And this has made for some tough conversations. We're also continuing to take action on our most underperforming or problematic businesses, above all, Korea.
As Richard said, our business in Korea had an extremely challenging 2013, with profits down, before the goodwill impairment, $527 million to a loss of $13 million. Much of this was due to a sharp fall in Consumer Banking performance given elevated levels of impairment, up 66%, and income falling by 12%, partly as a result of selective derisking of the unsecured book and the charge we've taken on the prospective sale of 2 small subsidiaries. Weak underlying trading performance was exacerbated by a one-off tax-related charge of $54 million and the non-repeat of last year's property sales which had contributed income of $74 million. Against this, one positive factor was the continued strength of our network income relating to Korean clients, a significant and growing revenue stream of over $200 million.
Of course, we weren't alone in encountering difficulties in Korea. 6 of the 7 major banks saw income and profits fall by double-digit rates, and average ROE was below 3%, the lowest for a decade. As the sixth largest player in the industry, we can't entirely escape the dynamics of the industry, yet neither can we tolerate such underperformance since it creates such a drag on the performance of the bank as a whole, so we are continuing to take action on multiple fronts. There's no silver bullet, but we're shrinking the businesses while very selectively investing to support the areas of most opportunity.  In 2013, we reduced risk-weighted assets in Korea by 7%. In 2014, we will reduce it further.
We're simplifying the structure selling off more consumer finance and savings bank subsidiaries, and we'll reduce the number of legal entities from 9 to 3. We're reducing costs as fast as we can given the constraints, with staff numbers down by nearly 400 year-on-year. We're consolidating the branch network, down by 24 during 2013, as we increasingly interact with our clients through digital means. We're redeploying capital in Wholesale Banking from locally oriented clients towards clients that can benefit from our network. And we're selectively derisking the unsecured book in Consumer Banking and putting greater emphasis on Wealth Management. As a result of these actions, our business in Korea will be smaller, more profitable, more focused on where we can play to our strengths, but given the constrained context, we cannot achieve this transformation as swiftly as we would like. Korea will continue to be very challenging through 2014.
In November, we showed you what we described as our flexed financial framework, setting out the metrics we would aspire to deliver over the next couple of years. As we've said before, these are aspirations. And we don't expect that we will always be able to deliver against all of them, we clearly haven't in the past, but they give you a sense of what it is we're setting out to achieve. We said we did not expect to deliver double-digit income growth over the next couple of years given various pressures, not least Korea. However, we haven't abandoned double-digit growth as a longer-term aspiration. Given the scale of the opportunities in our markets, we believe this remains a stretching but realistic aspiration. Of course, we're not going to compromise our risk appetite or strategic discipline to chase growth. If market circumstances only support somewhat slower growth, that's what we will deliver.
To protect the earnings momentum in an environment of slower income growth, we're shifting from a stance of broadly neutral cost-income jaws towards aiming to deliver positive jaws, i.e. costs growing more slowing than income. This will be challenging given inflationary and regulatory pressures, the bank levy and the measures we're trying -- we're taking to constrain RWA growth. And we must also keep creating the capacity to keep investing for growth. This means we must generate several hundred millions of dollars of productivity benefits every year. We did this in 2013 and we intend to keep doing it. Delivering positive jaws should help us towards our aspirations for earnings per share growth even at sub-double-digit rates of income growth. This in turn will help us continue to improve returns on equity. We already deliver returns above our cost of capital, and we'll continue to look to improve returns whilst also paying out a good level of dividends, as we have consistently done.
In November, we also introduced our fifth metric of growing profits after tax faster than RWA. As Richard has said, we have broadly funded our RWA growth through retained earnings and we are in a strong position in terms of capital ratios, yet given the ongoing uncertainty about regulatory expectations, we think it makes sense to manage for a positive capital trajectory to give us greater flexibility and resilience.
So what are our priorities for 2014? They flow very naturally from our strategic aspirations and financial framework. First, to deliver profitable and capital-accretive growth. After a disappointing performance in 2013, we are determined to get back to delivering the kind of results you expect from us. This won't happen automatically or overnight. Given the weakness of our Q4 performance, we anticipate that the first half of 2014 will prove challenging, but we are confident that the actions we are taking will give us the platform to deliver sustained and profitable growth.
Second, to make tangible progress on our 5 strategic aspirations. Here is where the reorganization will make a difference because it will enable us to put a sharper focus on the key strategic priorities, optimizing the deployment of capital and investment spend.
Third, to innovate, digitize and simplify to improve productivity and effectiveness. For us to simultaneously deliver positive jaws and keep investing for growth, we have to be delivering significant productivity improvements every year, and that requires constant innovation, a bias towards digitizing everything we can and a relentless focus on simplifying and streamlining the way we work. Here again, the reorganization will help. We can strip out some duplications and drive greater standardization.
Fourth, to raise the bar on conduct, demonstrating that we are Here for good. This is a strategic imperative.
And finally, to accelerate the next generation of leaders. The reorganization gives us a real opportunity to do this.
2013 was not a great year for the bank. 2014 will inevitably bring its own challenges, but we are very clear on what we have to do. We're making changes to adapt to the new realities. We have a strong balance sheet and we have great client relationships and superb capabilities.
I'd like to take this opportunity to thank all our staff for their hard work, commitment and professionalism during 2013. I'd particularly like to thank Richard for all he has done in his 11 years as a director, including 7 by my side as Finance Director. And I'd like to thank Steve for his leadership in transforming our Consumer Banking business over the last 5 years. And finally, I'd like to thank you, our analysts and investors, for your support through these turbulent times.
I guess, well, Ben and Julian will now take any questions in Hong Kong. Sunil and Anurag will do the same in Mumbai. John, Richard, Mike and I will take your questions in London. Thank you.

The group's most material market risk exposures are to credit risk, principally from the U.K. and Jackson fixed annuity portfolios; and to equity markets mainly from with-profit shareholder transfers in the U.K. and the fund-related charges in Asia. The group's most material non-market risk exposure is to lapse mortality and morbidity risk in Asia and to longevity risk on U.K. annuities.

0766807.transcript_text1:
Good morning, and welcome to our presentation of our 2014 interim results. As usual, Jonathan will take you through our financial performance, and I'll then provide an update of our businesses and the strategic progress we've made in the first half. After the formal presentation, we'll be available to take any questions.
Before I hand over to Jonathan, I'd first like to share with you the highlights of our performance in the first half of the year. The group continues to perform strongly. We delivered adjusted operating profit growth of 21%, GBP 97 million, in the period, with all 3 divisions contributing to the improved performance. As a result, adjusted earnings per share increased 19% to 50p.
Importantly, we continued to deliver strong returns while maintaining our high-quality balance sheet and strong capital position. In the period, reporting for the first time under CRD IV, our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio remained strong at 13.2%, while we improved the group's return on opening equity to 18%.
Finally, I'm pleased to say that this morning, we've announced a 10% increase in the interim dividend to 16.5p. Overall, we remain well-positioned for growth, as I'll discuss later on.
I'll now hand over to Jonathan.

---

Good morning, everyone, and I thank your presence. I'll now take you through our performance for the first half.
As you can see, we have delivered a strong result for the period. Overall, we have reported a 21% increase in adjusted operating profit to GBP 97 million. All 3 divisions increased their contribution to group profits. The bank is up 14% to GBP 90 million, driven by good loan book growth and lower bad debts. Securities profits increased by 58% to GBP 17 million. And Winterflood's profits grew by 81%, as trading conditions improved against the subdued first half in the prior year.
Asset Management continued to make progress, with adjusted operating profit of GBP 3 million. Finally, net group expenses increased to GBP 12 million, but the prior period included one-off income of GBP 2 million.
Looking now at the income statements in more detail. We've recorded a 14% rise in income, driven by good loan book growth in the bank, and improved investor risk appetite in securities. Expense income ratio has remained stable at 63%, as operating expenses increased by 14% to GBP 203 million. We've continued to invest in the bank to support further growth, and in securities, variable expenses increased as revenue improved.
The tax charge was GBP 22 million, corresponding to an effective tax rate of 23%. As a result, adjusted earnings per share increased by 19% to 50.4p. And we declared an interim dividend of 16.5p, an increase of 10% from last year, reflecting the strong earnings in the period.
The balance sheet continues to be simple and transparent, principally comprising assets and liabilities relating to lending activities in our banking division. The loan book and treasury assets account for over 80% of the group's total assets. The loan book grew by GBP 200 million or 5% to GBP 4.9 billion in the first half. The risk profile of the loan book has remained consistent, principally the short-term around 90% secured and with prudent loan-to-value ratios.
Treasury assets decreased slightly to about GBP 900 million. They represent our holding of high-quality liquid assets, principally deposits with the Bank of England. Our liquidity position remains strong and comfortably ahead of regulatory requirements. The securities assets, which include short-term settlement balances and trading positions increased GBP 200 million to around GBP 800 million, reflecting increased trading activity immediately preceding the balance sheet date. These assets are largely offset by related liabilities, with the net position remaining broadly stable at around GBP 100 million. Overall total assets increased by 4% to GBP 7.1 billion in the first half.
We have maintained our strong funding position with its emphasis on diversity and prudence. In the first, total funding increased to GBP 6.4 billion, covering a sum of 132% of the loan book at the balance sheet date. This reflects continued growth in our cost of deposits which increased by GBP 135 million to GBP 4.1 billion. Our term funding over 1 year remains stable at GBP 3.4 billion, this remains a prudent level relative to the loan book, which was 71% covered by term funding at the balance sheet date. And the average maturity of the term funding of 23 months continues to comfortably exceed the loan book at 13 months.
We are reporting for the first time under CRD IV. The group's capital remains strong with a common equity Tier 1 ratio of 13.2% and a leverage ratio at 9.3%, despite continuing growth in the loan book. The impact of CRD IV is broadly neutral. The group has taken the benefit of the discount for SME lending, but this has been offset by new deduction for foreseeable dividends. This arises from new regulations which apply to the whole banking industry.
The reduction in common equity Tier 1 capital to GBP 670 million is largely due to the new foreseeable dividend deduction. This is calculated by taking the group average payout ratio over a 3-year period, and applying it for the first half earnings. We remain focused on holding an appropriate level of capital and continue to monitor and manage capital resources carefully.
The banking division delivered a good performance in the first half, as the loan book continue to grow and bad debts improved. Income increased by 11% to GBP 218 million, principally due to a 10% increase in net interest and fees on the loan book. Cost increased by 15% to GBP 106 million, as we continue to invest in our business to support growth. This included additional volume-related costs, including increased head count in both the front and back office, to continue to support our customer proposition and infrastructure investments to ensure our technology remains robust and secure. Overall, the bank's expense income ratio increased slightly to 48%.
The strong credit performance across the portfolio has meant the bad debt charges on the loan book reduced by 12% to GBP 23 million. Overall, profit increased 14% to GBP 90 million, and the return on equity of the division, increased to 25%. This reflects our strong returns, but also improved balance sheet efficiency and lower tax rates.
The loan book has grown by 5% to GBP 4.9 billion in the first half, and by 11% over the last 12 months. Importantly, none of our distribution channels have reached maturity, and we expect continued growth across our proposition as we build scale. Lastly, we continue to make progress towards our medium-term profitability target, as well as benefiting from operating leverage as we build scale, we're also focused on improving the efficiency of our advice process for clients.
The revenue margin increased slightly in the period and we expect this to improve over time depending upon the business mix. We're confident we'll continue to increase our operating margin, and are on track to achieve our 15% target by 2015.

And in Asset Management, we continue to make progress as the business builds scale. Overall, we remain confident in the outlook for the year.

We have developed a vertically integrated model, founded on our core capabilities of financial planning, advice, research, investment management and platform technology, all enabling clients to choose the services they require according to their personal preference. Our professional advisors assist clients in developing their financial plan. This is broad in scope, and covers forecasting lifetime earnings, expenditure and retirement income. We help clients establish a long-term investment strategy, and assist with tax and pension solutions, insurance to protect against key risks, as well as a estate planning for the next-generation.
Alongside this, we provide global diversified investment management across all liquid asset classes to a range of investment vehicles. These include our own funds, model portfolios, and a fully bespoke service for our high-net-worth clients. Our platform technology provides clients with a consolidated picture of their wealth. We've designed these capabilities to work in tandem, and to deliver comprehensive and integrated approach for the clients.
In particular, we believe our range of capabilities and the flexibility of our proposition is differentiated and well-suited to the current environment. We develop strong credentials in our markets and are building scale in the business. We have over 120 financial advisors and 50 investment professionals, managing over GBP 9 billion of client assets. We remain focused on building, enduring long-term relationships with our clients, and we'll benefit as they increase their assets over time.
Ultimately, we earn revenue from several sources: Advice, investment management and our platform, which maximizes our profit potential per client, and provides significant scalability, particularly in investment management and through our platform.
Now looking at the last 6 months, the division has continued to make progress towards our profitability target. We continue to build scale, growing assets under management in the period, and seeing solid demand for our products, reflecting the quality of our integrated proposition. We're benefiting from investment and distribution, and are seeing good growth, particularly in our managed AuM. Supported by the strong performance to our funds, we continue to see good demand for our close discretionary fund range, which provides a cost-effective way to access professional investment management for both our own and  third party advisors.
Importantly, none of our distribution channels have reached maturity, and we expect continued growth across our proposition as we build scale. Lastly, we continue to make progress towards our medium-term profitability target, as well as benefiting from operating leverage as we build scale, we're also focused on improving the efficiency of our advice process for clients.
The revenue margin increased slightly in the period and we expect this to improve over time depending upon the business mix. We're confident we'll continue to increase our operating margin, and are on track to achieve our 15% target by 2015.
So to conclude, our business model, strong performance and financial position, ensure that we're well-placed going forward. We're confident in our strategy, seeing good opportunities for growth, and we'll continue to deliver strong returns for our shareholders. In Banking, we expect to continue to deliver good growth at attractive margins. Winterflood is well-positioned to continue to benefit from a stronger cyclical recovery. And in Asset Management, we continue to make progress as the business builds scale. Overall, we remain confident in the outlook for the year.
We now look forward to answering any questions you may have. As well as to Jonathan and myself, we have Stephen Hodges from Banking, Julian Palfreyman from Winterflood, and Martin Andrew from Asset Management, who will also be happy to take any questions. As usual, could you please state your name and company before asking a question.

Do you want to take the non-interest income?

---

Yes, yes. That line is -- includes treasury income. That just represents a timing -- a temporary effect, and also represents the fact that we are seeing slightly improved rates that can be achieved in the funding market. Should we factor that into a change in the net interest margin? The answer is, no, for 2 reasons: One is, we are seeing increased competition across the book. Everything else being equal, we will begin to see the common equity Tier 1 ratio increase. And that contrasts to our results presentation 6 months ago, when I was asked the same question. I think, we are just, again, continuing the nice evolution that we did over the years.

Once adjusted for these items, adjusted net earnings stood at $175 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2014, an increase of 14.4%, while adjusted diluted earnings per share stood at approximately $0.92, an increase of 13.6%. Please remember that our earnings for SFR for the third quarter of fiscal 2014 include 110 days compared to 123 days for the third quarter of fiscal 2013.
The growth is in net earnings derived partially from the nice results in same-store merchandise sales and fuel volumes. The strong road transportation fuel margin interrupt as well as the contributions from our acquisition also played an important part in the increase in earnings for the third quarter of fiscal 2014. Again, the contribution from our organic growth, including the impact of our continuous focus on the food, as well as the contribution from our acquisition, are the usual components of our long-established recipe. These items, which contributed to the growth in net earnings, were partially offset by the negative net impact of the conversion of our sales and expenses from our Canadian and European operations, in U.S. dollars, as well as by lower revenues, following the divestiture of our LPG business in December 2012. These results are solid when taking into account the unfavorable weather, which affected many of our North American markets, and the state of the economy in general. 
Now let's take a look on our key figures. Our organic growth is reflected in our same-store merchandise sales, which increased by 2.8% (sic) [3.8%] in the United States, by 8.9% in Europe and by 2.2% in Canada. More specifically, in North America, this growth is noteworthy, considering the unfavorable weather, which affected many of our markets, as previously stated. This increase in all our markets is the result of the pricing strategies we adopted during the previous quarter, aimed at increasing traffic in our stores as well as through the continuous efforts we've put in the fresh food category. This helped us keep our momentum in terms of transaction count. In Europe, this is the fourth quarter in a row that same-store sales are showing positive results.
The merchandise and service gross margin for the third quarter was mainly impacted by our pricing strategy and stood at 32.7% in the United States and at 32.7% in Canada. Gross margin for merchandise and service in Europe posted at 43.2%. Excluding the negative impact from the translation of our European and Canadian operations into U.S. dollars, growth in dollars of the merchandise and service gross margin is positive, even though partially offset by the impact of the lower number of days of SFR results for the third quarter of fiscal 2014.
Same-store volume increased by 1.3% in the United States, by 2.7% in Europe and by 2.1% in Canada. This quarter growth in Europe also confirm the positive trend shown during the last 4 quarters. Our fuel brand, miles, is, of course, a good contributor to our results, and help us to take some market share, where the rollout is completed. 
During the quarter, motor fuel gross margin in the U.S. posted at $0.1702 per gallon, at $0.1144 per liter in Europe and $0.0587 per liter in Canada. As usual, we continue our good work at controlling expenses.
Third quarter EBITDA increased by 7.5% compared to the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year, reaching $425.1 million. Net of acquisition costs, acquisition contribute $9 million to EBITDA, while the variation in exchange rates had a negative impact of approximately $5 million. Excluding the curtailment gain on pension plans, obligation of the third quarter of fiscal 2014 as well as the negative goodwill for both comparable periods, the third quarter of fiscal 2014 adjusted EBITDA increased by $22.4 million, or 5.7%, compared to the corresponding period on the previous fiscal year, reaching $417.6 million.
For the third quarter of fiscal 2014, depreciation, amortization and impairment expenses increased by $3.4 million, mainly due to an impairment charge on a non-operational lubricant plant in Poland, partially offset by the fact that the third quarter of fiscal 2014 only includes 110 days of SFR results compared with 123 days for the third quarter of fiscal 2013. We have completed our analysis of the remaining useful life and depreciation periods of the SFR assets, and final results are not significantly different from the preliminary estimates already reflected in the previous quarter.
Excluding the net foreign exchange gain of $10.4 million and the net foreign exchange loss of $13.6 million recorded, respectively, in the third quarters of fiscal 2014 and fiscal 2013, the decrease in net financial expenses is $3.6 million, explained by the reduction in our long-term debt following repayments we made on our revolving and acquisition facilities.
The income tax rate for the third quarter of fiscal 2014 was 16.1%, compared to 13% for the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal year. Income tax rate is still impacted by the negative goodwill recorded in the first quarter in the United States, where we have our highest statutory tax rate. Without it, our tax rate would only have been slightly higher compared with last year for the first 3 quarters of fiscal 2014.
For the third quarter of fiscal 2014, adjusted net earnings were $175 million, an increase of 14.4%, while adjusted diluted net earnings per share were $0.92, an increase of 13.6%.
During the third quarter, we repaid an additional amount of $265 million on our credit facilities. Since the beginning of the fiscal year, a total of $720 million has been repaid on our facility, from cash generated from our operations.
As at February 2, 2014, our adjusted net interest-bearing debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio of 2.51%, shows rapid improvement compared with the same ratio of 3.05% as at April 28, 2013, and 3.58% shortly after the acquisition of the Statoil Fuel & Retail in June 2012, giving us more flexible to take advantage of investment opportunity that may arise. Our return on capital employed also improved from 12.1% shortly after the acquisition to 13.3% for the third quarter of fiscal 2014. 
And that concludes my part. Alain?

---

Thank you, Raymond. I will start my closing comments in correcting the number I said about the new stores opened since the beginning of the fiscal year. It's since the -- it's in the last quarter, 14 stores were built in the last quarter. And it's less than normal while we have strict CapEx this year because of the debt reimbursement we did focus on.
I'm satisfied with the results of the third quarter. The outcome of our continuous effort to improve our in-store over to our clients and to generate traffic that can result in increased sales and gross profit can be measured by organic growth in North America and Europe. Our various exciting projects with SFR are moving forward, and new opportunities are still being identified. That will keep the teams busy for some time, and will generate long-lasting value for Couche-Tard.
We will now answer questions you submitted earlier today.

2011646.transcript_text3:
You have noted that North American customers are so very value-focused, and this seems you're working to provide the right balance in sales and margins and employee-specific tactics to drive baskets. Has this backdrop remained same throughout the third quarter relative to the first half of your fiscal year? And generally, which of your tactics are proving most effective?

---

This is Brian. I'll take that one. I'd say the pressures on the customer is still there as we see -- looking at post-releases from not only our channel, but other retailers. In terms of our tactics, a lot of different ones across our various business units, but I'll lump them into 3 big buckets. In terms of increasing the basket, our focus in more combos, bundling chips and drinks, things like that, 2 floors. Our layouts, improving our adjacencies, using data we have from our scan to use more science from what items to put where in the store, which I would say has been our most successful to-date, and a lot of work done in that regard. And then the third would be suggested selling, which I would still characterize as a work in process and, probably, the most potential. If we can get our 80,000 people engaged every day consistently in selling more, that's our biggest opportunity.

---

In addition to your ongoing acquisition of sites, you also have a new store program that is reasonably active. Can you talk about how stores of 2014, the new openings, might differ? If they do, from stores you opened, say, 5 years ago in terms of features, configuration, and et cetera, is there any influence from your SFR experience that figures into the new store thinking in North America?

---

I'll take that one. As I said, we have slowed down the new to industry stores for the last fiscal, or this actual fiscal, for focusing on debt reimbursement. So we will have quite a big number of stores that are ready to go for next fiscal. What we do as a difference in size today, we were building 2,400 square feet stores up to 5 years ago. Then 5 years ago, we started to use the 3,200 square feet minimum as a box; and now, we're building more in the range of 3,600 square foot. So we go up to 4,500 square foot. So these are the full math we are using today. So bigger stores with more food service offering, better aligned between the divisions. So we are going with 2 different formats instead of 5 or 6 before. And we are testing a lot of different offers we have in Europe in different division. So we will see how it goes and, eventually, pick the right product for the right division. So this is ongoing. Brian will talk about more food service later in this discussion. About the other offer, about other than the food service, you would see more doors, more cooler doors in our stores. We were 10 doors. Now it's more, 15 to 20 doors. And we have a lot more other beverages that include, energy drink and water, and all sort of different waters - the vitamin waters and all different waters today, so - and it's growing quite fast. So yes, a big, big configuration difference today as opposed to 5 years ago.

---

Let me add outside the box. We've become more disciplined around parking spaces, distance between the pumps and the store, distance between the pumps and the road. We have found -- and QuikTrip and people like that have shown us the customer value, freedom of movement and ease of movement on our sites. So I think you'll see -- and you do see more of that discipline in our new developments.

---

Can you provide an update on your food service and fresh food initiatives? What percentage of in-store growth margin does fresh food and food service represents?

---

Yes, I will take this one. It's Raymond Par. The food is still a catalyst and a big focus for us. Over a 17% of our total margin come from this category. We are experiencing solid same-store sales growth. And as a you just heard, it's clear that in our new stores and in our existing stores, it's clearly a category that we're pushing and making, I will say, more and more important.

---

What would be an appropriate tax rate to use for fiscal year 2015?

---

As you know, we don't have -- we don't give any kind of forecast. Of course, the trend could slightly be down. I will say, be up, the rate, with the deleveraging, but it's only if you are taking this factor in consideration. Again, not given factor or, I will say, forecast. But for sure, as we said in the past, the de-leveraging element will have an impact to push the rate slightly up, but it's not the only factor that could influence the tax rate.

---

With regards to the change in management, can you talk about how you see Alain's role and Brian's role complementing one another and evolving over time, and why now?

---

We'll start with the why now. It's a personal timing for Brian and I; and timing, good timing for the board too. We have had undertaking discussions for the last couple of years. And it also goes with the size we are today. With the Europe, with the Asia and North America, we thought it was a good timing for me to evolve in the role of more focused on acquisition and M&A activities, single sites -- NPI and the single sites acquisition and small buckets of store acquisition. And Brian is ready. I mean, he has been with the company a number of years, and he is well-known by the organization, well respected. So that's the right thing to do and now is the right time. So Brian -- maybe, Brian, you can comment on what would be your role and...

---

Everything else, everything Alain doesn't want to do.

---

No, no. I like everything I do. I will participate in some of the store visit, market visit, but less. It's very demanding. So Brian will focus on everything else.

---

Can you please provide an update on the fresh food initiative? How satisfied are you with the ongoing progress, growth rate of fresh food versus the balance of the inside categories, the proportion of inside sales from fresh food and any near-term initiatives?

---

So assuming this question focuses on North America, we've launched 4 markets, and in the process of our fifth, what we call as our fresh pilots. And this is -- this would entail, typically, 6-times-per-week delivery, the primary categories or foundation being fresh meat, pastries and sandwiches every day, and then also provide the foundation of delivery from a lot of other SKUs, such as salads, parfaits, fruit. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for AutoZone's 2014 Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Bill Giles, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, IT and ALLDATA; and Brian Campbell, Vice President, Treasurer, Investor Relations and Tax. 
Regarding the second quarter, I hope you've had an opportunity to read our press release and learn about the quarter's results. If not, the press release, along with the slides complementing our comments today, is available on our website, www.autozoneinc.com. Please click on Quarterly Earnings Conference Calls to see them.
To begin this morning, I want to thank all AutoZoners across the globe for another very good quarter. This morning, we reported our 30th consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings per share growth. That accomplishment is a testament to our organization's focus and discipline around delivering consistent WOW! Customer Service. 
Let's spend some time this morning discussing our sales results and provide you some details on regional and product sales trends. We'll also provide some detail on the cadence of sales throughout the 12-week quarter. Next, we will update you on our digital integration initiatives and our international store performance. Finally, we'll highlight what we've been doing to improve our business model for today and beyond. We're very excited about the initiatives we're working on and believe our recent learnings will help to shape our company's future for years to come.
For the quarter, we reported total sales increase of 7.3%, while same-store sales were up 4.3%. This overall sales performance showed noticeable improvement from our Q1 results. I do want to point out that part of the increase in DIY was due to the calendar shift resulting from our 53rd week in fiscal 2013. Our DIY same-store sales would have been approximately 1% lower if we were comparing to the same weeks last year.
Commercial continued to outpace the growth of our retail business. This quarter, retail showed marked acceleration from recent trends. The colder weather across much of the U.S. drove robust traffic on batteries antifreeze and wiper blades.
However, our West Coast stores experienced less favorable weather for parts failures. Abnormally dry conditions led to fewer, for example, wiper blade sales in our stores on the West Coast. We also experienced growth in both traffic and ticket across both our retail and commercial customer segments. Our failure-related hard part categories experienced the highest growth in both retail and commercial.
Clearly, the weather was a significant factor, but we also believe that work that we have been doing to improve inventory availability had us very well positioned to capitalize on the increased demand. We feel as we've continued to improve our hard parts product availability, this has led to increasing traffic and ticket, especially in commercial where the vast majority of the business is in hard parts.
In regard to the cadence of sales trends for the quarter, November, December and through mid-January, our sales ran quite strong, above 5% in same-store sales. However, for the last month of our quarter, our same-store sales slowed. During those weeks, our results dropped into the low single-digit range. We experienced a slowdown across both our retail and commercial businesses.
The culprit, strange, as it is for me to say, was the weather. It seems I've spent a career talking about how weather, in particular extreme weather, drives positive results for us. But by late January, by the time several of the U.S. regions were experiencing their third or fourth heavy cold snap, the parts that were close to failing appeared to have already failed earlier in the season.
Additionally, the later storms, particularly across the Southeast, caused us and our commercial customers to close due to the severity of the storms and the poor driving conditions. As we look at the balance of the year, we believe there will be a lingering positive effect on our industry.
2 years ago, the winter was quite mild, and we highlighted that as a headwind for our business for months. Conversely, after the extensive winter we have had this year, we anticipate that demand will remain strong as we head into the spring and summer seasons. While certain failure-related categories were particularly strong during the second quarter, other categories, specifically maintenance categories that can be deferred, were challenged. We expect these deferred projects to be completed in the balance of the year.
Regarding the consumer, we continue to believe our consumer remains under pressure. However, we feel 2014 has several positive items going forward. One large headwind has now been anniversary-ed, the payroll tax reinstatement last year. Another is gas prices have begun to abate, and we believe this can have a positive effect on our customers' ability to spend on routine maintenance.
With approximately 10 billion of gasoline consumed monthly in the U.S., any sizable move in price can have a material stimulus on the economy. Currently, gasoline prices are approximately $3.35 a gallon, about $0.25 a gallon below this time last year.
As we are heading into what is forecast to be a more normal spring and summer weather pattern, we are optimistic on the sales front. We continue to assume the most pronounced effects will be felt in the Midwest and Northeast markets, as these have been the most challenged for a couple of years.
Regarding market share, the data we have available to us is showing we're gaining share on both the retail and commercial fronts. We are especially focused on improving our trends in the application parts area where our efforts to improve our assortments would have the most impact.
And so far, we are encouraged. We feel the initiatives we're working on are making a difference. For example, we have enhanced our electronic catalog to better serve our customers by further highlighting related items necessary to do the complete job. We believe these enhancements will improve the customer experience and will complement the knowledge of our AutoZoners. While we are early in our efforts, the feedback we're receiving from AutoZoners and customers is encouraging.
Regarding DIY ticket and traffic trends, both increased for the quarter. As I previously mentioned, the traffic count was much stronger earlier in the quarter versus the last few weeks. While we've experienced traffic growth in commercial for several years, it was exciting to see growth in the retail channel.
On the average ticket front, retail continues to be up but at a lower rate than our historical experience. One driver of the lower retail ticket has been the lack of commodity-based inflation. Currently, we don't see any indications of that trend changing materially in the short to mid-term. While that is good news for our customers, it has certainly challenged our results.
On the commercial front, we were pleased to see a higher average ticket tied to as noted earlier, more hard parts sales. Overall, we don't have control over the macro factors that impact our business, and that is why we have intensified our efforts on enhancing our offerings. Our efforts on the initiatives we have underway or in test should lead to ongoing sales growth. 
We're pleased with the progress we're making in our commercial business. Our sales increased 12.2% from last year's second quarter, and we opened 49 new programs to finish with 74% of our domestic stores having a commercial sales program. This brings our year-to-date openings to 174. We expect to open a similar number of programs this year as we did last year.
Our all other businesses increased approximately 31% over last year. Starting this quarter, we began to anniversary our acquisition of AutoAnything. The all other segment of our business includes AutoAnything, autozone.com and ALLDATA.
Regarding these businesses, we've introduced the idea of being more digitally integrated. Therefore, we've made this 1 of our 4 strategic growth priorities, along with retail, commercial and international. While in an early stage, we believe this can be an important and significant opportunity for us to deepen customer relationships and ultimately grow sales. 
At this point in the evolution of our online offering, we're focusing more on data compilation and building a knowledge portal than on current sales. Today, shoppers use our websites for educating themselves on what they need for their vehicles, and they continue to buy the vast majority of what they need from our stores, which to us makes perfect sense and is in line with our operating plans. Our objective is to satisfy our customers' needs regardless of how they want to interact with us.
Now I'd like to update you on our initiatives. Last quarter, we discussed that we were testing a handful of initiatives that focused on increasing our ability to say yes to our customers' parts needs in both retail and commercial. We established tests last summer focused on increasing the depth of coverage available at the store, hub stores and at our distribution centers. Product additions at the hub stores and distribution centers also included tests around frequency of delivery to the stores that they service.
Over the last several months, we have significantly increased the pace of strategic assessments and challenged ourselves to review our test results very carefully. The amount of common effort going into this effort has been nothing short of extraordinary. Our entire organization owes the subset of individuals who are leading this effort tremendous gratitude.
On last quarter's call, we highlighted that one of our test initiatives was complete and in the process of being implemented. This initiative was the enhanced modeling for store SKU placements, where we would significantly add incremental inventory, while simultaneously removing unproductive inventory.
At the end of the quarter, we were complete with about 75% of this initiative. But it is important to note that much of this additional inventory began arriving at our stores very late in the quarter and some is still in the distribution centers. This has been a massive undertaking and has caused considerable work at the stores and in the distribution centers.
As you can see, our per store inventories increased significantly as a result of this initiative. We have a high degree of confidence that these new assortments will drive meaningful, profitable sales increases, as we tested this new methodology several times before implementation.
To date, the sales are generally in line with our expectations. But again, much of the inventory hasn't been positioned for sale or was positioned very late in the quarter.
We've also been testing additional inventory in our hub stores. We continue to find opportunities to add productive inventory to all of our hubs, and we expect this to continue, especially as we further penetrate the highly fragmented commercial market.
Additionally, we are testing a much deeper product offering in a select few hub stores, and these locations are leveraging that inventory across a wide network of additional hubs and satellites. This allows us to significantly broaden the depth of the product offering closer to the customer, with many stores having same-day access to the broad assortment.
In addition to testing broader SKU assortments in our hubs and in our distribution centers, we are also testing more frequent deliveries to both select hub and satellite stores. All of these efforts are designed to assess the most effective way to service our customers' needs and to reduce the amount of unproductive activity we have transferring products from store to store. It is still very early. But what we have learned, as we expected, that more inventory closer to the customer increases sales. At this stage, we have not determined the optimal solution, and we expect to continue to run these tests for an extended period of time.
We continue to execute on our strategies to improve the customer shopping experience. We expanded 5 net additional hub locations during the quarter to take our total remodeled hubs to 115 locations. These remodels entail expanding the size and capacity of these locations, ensuring they are in the right physical location and adding additional inventory into the market that benefits both retail and commercial.
We also opened 3 new hub stores, finishing with 160. Over time, we do expect to open more hub locations, but we believe our strategy on inventory deployment at the store level allows us to keep the number of openings at a moderate level.
Last quarter, I also mentioned the new version of Z-net that was being deployed. Over the last couple of years, we have reset our expectations in regard to technology investments in an effort to leverage technology to enhance the customer experience and leverage operating efficiencies. The enhanced Z-net is the first of those efforts to be implemented.
Finally, I mentioned our goal is and remains to be growing market share in 2014 while continuing to deliver solid earnings. We were successful with this objective in the last calendar quarter of 2013 according to the data available to us. However, we compete against great companies in our industry, and they, too, are aggressively modifying their business.
While we are improving, we clearly see where we can improve our selling proposition, and we are focused on those areas. Our organization understands the importance of balancing investments and returns, and we have to invest our time and capital accordingly.
With the continued aging of the car population, we are optimistic regarding trends for our industry in both DIY and DIFM. While new car sales have been very strong these past 2 years, we have seen those traded-in vehicles be resold to new owners who are repairing and enhancing their "new vehicle."
With gas prices declining a bit here recently on a year-over-year basis, we believe miles driven can increase in 2014. Historically, lower gas prices and an improving economic outlook have led to more miles being driven. We expect that trend to reemerge.
We remain bullish on our industry sales growth opportunities on both retail and the commercial front over the long term. As the vehicle population remains at an all-time high and consumers continue to look for good values while maintaining their vehicles, we see AutoZone's opportunity to sell to these customers only growing.
Now let me review our operating theme priorities for 2014. Our overarching operating theme this year is Creating Customers for Life, and the key priorities for the year are: One, Great People Providing Great Service!; two, profitably growing our commercial business; three, leveraging the Internet; four, leveraging technology to improve the customer experience while optimizing efficiencies; and finally, improving inventory availability.
On the retail front, this past quarter under the Great People Providing Great Service! theme, we continued with our intense focus on improving execution. Along with the completion of the rollout of our new Z-net software, we spent a great deal of time training AutoZoners on the system enhancements. We've tried to make the system as intuitive as possible, but along with change, we have to spend time teaching and discussing those changes.
We also learned from our store AutoZoners how to improve the way the information is presented on the screens. This mutual respect for operations and technologies will lead, in our belief, to a superior selling tool in our stores.
We also invested more payroll in our stores this past quarter. Last year, we managed expenses tightly, as our sales results were below our expectations. This year, as we expected sales to improve with all of our initiatives, we wanted to make sure we've represented our brand well so we added additional payroll.
We should highlight another strong performance in return on invested capital, as we finished Q2 at 32.3%. While slightly below last year's Q2 ROIC, excluding the acquisition of AutoAnything, we would have been slightly higher than last year.
We are very pleased with this metric, as it is one of the best, if not the best, in all of hard lines retailing. Our primary focus has been and continues to be that we ensure every incremental dollar of capital that we deploy in this business provides an acceptable return well in excess of our cost of capital. It is important to reinforce that we will always maintain our diligence regarding capital stewardship as the capital we invest is our investors' capital.
Now let me turn the call over to Bill Giles. Bill?

---

Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. To start this morning, let me take a few moments to talk more specifically about our retail, commercial and international results for the quarter.
For the quarter, total auto parts sales, which includes our domestic retail and commercial businesses, our Mexico stores and our 4 stores in Brazil, increased 6.5% over the 12 weeks. Regarding macro trends, during the quarter, nationally, unleaded gas prices started out at $3.29 a gallon and finished the quarter at $3.38 a gallon. Last year, gas prices increased $0.18 per gallon during the quarter, starting at $3.43 and ending at $3.61 a gallon. We continue to believe gas prices have a real impact on our customers' abilities to maintain their vehicles, and we continue to monitor prices closely in the future.
We also recognize that the impact of miles driven on cars over 10 years old, the current average, is much different than on newer cars in terms of wear and tear. Miles driven data reported by the Department of Transportation are available only through December. But October was up 2.3%, while November was down 0.2%, December was up 1.1%.
The other statistic we highlight is the number of 7-year-old and older vehicles on the road, which continues to trend in our industry's favor.
Another key macro headwind last year was the payroll tax reinstitution. While we do not expect to benefit this year, we simply are anniversarying a negative event from last year. It is hard to gauge what benefit this will have on our traffic, but it won't be an additional pressure point like it was last year.
For the trailing 4 quarters, total sales per auto parts store was $1,754,000. This statistic continues to set the pace for the rest of the industry.
For the quarter, total commercial sales increased 12.2%. Commercial represented 16.3% of our total company sales and grew $35 million over last year's second quarter. Last year's commercial sales mix percent was 15.6%. We believe there are ample opportunities for us to continue to improve many facets of our operations and offerings. And therefore, we are optimistic about the future of this business.
Year-to-date, we opened 170 new -- 174 new programs versus 93 programs opened last fiscal year. We now have our commercial program in 3,595 stores, supported by 160 hub stores. Approximately 1,080 of our programs are 3 years old or younger. With only 74% of our domestic stores having the commercial program and our average revenue per program below several of our competitors, we believe there is further opportunity for additional program growth, in addition to improved productivity opportunities in current programs.
The tests on inventory that we've conducted provide us with one of the pieces of information on how to close the gap with competitors that are more productive in commercial than us today on a per outlet basis. We understand where share opportunities exist, and we remain focused on closing that gap. We believe we're on the right track when it comes to our ability to climb the call list to becoming our customer's first call.
In summary, we remain committed to our long-term growth strategy. We have accelerated the growth of our commercial programs, having opened over 1,000 programs in the past 36 months. 30% of the programs are 3 years old or younger, and we believe we are well positioned to grow this business and capture market share.
Our Mexico stores continued to perform well. We opened 4 new stores during the second quarter. We currently have 367 stores in Mexico. Our returns and profit growth continue to be in line with our expectations.
Regarding Brazil, we opened no new stores in the quarter and have 4 stores open as of the end of the quarter. Our plans remain to open in total about 10 stores, then pause our development as we refine our offerings, and prove that our concept works for our customers and it's financially viable. At that point, we will talk more on our long-term growth plans.
Recapping this past quarter's performance for the company. In total, our sales were $1,999,000,000, an increase of 7.3% from last year's second quarter. Domestic same-store sales or sales for stores opened more than 1 year were up 4.3% for the quarter.
As Bill had mentioned earlier, our last 4-week sales results were below the run rate of the first 8 weeks. We attribute much of this decline to even harsher-than-expected winter weather in certain parts of the country, keeping customers at home, indoors, along with an excessive amount of precipitation, challenging customers to complete vehicle projects outdoors.
Additionally, we believe many of the failure parts that were subject to failure during extreme temperatures had already failed earlier in the season.
Moving on to gross profit. The gross margin for the quarter was 52.1% of sales, up 25 basis points versus last year's second quarter. The improvement in gross margin was attributable to higher merchandise margins, lower shrink expense, offset primarily by the inclusion of the recent acquisition of AutoAnything. 
In regards to inflation, we continue to see modest decreases in costs year-over-year. This is different than in past years. At this point, our assumption is we'll experience subdued producer pricing for the foreseeable future. And therefore, we feel costs will be predicable and manageable. We'll remain cognizant of future developments regarding inflation, and we'll make the appropriate adjustments should they arise.
Looking forward, we continue to believe there remains an opportunity for gross margin expansion within both the retail and the commercial businesses. However, we do not manage to a targeted gross margin percentage. As the growth of our commercial business has been a steady headwind on our overall gross margin rate for a few years, we have not bothered to call out the headwind quarterly as an integrated part of our business model.
Additionally, AutoAnything has been a slight drag on our gross margins, as this business model operates at a lower gross margin rate. As we anniversary our acquisition of AutoAnything during Q2, our margin comparisons will be comparable going forward. Our primary focus remains growing absolute gross profit dollars.
SG&A for the quarter was 35.2% of sales, higher by 42 basis points from last year's second quarter. The increase in operating expenses as a percentage of sales was primarily due to the timing of advertising expenditures in Q2 from Q1.
As I had mentioned a few moments ago, our investments in store payroll did leverage our domestic -- or deleveraged our domestic store operating expenses as a percentage of sales. Advertising, however, was the largest single component to the increase.
While expenses were higher than last year, they were budgeted to be higher and were in line with our expectations. We continue to believe we are well positioned to manage our cost structure in response to our sales environment.
EBIT for the quarter was $337 million, up 6.2% over last year's second quarter. Our EBIT margin was 16.9%. This represented a decrease of 17 basis points versus the previous year's second quarter. Interest expense for the quarter was $39.5 million compared with $41.3 million in Q2 a year ago. 
Debt outstanding at the end of the quarter was $4,311,000,000 or approximately $310 million more than last year's Q2 balance of $3,998,000,000. Our adjusted debt level metric finished the quarter at 2.5x EBITDAR. While in any given quarter, we may increase or decrease our leverage metric based on management's opinion regarding debt and equity market conditions, we remain committed to both our investment grade rating and our capital allocation strategy. Our share repurchases are an important element of that strategy.
For the quarter, our tax rate was approximately 35.3%, lower than last year's second quarter of 36.2%. This quarter benefited from certain discrete tax items. Net income for the quarter of $193 million was up 9.4% versus the prior year's second quarter. Our diluted share count of 34.3 million was down 7.2% from last year's second quarter. The combination of these factors drove earnings per share for the quarter to $5.63, up 17.8% over the prior year's second quarter.
Related to the cash flow statement, for the second fiscal quarter, we generated $151 million of operating cash flow. Net fixed assets were up 6.5% versus last year. Capital expenditures for the quarter totaled $77 million and reflected the additional expenditures required to open 32 new stores this quarter, capital expenditures on existing stores, hub store remodels, work on development of new stores for upcoming quarters and information technology investments.
Additionally, we purchased the rights to certain customer relationships in connection with our ALLDATA business. These investments were approximately $11 million this year, with an additional $20 million to be paid over the next 2 years. For all of fiscal 2013, our CapEx was approximately $415 million.
With the new stores opened, we finished this quarter with 4,871 stores in 49 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico; 367 stores in Mexico; and 4 in Brazil, for a total store count of 5,242. Depreciation totaled $58.4 million for the quarter versus last year's second quarter expense of $52.3 million.
With our excess cash flow, we purchased -- repurchased $200 million of AutoZone stock in the second quarter. At quarter end, we had $727 million remaining under our share buyback authorization. Our leverage metric was 2.5x this past quarter. Again, I want to stress, we manage through appropriate credit ratings and not any one metric. The metric we report is meant as a guide only, as each rating firm has its own criteria. We continue to view our share repurchase program as an attractive capital deployment strategy.
Accounts payable as a percent of gross inventory finished the quarter at 113%.
Next I'd like to update you on our inventory levels in total and on a per store basis. We reported an inventory balance of $3.1 billion, up 12% versus the Q2 ending balance last year. Increased inventory reflects new store growth, along with additional investments and coverage for select categories. Inventory per store was up 8.3% at $589,000 per store, reflecting our continued investments in hard parts coverage.
Finally, as Bill previously mentioned, our continued disciplined capital management approach resulted in return on invested capital for the trailing 4 quarters of 32.3%. We have and will continue to make investments that we believe will generate returns that significantly exceed our cost of capital.
Now I'll turn it back to Bill Rhodes.

---

Thanks, Bill. We are pleased to report our 30th consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings per share growth. Our company continues to be successful due to our long-term focus. That focus on exceptional customer service is part of the AutoZone DNA.
We focus on executing at a very high level consistently, which we believe can be a competitive advantage. To execute at a high level, we have to consistently adhere to living the pledge. We cannot and will not take our eye off of execution. Success will be achieved with a strong attention to detail.
But we also have to evolve and change to adapt to our ever-evolving industry. The initiatives we are working around inventory assortment, hub stores, commercial growth, Mexico, ALLDATA, E-Commerce and Brazil are all very exciting to us. We feel these efforts will lead to increasing sales for 2014 and beyond.
While our industry sales, according to the NPD data made available to us, accelerated this past quarter, we continued to experience share gains on both the retail and commercial fronts. While this is exciting, we cannot be complacent. We are just starting to implement our major initiatives. And the best, we believe, is ahead of us.
Our long-term model is to grow new store square footage at a low single-digit growth rate, and we expect to continue growing our commercial business at an accelerated rate. As we continue to execute on our financial model, we look to routinely grow EBIT dollars in the mid-single-digit range or better in times of strength. And we leverage our very strong and predictable cash flow to repurchase shares, enhancing our earnings per share growth into double digits.
We feel the track we are on will allow us to continue winning for the long run. We believe our steady, consistent strategy is right. It is the attention to details and consistent execution that will matter over time. Our belief is solid, consistent strategy combined with superior execution is a formula for success. We're investing in the key initiatives that will drive our long-term performance.
In the end, delivering strong EPS growth and ROIC each and every quarter is how we measure ourselves. We remain committed to delivering on our strategic and financial objectives.
Now we'd like to open up the call for questions.
