I don't think we'll lose all the 0.9% in retail because some of it has come as a result of more efficient clearance processes in the Directory. The other 0.3% was about last year's stock that we had anticipated we wouldn't sell, but we actually managed to sell online.
Freight, fabric and stock loss 0.2 here. That compares to 0.5 in retail. The difference was this time last year, we had a provision release on this line of 0.3. So actually, underlying 0.5 both in retail and Directory improvement in margin as a result of freight, fabric and stock loss improvements.
Catalog production, 0.2% improvement here. Two things going on. First of all, a positive movement of 0.6%, and this is because cash customers don't require catalogs, don't tend to request catalogs, and that means we printed fewer catalogs. That gave us a 0.6% improvement. We -- but at the same time, we introduced more brochures, in particular, new in brochures that go mid season, and those ate up 0.4% of that gain. 
Warehouse and distribution. The adverse movement of 0.5% mainly relating to, in fact, more than all of it, relates to the costs of international dispatchers. That's right, it's more expensive to deliver overseas, so this line gets particularly hit by international. The cost of that actually would have been 0.7%. We offset some of that with cost savings on U.K. distribution.
Service charge and bad debt, 0.5% adverse movement as a result of credit sales growing slower than total sales, and a 0.1% improvement as a result of slightly lower bad debt. 
Central overheads, 0.1%.
Moving off the accounts onto the more general part of the presentation. This is slightly more interesting, this bit. So you can even stop your e-mailing, and if you look up and enjoy this part, because this is more interesting, I promise you. 
So 5 things that we're going to focus on. These things won't come as a surprise because 4 of them were here last year and the year before. Develop the NEXT brand, that really means improving our product; grow retail space; develop our business online; improve service, which is an additional objective for the business, which I'm going to talk about in a little bit more detail later on; and control costs. 
In terms of our financial objective, traditionally, we've said it's to deliver long-term sustainable growth in earnings per share. Having switched from buybacks to special dividends, that objective isn't quite right. And our new objective fulfills all the functions of the previous objective, but it is more appropriate to what we're doing. So long-term, sustainable growth in total shareholder returns. This is different from TSR, as you know, which is share price positive within growth. What we're looking at here is growth in earnings per share plus dividend yield. And that is done in the belief that long-term, growth in earnings per share does eventually filter through into share price. 
I'm going to focus on 4 of those things in the presentation. Starting with retail space. That's now our quite old shop in Ipswich. We opened 11 new stores. We moved 8, we extended 13, closed 10. So net increase in stores of just 1:541. Total increase in space of 280,000. 
What you will have noticed is that an area that we haven't been particularly good at forecasting is our space pipeline. So -- and what's happened is we've consistently overestimated the amount of space that we will open. So for the year that we're currently in, a year ago, we were talking about 450,000 square feet. We're now talking about 360,000 square feet. That's not because we don't plan to open space, it's because it's taking much, much longer to open the much bigger stores than we had anticipated. Part of that is about simple build time, but by far, the most important factor in that is the planning and the deal side of it. And mainly, it's about planning. And the planners' motto seems to be that they won't say no, they'll just say yes very, very slowly. 
In terms of the space that we have opened, in the year just gone, 40% of it was in Home departments. That's not all in standalone or big Home shops. Part of that is in fashion stores in town. So we're now at a situation where 25% of our space across the group is given over to Home. And in retail, that equates to around 16% of the sales. And that compares to around 18% of our sales across the group on Home across the brand. 
In terms of the performance of the new space, pretty much as we expected, around 4% up both in terms of fashion and large format Homes. Return on capital comfortably below our 24-month payback. Profitability, pretty much 22%, and that compares to our rest of store profit of around 23%. That comparison of the 22% to the 23% is actually better than it looks because a lot of the -- some of the 23% will be in stores where their assets have already been written down and depreciation is very low. 
In terms of the pipeline moving forward, this is our new shop that we're building bottom up in Hedge End, that's what we hope it will look like when it opens in August. Pipeline remains at GBP 1.1 million. But again, as I mentioned earlier, it has slipped back a little bit. 360,000, we intend -- we anticipate will open in the current year; 400,000 next year; 350,000 year after. In terms of what that space is made up of, 40% of it comes from the new large-format, side-by-side stores with a separate Home entrance and Home on 2 floors: the downstairs furnishing downstairs, the upstairs furnishing upstairs. We're opening 3 of those stores in the current year, and they will account for around 30% of the current year's openings. Just little pictures of them, York, Hedge End and Maidstone. Two of those we have designed the building, as well as the internals of the shop. And our aim here is to slowly but surely transform the nature of what out-of-town shopping means to the NEXT customer. 
I think -- I do think this is really important going forward, and not just for NEXT, but for the whole of retail. I think it's going to be important that we create -- that where we open out-of-town, we don't throw up big, ugly sheds because people won't be enthusiastic about it. But when you throw out something that is actually nice to look and nice to be in, people are much less antipathetic to it, particularly if it's got a nice cafe in it, which this one has on the mezzanine on the right-hand side. You can sit there and look at the roundabout and flyover, get a beautiful view of it. 
Just to remind you how our shop fit has changed over the last 7 years -- 8 years, this is what our new shop would have looked like in 2006. And the cost of that was GBP 127 a square foot. If you adjust that for inflation, in today's money, that would be GBP 149 a square foot. This is our latest womenswear shop fit in Romford. This is the shoe department. You can see it's got concrete walls, parquet flooring, a light well that we bought in through the stockroom to get some natural light into the back of the shop. And real marble tops on the shoe department -- on the shoe fixtures. 
The interesting thing about this shop is that when you look at the cost of it, actually, in real terms, it's slightly cheaper than the shops we were building in 2006. And there are all sorts of reason for that, part -- building costs have come down, globalization on building materials, this meant that there are things that we can get cheaper. But the point we would make about this is that actually, the real investment hasn't been in the materials that we've put into the shop. It has been in the design work that's gone into finding the mosaic, and then buying it in enough bulk and in pieces that you can assemble it so that it is affordable.
And within the business, we've used this. And I'm going to show you a couple -- I'm going to talk a bit about product now, which is always dangerous for a Chief Executive because you can sound a bit insincere and scripted when you [indiscernible] retail company talks about products. What I'm going to show you are some of the slides we presented to our staff to give you a flavor of what we're trying to achieve on product, which is really what comes down to the same thing, comes down to getting fantastic fabrics, great detailing on design. We design pretty much all of our products in-house, sourcing the trim ourselves and hand -- all the prints we produce, pretty much all of them are in-house prints as well. And it's a question of designing those beautifully, getting them right, and then buying them in enough volume to get them at affordable prices. And that is kind of the essence of what we're trying to achieve in our product departments. 
But one thing we'll be very clear about, and I share it with you just in case you think we get all NEXT products, are they going to have bells and whistles on it, great design doesn't mean overdesign. So a great design can be simple. And great design doesn't mean just focusing on the top end of your price architecture. The basics must be well-designed, whether that be the slab fabric that we're using or the shape of the neckline on a T-shirt. Everything should be designed correctly. And that is the aim of what we're trying to achieve in our product departments at the moment. 
What we've also done is changed our buying cycle to make sure that our stock is more appropriate to the time of year and that our customers are buying it.
Traditional retail buying cycles have worked on our spring, summer and autumn, winter collections. You'll see in the shops, the spring-summer range has just arrived. And there is a problem with that, in that when you sit down and do a spring-summer design work presentation, inevitably, you're thinking of summer rather than spring. And what's -- this just shows the performance of our womenswear clothing division in Phase 1 and 2 of spring-summer compared to 3, 4 and 5 of spring-summer, and autumn-winter 1 and 2 compared to 3 and 4 autumn-winter. 
Now there were other things that affected this performance. So it's not as dramatic as it appears on the screen in terms of the seasonal effect. What you can see is that underlying that, there is definitely an effect where we are designing our ranges in a way that isn't appropriate for spring or autumn. And there, at the bottom there, you can see a generic designer of no particular sex there. It's just a sort of a designer. When they're thinking of spring-summer, they're thinking of beaches. When they're thinking autumn-winter, they're thinking of Winter Wonderland. 
Going forward, we're going to be more paired with the temperature. Because if you look at the last 10 years, what's interesting is that autumn is warmer than summer and spring is colder than winter. So going forward, we are buying 4 in 4 seasons, 4 design presentations for spring, summer, autumn, winter. Partly that means our stock will be more appropriate, although I should point out that this is not an absolute shift. 
People still -- if something's really fashionable and they really like it, they will buy summer dresses in early spring. So there will be a summer element to our spring ranges. But there's going to be more to buy that is appropriate to the time of year. What the customers will also see, more importantly, is a much bigger change going from spring into summer and from autumn into winter. And I think in the very long term, what you'll see is that our mid season sales accordingly increase in size, and our end of season sales reduce in size. It's not an effect that's going to take place immediately. We think over the next 10 years, we'll slowly see mid season sale increase in expense of the end of season sale.
Service is an area that we haven't focused on over the last 5 -- because I haven't talked to you about it over the last 5 years. It's not that we think we've -- it's not that we've been sleeping. It's that it hasn't been top of our list. And when you look -- if you look at where we sit -- this is an independent ranking of various retailers. I haven't named them to save any embarrassment for anybody. I haven't named the other retailers, but this is the main retailers you can think of on the high street. This is the percentage that rated outstanding, very good and good. And you can see we're about in the middle of the pack and not a long way behind #3, 4 and 5. 
However, if you look at the customers who rate NEXT outstanding and very good, the difference drops dramatically. And it's that -- it's moving from good to very good and outstanding that we are -- we aim to achieve over the next few years, both in our retail stores and as importantly, and in some ways more importantly, in terms of how we handle people in our call center.
I mean, just -- I'm going to share with you a few of the things that we -- a few of the operational things that we've done to improve service. We changed our recruitment process. And the watch word here is to recruit for attitude, not skill. So in the past, we've fallen into the trap of, say, have you got retail experience? When did you last work in a shop? And actually, it only takes half an hour to an hour to train someone on retail. It's not -- it's a job where it's far more important to us that they come and that they're nice people, that they're team players, that they work hard, that they're enthusiastic, that they turn up on time, that they get on with their colleagues, and that they genuinely want to do -- give a good service to their customers. 
We've been -- we sort of torn up our appraisal system, which is -- the appraisal systems that doubtless, you will be used to in the bank, and such great big tomes of paper that have no meaning whatsoever, but produce annual grind for people to sit through. We've changed that and done a TripAdvisor, very quick, 15-minute, half-an-hour appraisal, which we do 4 times a year, very simple rating system, 4 stars for excellent, 1 star for needs to improve or you're in trouble.
We've then taken that through into the way that we allocate extra hours. So in retail business, our peaks, we always have extra hours. When people go on holidays, we have extra hours. And in the past, that process of giving out extra hours has been done by the store manager asking people to go on extra hours. We've -- what we've done is we've developed a system whereby the staff can go on to sign in online or on their mobiles, 70% of them are doing this on their mobiles, and see what shifts are available on the different days of the week. They can then see what shifts -- what time of day their shifts are and how much they will earn. 
Because we know it's them that's logged in, we know what their pay rate is, over 21, under 21, merit sales or normal sales consultant. So we can give them the actual amount of money that they will earn. They just click on it, accept it and that's it, they're in to work. What they can also do is give up time on there. So they can swap their shifts and offer them up. So if people want, for any reason, need time off, they can offer them on the marketplace. It's not guaranteed to go, but at the moment, we are getting around 80% of the shifts that we put on the marketplace are being taken up. 
And the nice thing about this is that it works with our appraisal system. And what we do is we give the 4-star rated people an extra day to look at those shifts. So they get a whole day to take those shifts before anyone else gets a look at them, then the 3 stars, then the 2 stars, and the 1 stars don't get a look at them.
In terms of online, I'm not going -- we've done a lot with next-day delivery to store, which you know about, so I'm not going to talk about that. I'm going to talk about international. International had a really good year. GBP 33 million 2 years ago, GBP 54 million last year. In the year just gone, GBP 101 million. Two things to point out about this. It was much -- this was much greater growth than we were expecting at the beginning of the year. We said GBP 70 million to GBP 75 million. The other thing to note is the slight decline in margin. This was something that we managed. We did 2 things. First, we saved a lot of money on distribution and operations and overseas in certain territories. And we passed a little bit more than that back to our customers overseas by way of permanent price reduction. So this wasn't promotion. This is just saying everything now on this website is now 10% cheaper.
And it -- it was those price reductions more than anything else that has -- that drove the exceptional level of growth. We managed to achieve price reductions in 28 territories, which, between them, account for around 50% of our overseas territories. We also converted 5 territories that were trading in dollars or euros to their domestic currency and introduced one new translation, which was Chinese -- traditional Chinese for Taiwan. 
Looking forward to the year ahead, we're expecting around GBP 150 million growth. The reason that the growth is less aggressive than the year just gone is because we got far fewer price reductions. And when those price reductions annualize, it will be extraordinary if we didn't see a falloff in the growth rate. 
Looking to the -- we're not [indiscernible] looking to the year ahead, we've got 11 new territories we want to open. We're converting 11 countries to their domestic currency. That does have a positive impact in sales in our experience, but nothing like the effect of lowering prices. We've got 6 new languages that we're introducing on various sites across the globe and only 5 price reductions that account for just under 2% of the sales of our online business. 
Incidentally, one of the countries here that we're opening is China. This is the second time in 2 years that I've announced the opening of our Chinese website. And -- but this -- it's actually working at the moment. We've got it in test mode, so we are actually delivering stock to China. And you can't get to it yet, but that will come public in the next few days. Please don't expect too much from China. I think there's an enormous temptation to think that China is -- because there are 2 billion people, there'll be enormous number of sales. That is not our expectation. The vast majority of our customers, we don't think this -- our product will be appropriate for in China. So we're not too excited about that.
In terms of the outlook, a brief word about the economy. We are more positive about the economy than we've been for the last 6 years. Employment is looking good. Housing transactions are increasing, in line with growth in mortgage approvals. And this is definitely having an impact on our Home business, which has been our fastest-growing significant area in the last year. And that's -- and the space that we bought over the last 6 years -- we've pretty much doubled our Home space over the last 6 years. That is now beginning to really pay dividends.
The one thing about this that's interesting is although transaction levels are growing by 20% on last year, they're still 20% below the sort of run rate that the U.K. were seeing in the '90s. So we're not necessarily expecting the turnover of housing to drop in the next year. So we think that this is a permanent return to normality rather than an aberration. But we could be wrong about that.
In terms of credit flow, totals of GBP 7 billion, this is the Bank of England, flows of credit. This doesn't include write-offs or backers. This is real cash in and out of the economy. Significant change in 2013 compared to the previous 3 years. In total, GBP 7 billion of debt flowed into the economy. That's around 1% of total earnings in the U.K., total earned income excluding pensions. So it kind of makes up for the gap between -- and one way of looking at that is it kind of makes up for the fall in real earnings over the last year, which is one of the reasons I think last year was slightly better than we were expecting. 
But obviously, that cannot continue forever. You can't have credit growing faster than earnings forever. And on the earnings front, for the first time, we've seen what might be some positive news on this. And the numbers out yesterday just showed that inflation and earnings almost touching -- still negative, almost touching. So I think we're at a turning point. It's very difficult to know which way it's going to go. There might be a blip, there might not be. But if it's not a blip and we see return to growth in real earnings, then I think that is good news for the retail economy. 
So on balance, we think that things are looking slightly rosier in the economy. But there are risks. If we don't see growth in earnings, there is a question as to the sustainability of credit growth. We've all been there before. There's a real risk that the housing bubble in the southeast of the country will suck a lot of money out of the economy and encourage people to take on too much debt, and that will be not necessarily damaging in the short term, but in the medium to long term. When the interest rates go up, it will be very damaging. So although we're positive, we recognize that any real strong positive movement in the economy will result in an interest rate rise. And again, that will be a significant impact. 
There's also GBP 1.2 trillion, GBP 1.3 trillion worth of mortgage debt. 1% on that is 2% of earnings in very simple terms. It doesn't all come through straight away, some people are on fixed mortgages, some people are below the minimum. But I don't think that it will be right to prepare for a return to the boom days because as soon as it looks like there will be a boom, the interest rate breaks will be applied and you shouldn't underestimate both the science of those interest rate breaks and the shock that people will get when they go up. Because although -- sort of it's a bit like death. Everyone knows that it will happen, but no one quite believes it. So it's a nice little analogy there for you, so to get the points across. 
But I think that it will come as a significant shock to the U.K. consumer when interest rates go up. So we need to be cautious in our outlook, but we are slightly more optimistic. And for that reason, we have set our sales range between 4% and 8% maximum. That's the -- as the Chairman very gladly said vested, the highest sales range we've given since he was Chairman. We haven't been giving sales ranges for that long, for as long as he's been Chairman, I should just point out. But it is nonetheless quite an aggressive number for us. It compares to 5.5% last year. And you might think, oh, well, that's sort of typical NEXT, overly conservative. 
I would just remind you that if you look across the year, that 5.5% was hugely driven by the last quarter. And not only do we not expect the last quarter to be as strong in the year ahead. Because it was so strong, it will give us very tough comparatives. And our own budgets for the fourth quarter are extremely conservative because we know that some of the business that we won then, we are likely to lose. So if you look at the first 3 quarters, the run rate was 3%. And in that context, the 4% to 8% looks reasonable, if not aggressive.
In terms of what that means for profit, 4% to 8% profit range means we're still anticipating lower negative like-for-likes, GBP 12 million cost of negative like-for-likes, GBP 44 million of cost increases. The vast majority of that relates to wage inflation and occupancy cost increases. That will get you to over GBP 30 million of that cost. Still significant cost savings coming through in the business in Directory operations, still some savings to come through in retail operations and some balancing savings also in our occupancy costs where we've taken write-offs last year that we don't expect to recur in the year ahead, which all of you will spot on real savings and not cash, obviously. So slightly deceptive, this one. New space, we think, will give us GBP 15 million and Directory growth will give us GBP 49 million. So cost savings in Directory in equal measure, providing the lion's share of the growth for next year, midpoint of GBP 750 million. 
That was -- so that gives a profit range of 5% to 11%. A dividend yield of 2%, and that's based on the share price around GBP 65. Special dividend yield of around 3%, assuming that special dividends continue. If they don't, that 3% will just convert into earnings enhancement by way of buybacks. So underlying total shareholder returns of EPS growth plus dividend yield, we're looking at somewhere between 10% and 16% in the year ahead, which we think is a reasonable ambition. 
Just in terms of where that sits, you'll remember, I showed you this graph 5 years ago of our ambitions for earnings enhancement, profit growth and dividend yield. We achieved 25% in the year just gone. That figure is a bit of a cheat because 5% of it came from tax. So underlying growth total return is around 20%. In the year ahead, we're looking at 10% to 16%. So still comfortably within our target range of 9% to 15% that we set the business 6 years ago.

: Simon Wolfson (Executives)
Hi. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. As Chairman said, we had a good year. Actually, he used the word great, but that was a bit of a wild exuberance, I'll say good. 4 -- 5.5% increase in revenue, 11.2% increase in operating profit. The difference between sales and operating profit is not as great as it appears. Full price sales were up 6.7%, and that's all about less markdown going into the end of season sale. 
Interest was level with last year. Looking to the year ahead, we expect interest costs to rise around GBP 30 million, and that's as a result of us having more gross debt. We think that the net debt will remain about the same, but having issued a bond, we got more gross debt. And that increase of GBP 2 million is the difference between having money on deposit and what we're paid by way of interest for the cost of the bond versus what we paid on deposit. 
Taxation, we settled a big case with HMRC. That produced a significant provision release. So taxation rate dropped to 20.4%. Obviously, that's a noncash item. And in the year ahead, we expect that to rise to around 21%, which we remain -- which we expect to be the tax rate for the next year and the year after that. 
In terms of profit after tax, 16.9%. Buybacks boosted the earnings further to 23% growth earnings per share. And as we said before, we intend to grow dividends in line -- ordinary dividends in line with earnings per share, so dividends per share up 23% as well. 
And moving on to the cash flow, CapEx up around GBP 100 million -- I'm sorry, GBP 20 million last year to GBP 105 million. Pretty much all of that change is about increased opening of new stores. We spent a little bit more on refurbishment, but of that GBP 13 million refurbishment costs, GBP 3 million of it was the rebuilding of Warrington that was burned down by our neighbors and rebuilt at our insurers' expense. So really, underlying is GBP 10 million. And GBP 22 million on various pieces of investment around the business. 
In terms of looking at next year, around the same amount on space. Actually, net, we think we'll have a little bit more space next year, I'm going to come onto that. Refurbishment's dropping dramatically. This is really because having opened so much new space over the last 5 or 6 years, there isn't an awful lot of refurbishment to do. So we think around GBP 5 million refurbishment costs in the year ahead. 
Warehouse and other, a significant increase here. And I'm just going to spend a little bit of time talking about where we're investing that money in the central heads of the business or central CapEx. Warehouse is GBP 18 million of it, of which GBP 11 million relates to a new Home warehouse and GBP 8 million of that is the land upon which we intend to build the new warehouse. The GBP 5 million of distribution cost is partly the cost of making our next-day to store delivery service universal. At the moment, there's only around 3/4 of the shops get that service, and some of it is infrastructure acquired for our overseas business. 
In terms of systems, a significant investment in systems over the next year, we're rewriting our in-store system and replacing all the hardware. This is mainly because this -- the tills we're using are now obsolete. We can't replace them. And whilst there will be some efficiency gains through rewriting the software, this is really a standstill project rather than a full project. We're rebuilding our IT building to get better facilities for our systems team, and we are renewing a lot of our infrastructure, IT infrastructure to make our systems work better. GBP 50 million of the swing is about increased debt to book in the Directory, GBP 70 million swing is about stock. I'm going to talk about stock, basically. We look at the half rather than the full year when looking at the debtor book because it's the last half of the year that drives the debt balance at the end of the year, because our consumers pay down their debt roughly over 6 months. We spent GBP 26 million maintaining our dividend. So that is really an operational cost. So the true operator -- the real free cash flow is GBP 300 million. Special dividends, we've paid GBP 75 million in special dividend. We've announced the payment of another special dividend beginning of May. And we will either spend another GBP 150 million on further special dividends or buybacks in the year ahead, dependent on where the share price is. 
In terms of the share price, just to remind you, the measure we use to decide whether to do buybacks or special dividends is equivalent rate of return. This is the return required from an alternative investment if that investment were to produce the same earnings enhancement as the proposed buyback. So it's basically saying, if we were to invest this money in the business, what you would have to do to give in order -- how much we'll have to grow profits by to get an 8% increase in profits.
We spent a long time talking to many shareholders about this. The 8% figure, you can argue about some people. On the whole, more people said it's too high than too low, but by no means universal. The 8%, most people agreed with. At GBP 695 million of profit before tax, at 8%, that gives a share price of around GBP 58, almost exactly GBP 58. 
What many people have said to us, and we agree with this, is that we -- in the same way that you look at dividend yield going forward, we should be looking at earnings per -- equivalent rate of return going forward. So we're going to use the midpoint of our guidance, of our publicly issued guidance, at any point in time to determine the maximum share price that we would pay. That takes the maximum share price to around GBP 62.45, still quite a long way from where the share price is today. And it goes back to the old adage that if you're going to move the goal post, make sure the ball has gone the other end of the field first.
That was a little joke there just to liven up the morning, but clearly, it hasn't had that effect. But we'll try later for some more wit and humor.
Moving on to the retail accounts. Against our expectations, retail total moved forward and profits moved forward. Again, the sales hit somewhat distorted. The 1.7% is total sales. Full price sales were up 3%, markdown sales down 11%. Sales from new space, we've got a 3.1% growth from new space of an average net space increase, in percentage terms, around 4.2%. That has given us a 72% return on the space that we've opened. That's an unusual figure. We would normally budget between 60% and 65%. That has been the consistent figure for the last 8 or 9 years.
The reason that this one has been higher than usual is all about 2 stores that we opened with that were big space and high-density, one of which was Camberley, the other one is -- was in Sprucefield, Lisburn.
Profit analysis. Operating profit up 5%, significantly ahead of sales. All and more of that profit increase was driven by reduced markdown. So I think there is a risk and indeed, at the last meeting that we had, there was some confusion of what that 0.8% improvement means. It doesn't mean that we reduced our markdowns by 0.8% and reduced discounting by that amount or improved clearance rates by that amount. Of that 0.8%, 0.6% of it is all about the mix between full price and markdown profit. So the 0.6% comes from growth in full price sales, not reduction in markdown.
0.2% of it does come from improved clearance rates, and that's because whilst our sales were down 11%, our stock was down 15%. So we cleared through better. And that gave us a 0.2% improvement. We expect that 0.2% improvement to reverse out in the year ahead because we went in with exceptionally low stock levels.
Freight, fabric and stock loss, all sort of pretty much in equal measure, contributed another 0.5% towards achieved gross margin. Store payroll, a very slight positive here, 2 things going on. Cost of living would've cost around minus 0.2% of margin, but the efficiency measures we put in improved productive clawed slightly more than that back to get a net figure of 0.1 up. 
Store occupancy, adverse movement to 0.7%. Of this 0.7%, 0.3% of it relates to write-offs that won't recur in the current year. 0.4 of it is about rent and rates, and those 2 pretty much in equal measure. The rental figure, most of that 0.2% is driven by like-for-like declines in certain stores. And the actual rent reviews we're seeing coming through, the vast majority of those are at mill at the moment. And on non-renewal, we're seeing the majority of leases, if we renew a lease, we're seeing the rent coming down.
And other overheads, really central overheads and staff incentives. 
Moving on to Directory. Directory had a cracking year. Full price sale is up 14%, markdown flat. In terms of the contribution to that growth, 8.5% of the 12.4 came from U.K. business, which grew around 9%. International added another 3.9% to the growth to get to the 12.4%. 
In terms of customer base, we now have a customer base of 3.7 million. And customers, we define active customers as those who have bought something within the last 4 or 5 months, 20 weeks actually, the last 20 weeks, or have paid off part of their balance in the last 20 weeks. 
In terms of where that growth came from, in the U.K, we recruited more cash customers than credit customers, although the contribution to sale -- to sales growth wasn't as great. Because on the whole, the credit customers tend to spend more. And we increased our number of overseas customers by around 120,000.
In terms of profit, big move forward in the operating profit of Directory, much bigger than sales. Again, there's a markdown effect here, but a much more significant markdown effect than we saw in retail. Of that 1.8% improvement in markdown, 0.7 of it is about mix. That has just -- come from growth in full price sales. 1.1% of it has come from improved clearance rates. And of that 1.1%, 0.8% of it came from improved clearance rates in the end of season sales. And that's because our stock was down 9%, but our sales were flat. I don't think we will lose all of that 0.9%, whereas the 0.2 in retail, I think we will lose. I don't think we'll lose all the 0.9% in retail because some of it has come as a result of more efficient clearance processes in the Directory. The other 0.3% was about last year's stock that we had anticipated we wouldn't sell, but we actually managed to sell online.
Freight, fabric and stock loss 0.2 here. That compares to 0.5 in retail. The difference was this time last year, we had a provision release on this line of 0.3. So actually, underlying 0.5 both in retail and Directory improvement in margin as a result of freight, fabric and stock loss improvements.
Catalog production, 0.2% improvement here. Two things going on. First of all, a positive movement of 0.6%, and this is because cash customers don't require catalogs, don't tend to request catalogs, and that means we printed fewer catalogs. That gave us a 0.6% improvement. We -- but at the same time, we introduced more brochures, in particular, new in brochures that go mid season, and those ate up 0.4% of that gain. 
Warehouse and distribution. The adverse movement of 0.5% mainly relating to, in fact, more than all of it, relates to the costs of international dispatchers. That's right, it's more expensive to deliver overseas, so this line gets particularly hit by international. The cost of that actually would have been 0.7%. We offset some of that with cost savings on U.K. distribution.
Service charge and bad debt, 0.5% adverse movement as a result of credit sales growing slower than total sales, and a 0.1% improvement as a result of slightly lower bad debt. 
Central overheads, 0.1%.
Moving off the accounts onto the more general part of the presentation. This is slightly more interesting, this bit. So you can even stop your e-mailing, and if you look up and enjoy this part, because this is more interesting, I promise you. 
So 5 things that we're going to focus on. These things won't come as a surprise because 4 of them were here last year and the year before. Develop the NEXT brand, that really means improving our product; grow retail space; develop our business online; improve service, which is an additional objective for the business, which I'm going to talk about in a little bit more detail later on; and control costs. 
In terms of our financial objective, traditionally, we've said it's to deliver long-term sustainable growth in earnings per share. Having switched from buybacks to special dividends, that objective isn't quite right. And our new objective fulfills all the functions of the previous objective, but it is more appropriate to what we're doing. So long-term, sustainable growth in total shareholder returns. This is different from TSR, as you know, which is share price positive within growth. What we're looking at here is growth in earnings per share plus dividend yield. And that is done in the belief that long-term, growth in earnings per share does eventually filter through into share price. 
I'm going to focus on 4 of those things in the presentation. Starting with retail space. That's now our quite old shop in Ipswich. We opened 11 new stores. We moved 8, we extended 13, closed 10. So net increase in stores of just 1:541. Total increase in space of 280,000. 
What you will have noticed is that an area that we haven't been particularly good at forecasting is our space pipeline. So -- and what's happened is we've consistently overestimated the amount of space that we will open. So for the year that we're currently in, a year ago, we were talking about 450,000 square feet. We're now talking about 360,000 square feet. That's not because we don't plan to open space, it's because it's taking much, much longer to open the much bigger stores than we had anticipated. Part of that is about simple build time, but by far, the most important factor in that is the planning and the deal side of it. And mainly, it's about planning. And the planners' motto seems to be that they won't say no, they'll just say yes very, very slowly. 
In terms of the space that we have opened, in the year just gone, 40% of it was in Home departments. That's not all in standalone or big Home shops. Part of that is in fashion stores in town. So we're now at a situation where 25% of our space across the group is given over to Home. And in retail, that equates to around 16% of the sales. And that compares to around 18% of our sales across the group on Home across the brand. 
In terms of the performance of the new space, pretty much as we expected, around 4% up both in terms of fashion and large format Homes. Return on capital comfortably below our 24-month payback. Profitability, pretty much 22%, and that compares to our rest of store profit of around 23%. That comparison of the 22% to the 23% is actually better than it looks because a lot of the -- some of the 23% will be in stores where their assets have already been written down and depreciation is very low. 
In terms of the pipeline moving forward, this is our new shop that we're building bottom up in Hedge End, that's what we hope it will look like when it opens in August. Pipeline remains at GBP 1.1 million. But again, as I mentioned earlier, it has slipped back a little bit. 360,000, we intend -- we anticipate will open in the current year; 400,000 next year; 350,000 year after. In terms of what that space is made up of, 40% of it comes from the new large-format, side-by-side stores with a separate Home entrance and Home on 2 floors: the downstairs furnishing downstairs, the upstairs furnishing upstairs. We're opening 3 of those stores in the current year, and they will account for around 30% of the current year's openings. Just little pictures of them, York, Hedge End and Maidstone. Two of those we have designed the building, as well as the internals of the shop. And our aim here is to slowly but surely transform the nature of what out-of-town shopping means to the NEXT customer. 
I think -- I do think this is really important going forward, and not just for NEXT, but for the whole of retail. I think it's going to be important that we create -- that where we open out-of-town, we don't throw up big, ugly sheds because people won't be enthusiastic about it. But when you throw out something that is actually nice to look and nice to be in, people are much less antipathetic to it, particularly if it's got a nice cafe in it, which this one has on the mezzanine on the right-hand side. You can sit there and look at the roundabout and flyover, get a beautiful view of it. 
Just to remind you how our shop fit has changed over the last 7 years -- 8 years, this is what our new shop would have looked like in 2006. And the cost of that was GBP 127 a square foot. If you adjust that for inflation, in today's money, that would be GBP 149 a square foot. This is our latest womenswear shop fit in Romford. This is the shoe department. You can see it's got concrete walls, parquet flooring, a light well that we bought in through the stockroom to get some natural light into the back of the shop. And real marble tops on the shoe department -- on the shoe fixtures. 
The interesting thing about this shop is that when you look at the cost of it, actually, in real terms, it's slightly cheaper than the shops we were building in 2006. And there are all sorts of reason for that, part -- building costs have come down, globalization on building materials, this meant that there are things that we can get cheaper. But the point we would make about this is that actually, the real investment hasn't been in the materials that we've put into the shop. It has been in the design work that's gone into finding the mosaic, and then buying it in enough bulk and in pieces that you can assemble it so that it is affordable.
And within the business, we've used this. And I'm going to show you a couple -- I'm going to talk a bit about product now, which is always dangerous for a Chief Executive because you can sound a bit insincere and scripted when you [indiscernible] retail company talks about products. What I'm going to show you are some of the slides we presented to our staff to give you a flavor of what we're trying to achieve on product, which is really what comes down to the same thing, comes down to getting fantastic fabrics, great detailing on design. We design pretty much all of our products in-house, sourcing the trim ourselves and hand -- all the prints we produce, pretty much all of them are in-house prints as well. And it's a question of designing those beautifully, getting them right, and then buying them in enough volume to get them at affordable prices. And that is kind of the essence of what we're trying to achieve in our product departments. 
But one thing we'll be very clear about, and I share it with you just in case you think we get all NEXT products, are they going to have bells and whistles on it, great design doesn't mean overdesign. So a great design can be simple. And great design doesn't mean just focusing on the top end of your price architecture. The basics must be well-designed, whether that be the slab fabric that we're using or the shape of the neckline on a T-shirt. Everything should be designed correctly. And that is the aim of what we're trying to achieve in our product departments at the moment. 
What we've also done is changed our buying cycle to make sure that our stock is more appropriate to the time of year and that our customers are buying it.
Traditional retail buying cycles have worked on our spring, summer and autumn, winter collections. You'll see in the shops, the spring-summer range has just arrived. And there is a problem with that, in that when you sit down and do a spring-summer design work presentation, inevitably, you're thinking of summer rather than spring. And what's -- this just shows the performance of our womenswear clothing division in Phase 1 and 2 of spring-summer compared to 3, 4 and 5 of spring-summer, and autumn-winter 1 and 2 compared to 3 and 4 autumn-winter. 
Now there were other things that affected this performance. So it's not as dramatic as it appears on the screen in terms of the seasonal effect. What you can see is that underlying that, there is definitely an effect where we are designing our ranges in a way that isn't appropriate for spring or autumn. And there, at the bottom there, you can see a generic designer of no particular sex there. It's just a sort of a designer. When they're thinking of spring-summer, they're thinking of beaches. When they're thinking autumn-winter, they're thinking of Winter Wonderland. 
Going forward, we're going to be more paired with the temperature. Because if you look at the last 10 years, what's interesting is that autumn is warmer than summer and spring is colder than winter. So going forward, we are buying 4 in 4 seasons, 4 design presentations for spring, summer, autumn, winter. Partly that means our stock will be more appropriate, although I should point out that this is not an absolute shift. 
People still -- if something's really fashionable and they really like it, they will buy summer dresses in early spring. So there will be a summer element to our spring ranges. But there's going to be more to buy that is appropriate to the time of year. What the customers will also see, more importantly, is a much bigger change going from spring into summer and from autumn into winter. And I think in the very long term, what you'll see is that our mid season sales accordingly increase in size, and our end of season sales reduce in size. It's not an effect that's going to take place immediately. We think over the next 10 years, we'll slowly see mid season sale increase in expense of the end of season sale.
Service is an area that we haven't focused on over the last 5 -- because I haven't talked to you about it over the last 5 years. It's not that we think we've -- it's not that we've been sleeping. It's that it hasn't been top of our list. And when you look -- if you look at where we sit -- this is an independent ranking of various retailers. I haven't named them to save any embarrassment for anybody. I haven't named the other retailers, but this is the main retailers you can think of on the high street. This is the percentage that rated outstanding, very good and good. And you can see we're about in the middle of the pack and not a long way behind #3, 4 and 5. 
However, if you look at the customers who rate NEXT outstanding and very good, the difference drops dramatically. And it's that -- it's moving from good to very good and outstanding that we are -- we aim to achieve over the next few years, both in our retail stores and as importantly, and in some ways more importantly, in terms of how we handle people in our call center.
I mean, just -- I'm going to share with you a few of the things that we -- a few of the operational things that we've done to improve service. We changed our recruitment process. And the watch word here is to recruit for attitude, not skill. So in the past, we've fallen into the trap of, say, have you got retail experience? When did you last work in a shop? And actually, it only takes half an hour to an hour to train someone on retail. It's not -- it's a job where it's far more important to us that they come and that they're nice people, that they're team players, that they work hard, that they're enthusiastic, that they turn up on time, that they get on with their colleagues, and that they genuinely want to do -- give a good service to their customers. 
We've been -- we sort of torn up our appraisal system, which is -- the appraisal systems that doubtless, you will be used to in the bank, and such great big tomes of paper that have no meaning whatsoever, but produce annual grind for people to sit through. We've changed that and done a TripAdvisor, very quick, 15-minute, half-an-hour appraisal, which we do 4 times a year, very simple rating system, 4 stars for excellent, 1 star for needs to improve or you're in trouble.
We've then taken that through into the way that we allocate extra hours. So in retail business, our peaks, we always have extra hours. When people go on holidays, we have extra hours. And in the past, that process of giving out extra hours has been done by the store manager asking people to go on extra hours. We've -- what we've done is we've developed a system whereby the staff can go on to sign in online or on their mobiles, 70% of them are doing this on their mobiles, and see what shifts are available on the different days of the week. They can then see what shifts -- what time of day their shifts are and how much they will earn. 
Because we know it's them that's logged in, we know what their pay rate is, over 21, under 21, merit sales or normal sales consultant. So we can give them the actual amount of money that they will earn. They just click on it, accept it and that's it, they're in to work. What they can also do is give up time on there. So they can swap their shifts and offer them up. So if people want, for any reason, need time off, they can offer them on the marketplace. It's not guaranteed to go, but at the moment, we are getting around 80% of the shifts that we put on the marketplace are being taken up. 
And the nice thing about this is that it works with our appraisal system. And what we do is we give the 4-star rated people an extra day to look at those shifts. So they get a whole day to take those shifts before anyone else gets a look at them, then the 3 stars, then the 2 stars, and the 1 stars don't get a look at them.
In terms of online, I'm not going -- we've done a lot with next-day delivery to store, which you know about, so I'm not going to talk about that. I'm going to talk about international. International had a really good year. GBP 33 million 2 years ago, GBP 54 million last year. In the year just gone, GBP 101 million. Two things to point out about this. It was much -- this was much greater growth than we were expecting at the beginning of the year. We said GBP 70 million to GBP 75 million. The other thing to note is the slight decline in margin. This was something that we managed. We did 2 things. First, we saved a lot of money on distribution and operations and overseas in certain territories. And we passed a little bit more than that back to our customers overseas by way of permanent price reduction. So this wasn't promotion. This is just saying everything now on this website is now 10% cheaper.
And it -- it was those price reductions more than anything else that has -- that drove the exceptional level of growth. We managed to achieve price reductions in 28 territories, which, between them, account for around 50% of our overseas territories. We also converted 5 territories that were trading in dollars or euros to their domestic currency and introduced one new translation, which was Chinese -- traditional Chinese for Taiwan. 
Looking forward to the year ahead, we're expecting around GBP 150 million growth. The reason that the growth is less aggressive than the year just gone is because we got far fewer price reductions. And when those price reductions annualize, it will be extraordinary if we didn't see a falloff in the growth rate. 
Looking to the -- we're not [indiscernible] looking to the year ahead, we've got 11 new territories we want to open. We're converting 11 countries to their domestic currency. That does have a positive impact in sales in our experience, but nothing like the effect of lowering prices. We've got 6 new languages that we're introducing on various sites across the globe and only 5 price reductions that account for just under 2% of the sales of our online business. 
Incidentally, one of the countries here that we're opening is China. This is the second time in 2 years that I've announced the opening of our Chinese website. And -- but this -- it's actually working at the moment. We've got it in test mode, so we are actually delivering stock to China. And you can't get to it yet, but that will come public in the next few days. Please don't expect too much from China. I think there's an enormous temptation to think that China is -- because there are 2 billion people, there'll be enormous number of sales. That is not our expectation. The vast majority of our customers, we don't think this -- our product will be appropriate for in China. So we're not too excited about that.
In terms of the outlook, a brief word about the economy. We are more positive about the economy than we've been for the last 6 years. Employment is looking good. Housing transactions are increasing, in line with growth in mortgage approvals. And this is definitely having an impact on our Home business, which has been our fastest-growing significant area in the last year. And that's -- and the space that we bought over the last 6 years -- we've pretty much doubled our Home space over the last 6 years. That is now beginning to really pay dividends.
The one thing about this that's interesting is although transaction levels are growing by 20% on last year, they're still 20% below the sort of run rate that the U.K. were seeing in the '90s. So we're not necessarily expecting the turnover of housing to drop in the next year. So we think that this is a permanent return to normality rather than an aberration. But we could be wrong about that.
In terms of credit flow, totals of GBP 7 billion, this is the Bank of England, flows of credit. This doesn't include write-offs or backers. This is real cash in and out of the economy. Significant change in 2013 compared to the previous 3 years. In total, GBP 7 billion of debt flowed into the economy. That's around 1% of total earnings in the U.K., total earned income excluding pensions. So it kind of makes up for the gap between -- and one way of looking at that is it kind of makes up for the fall in real earnings over the last year, which is one of the reasons I think last year was slightly better than we were expecting. 
But obviously, that cannot continue forever. You can't have credit growing faster than earnings forever. And on the earnings front, for the first time, we've seen what might be some positive news on this. And the numbers out yesterday just showed that inflation and earnings almost touching -- still negative, almost touching. So I think we're at a turning point. It's very difficult to know which way it's going to go. There might be a blip, there might not be. But if it's not a blip and we see return to growth in real earnings, then I think that is good news for the retail economy. 
So on balance, we think that things are looking slightly rosier in the economy. But there are risks. If we don't see growth in earnings, there is a question as to the sustainability of credit growth. We've all been there before. There's a real risk that the housing bubble in the southeast of the country will suck a lot of money out of the economy and encourage people to take on too much debt, and that will be not necessarily damaging in the short term, but in the medium to long term. When the interest rates go up, it will be very damaging. So although we're positive, we recognize that any real strong positive movement in the economy will result in an interest rate rise. And again, that will be a significant impact. 
There's also GBP 1.2 trillion, GBP 1.3 trillion worth of mortgage debt. 1% on that is 2% of earnings in very simple terms. It doesn't all come through straight away, some people are on fixed mortgages, some people are below the minimum. But I don't think that it will be right to prepare for a return to the boom days because as soon as it looks like there will be a boom, the interest rate breaks will be applied and you shouldn't underestimate both the science of those interest rate breaks and the shock that people will get when they go up. Because although -- sort of it's a bit like death. Everyone knows that it will happen, but no one quite believes it. So it's a nice little analogy there for you, so to get the points across. 
But I think that it will come as a significant shock to the U.K. consumer when interest rates go up. So we need to be cautious in our outlook, but we are slightly more optimistic. And for that reason, we have set our sales range between 4% and 8% maximum. That's the -- as the Chairman very gladly said vested, the highest sales range we've given since he was Chairman. We haven't been giving sales ranges for that long, for as long as he's been Chairman, I should just point out. But it is nonetheless quite an aggressive number for us. It compares to 5.5% last year. And you might think, oh, well, that's sort of typical NEXT, overly conservative. 
I would just remind you that if you look across the year, that 5.5% was hugely driven by the last quarter. And not only do we not expect the last quarter to be as strong in the year ahead. Because it was so strong, it will give us very tough comparatives. And our own budgets for the fourth quarter are extremely conservative because we know that some of the business that we won then, we are likely to lose. So if you look at the first 3 quarters, the run rate was 3%. And in that context, the 4% to 8% looks reasonable, if not aggressive.
In terms of what that means for profit, 4% to 8% profit range means we're still anticipating lower negative like-for-likes, GBP 12 million cost of negative like-for-likes, GBP 44 million of cost increases. The vast majority of that relates to wage inflation and occupancy cost increases. That will get you to over GBP 30 million of that cost. Still significant cost savings coming through in the business in Directory operations, still some savings to come through in retail operations and some balancing savings also in our occupancy costs where we've taken write-offs last year that we don't expect to recur in the year ahead, which all of you will spot on real savings and not cash, obviously. So slightly deceptive, this one. New space, we think, will give us GBP 15 million and Directory growth will give us GBP 49 million. So cost savings in Directory in equal measure, providing the lion's share of the growth for next year, midpoint of GBP 750 million. 
That was -- so that gives a profit range of 5% to 11%. A dividend yield of 2%, and that's based on the share price around GBP 65. Special dividend yield of around 3%, assuming that special dividends continue. If they don't, that 3% will just convert into earnings enhancement by way of buybacks. So underlying total shareholder returns of EPS growth plus dividend yield, we're looking at somewhere between 10% and 16% in the year ahead, which we think is a reasonable ambition. 
Just in terms of where that sits, you'll remember, I showed you this graph 5 years ago of our ambitions for earnings enhancement, profit growth and dividend yield. We achieved 25% in the year just gone. That figure is a bit of a cheat because 5% of it came from tax. So underlying growth total return is around 20%. In the year ahead, we're looking at 10% to 16%. So still comfortably within our target range of 9% to 15% that we set the business 6 years ago.

Thanks, Ms. Walter. Yes, welcome to our conference call on the preliminary fiscal year 2013 results. As always, before we start, some reminders. You should have received our press release, then the preliminary consolidated financial statements, our presentation. And if you have not received them, you can pull them from our website, which is continental-ir.com.
We will also release in the afternoon our Fact Book. It should be available after this conference call has concluded. And it contains then the latest updates on 2013 as well, of course, preliminary.
Together with myself here in Frankfurt, I have our CFO, Wolfgang; and also from our Press Department, Hannes Boekhoff. And Wolfgang will guide you through the presentation. Afterwards, we will host a question-and-answer session. From my side, that's it up to now. And I hand over to Wolfgang. Please go ahead.

---

Welcome, and thanks for your interest in Continental. Let me start with the most important KPIs for the full year of 2013, which are mainly in line with the key data which we have published already on January 13.
On Page 3, the most important KPIs I mentioned, sales were up in 2013 by 2% to EUR 33.3 billion, including an EUR 800 million headwind from foreign exchange rates, which leads to an organic growth for the full year of plus 4%.
And specifically, Q4 showed strong growth with organic sales growth of 8%, profiting from new projects, which were starting in the second half of last year and, as well, tailwind from an increase in the car production and in the tire markets.
The adjusted EBIT was up by 4% to EUR 3.7 billion, leading to an adjusted EBIT margin of 11.3%, up 30 base points. And net income after tax, up by 1% to EUR 1.9 billion, burdened on the one hand side with one-time effects from refinancing, and supported on the other hand side from tax relief effects. Both effects together with the net one-time, a burden of roughly EUR 100 million.
Free cash flow amounted to EUR 1.8 billion, another EUR 160 million better than the year before. And this number at the upper end of our communication in January 13, of more than EUR 1.5 billion. Net indebtedness, consequently down, EUR 1 billion to EUR 4.3 billion, gearing ratio at 46%, equity ratio at 35%.
We continue to create value with the trailing ROCE up by 60 basis points to 19.4%.
Three other topics which I would like to mention as most important KPI. First, investment-grade rating was reconfirmed in the second half -- was in the second half of last year, finally given to us again after many years where we did not achieve that from all 3 rating agencies: Standard & Poor's, Moody's and Fitch. Secondly, dividend proposal from us to the annual shareholder meeting is EUR 2.50 per share with a payout ratio of 26%, up from the EUR 2.25 with the similar payout ratio the year before.
Thirdly, I would like to mention again the agreement to acquire Veyance Technology for EUR 1.4 billion, which we have announced on February 10 this year.
To give some more information about sales and adjusted EBIT by quarter, I move to Page 5 on a group level. Q4 showed an increase in sales of EUR 300 million to EUR 8.4 billion increase versus previous year. Organically, specifically, adjusted for FX effect, this is a growth of 7.7% for the group, and this is reconfirming our growth-supporting portfolio.

Thank you, and a warm welcome to everyone out there for our full year '13 and Q4 earnings call for DPDHL. We are here at our headquarter in spring-like Bonn. And we assume that you've got all the material that we sent out this morning in front of you and/or follow this via the web. For our call today, we have our CEO, Frank Appel; and also our CFO, Larry Rosen, who will take you through the presentation and as usual, we will afterwards have time for answers to your questions. 
And with that, I'd like to hand over right away to you, Frank.

---

Yes, thank you, Martin. Good morning, good afternoon from myself, as well. Thank you for joining us for the call. Let me go straight away into the figures and the presentation. So if you turn to Page 3. This is a, I think, a good summary of what we have achieved last year. We had a very good year. I think, again, based on delivering an EBIT, which is just in the middle of our guidance despite that the economy was not particularly strong. The key trends are still intact. We have benefited from our strong footprint in the international express business and gained market share. We also have grown and continues to grow our parcel business in Germany; it's very strong and had a good final quarter as well. We have, unfortunately, continued to see the headwind in the air freight market and the Ocean Freight market I will come to that later on. And that has result in a very strong cash flow driven by a very good performance also in the fourth quarter, but if we got that, Larry will explain more the flow over the year. We are very happy about that. And together with the significant increase in net profits, which is also supported by lower tax rate, when we originally anticipated. 
We are happy to suggest an increase of the dividend to EUR 0.80, which is 40% lift to the previous year. So we think we have delivered all the targets of the guidance. Larry will show that in detail later on. So let me turn to the next page, where you see the different results. And if you look, start first with the group, it looks like that we shrank the business a little bit, but is only a result of foreign exchange headwinds. If you exclude that, we had been an organic growth almost 3%, and the fourth had shown the strongest growth in the year, with more than 4% organic growth. And that has led to a good development as well of our EBIT, with a number here of 7.5% EBIT growth. 
The divisions are looking positive from the revenue perspective in MAIL. We have -- and you will see later on as well, we have nice development on the top line. The EBIT looks better when actually it is, if you compare year-by-year. It is a good number, we are now about EUR 1.2 billion, but we have last year a negative impact of EUR 150 million from the VAT and the State Head proceedings. And we have this year, as we already told you earlier, a slight improvement because we have released a post of provisions. So if you take that out it would be -- the number would be slightly down more or less on the same level as previous year. 
EXPRESS, the other way, is showing here no growth, but it has grown quite nicely, if you exclude foreign exchange. The profit has lifted more than it's shown here because we had last year about EUR 100 million, one-off effect as a positive in 2012. And therefore, if you exclude that, we have a nice development, which is above 10% growth from the bottom line, and you will see later on as well, the nice development of the margin. 
FORWARDING, FREIGHT has continued to be challenged from the market. Our strategy to be focused on profitable business has put pressure on our top line, so we definitely lost market share, but the profitability from the margin is still the same, as you'll see later and the profitability is only slightly down year-over-year. You are still the second best year ever in forwarding activities despite that we have a significant transformation going on.
SUPPLY CHAIN, also challenged with foreign exchange changes, exchange rate changes, and if you exclude that, we are probably about 5% very nice growth. You will see later on that we had some positive one-offs in the fourth quarter, but if you take the year, those numbers are more or less on the same level, and we are compensating some one-offs positive in the last quarter, some pushback in the first quarter. So overall, that is a nice development. And as you have seen, from our release, we have now changes well in the management in best terms in a way that Bruce wanted to hand over to his predecessor in the moment, where we have to start thinking about the next step any way before I got our strategy and instead of me on board to start executing that [indiscernible] is better prepared that we head over. So that's the reason, why we have that change, it was not because the performance is just satisfactory or whatsoever. It is really because we think, it's a good timing for have a transition to the younger colleague. 
So overall, we are happy with the numbers. If you go to next page, Page 5. You'll see that we even have seen in the MAIL, communication volumes an increase which is parcel has grown as well very nicely. The dependency on letter is shrinking as you see here as well if you look from revenue. 
The E-Post revenue is now EUR 100 million, which is a significant step to the previous year. We have transferred as well some parcel operations in Europe to the MAIL division, which have an impact on the EBIT for 2014, and you will see that later on in the guidance. We have still a challenge that we grow revenue, but we don't generate more profit and that comes from factor cost increases, but also significant wage cost. And of course, we have to work on that, but the good news is that we have now a growing business again. 
EXPRESS is definitely our star performer and has continued so, very nice growth here in all dimensions. And also, if you look to the right, the margin has improved for the whole year and more than a percentage point in the last 3 quarters. So we are delivering what we have promised you a couple of years ago that we first to invest and then we expand margins, and that is happening. And Ken always said that 2013 would be a year of margin expansion. 
FORWARDING, FREIGHT, the good news on that page is that the deterioration of volumes is slowing. So you see here in the fourth quarter, we had less airfreight reduction than we have in previous quarters and in ocean freight, we have even an increase. So I think, we are heading in the right direction. Nevertheless, 2014 will be as 2013, a challenging year because we will go through the transformation organizationally, introducing -- introduction of the new system despite that we are making good progress, as steady here as well. There will be a challenge and also the markets are not yet, so much stronger than last year.
SUPPLY CHAIN, also a new record number in new signings. I think that's a great number with EUR 1.5 billion. The business, we win is larger and has good attractive margins, which are higher than the existing business. So we believe that this we continue and I have no doubt that the new colleague, who is coming from the region with the strongest margin, Americas will help us to improve even further. 
So these are the results from a high-level of a volume development. If I now go to Page 10, you see additional elements of what we want to do in e-commerce. Yes, we want to roll out now the parcel boxes in Germany. We have added additional services to our parcel products to make it even more convenient for our customers, so that they really have an easy life and get easy access. So we will continue to do that. That will be less an investment case, but in the continuous improvement overall. 
On Page 11, you see the development of the revenue proportion which comes from the emerging markets. If we compare last year with 2009, we have seen a significant step upwards and that we have no doubt that this will continue into next year because with fundamental trends of globalization are still intact even if the growth is right in some of these areas is smaller than what it was.
Last page, before I come to the guidance for this year and next year. We had invested in 2012 significantly. We have continued to invest in 2013, and one of the biggest investments, we will start now or have started last quarter is the expansion of our major hub in Leipzig. That's the result of significant growth. That's also, if you look later in the guidance, that's also the reason why we think, we will continue to see even a slight increase in CapEx because we see significant growth in our operations and to feed that and to continue to grow fast, we probably need more CapEx when we a couple of years anticipated. But that is not for any crazy things, it's really for supporting the strong growth we have experienced very recently and we want to continue in that path. 
Page 13, the guidance for 2014. We believe that we can deliver EUR 2.9 billion to EUR 3.1 billion. So another step into the direction of our 2015 target. We have increased the MAIL guidance to about EUR 1.2 billion. It's also driven by the transfer of some businesses from EXPRESS and that's a flipside that given the number is small in DHL and maybe then you have anticipated originally that, that comes also because we have transferred some activities, as mentioned about EUR 60 million from the DHL divisions to MAIL. The Corporate Center/Other should next year or this year better than EUR 400 million. We are very confident and the free cash flow should at least cover the 2013 dividend. Larry will talk a little bit more about some timing effects with regard to the cash flow. We believe that this is doable and we should see the same, what we have seen this year that we can really pay the dividend out of the free cash flow. 
The tax rates should go up again and as I already said, the gross CapEx would go up to about EUR 1.9 billion. And that is only driven by our greatest success in the marketplaces and mainly by Parcel and EXPRESS. And if you look then on the next page, you see that we have not changed our guidance overall for 2015. We are still confident, despite it still needs hard work because the economy is not helping us, and currencies are not helping us either. That we are confident that we will deliver that number. We have increased MAIL as a consequence of some transfers as well to $1.1 billion and that's the reason, FX [indiscernible] being reduced the guidance for the DHL divisions and for Corporate Centers, it's still the same. 
So we are, at the moment, confident that we can deliver the 2014, and this is another step into the direction that we deliver next year, as well the guidance, we gave you already a while ago. So with that, I would like to hand over to Larry to talk a little more about other some good financial [indiscernible] in the fourth quarter. Thank you for listening.
