Good afternoon, everybody. I want to continue the presentation now with a deeper look at our financial performance for the whole year 2013 and also for Q4. And that will include also a review of the performance for the division. 
So turning on to the next slide. We're very pleased that we've been able to meet or exceed all aspects of our 2013 guidance with growth of 7.4%. EBIT at EUR 2.861 billion was just about in the middle of our guidance range. MAIL, DHL and Corporate Center, each met their targets as well.
As forecast, net income grew faster than EBIT with almost 28% growth to around EUR 2.1 billion, and we'll talk a bit more about the reasons for that excellent performance in just a minute. And finally, free cash flow was a star performer in 2013 with EUR 1.65 billion of free cash flow generated, far in excess of what we would have needed to cover the dividend that we paid last May.
Over to the next page. You see our dividend recommendation, which we hope will be approved in the shareholder meeting in May. Due to -- especially to the excellent cash flow and net income performance, the management and supervisory board have recommended the dividend increase of EUR 0.10 per share to EUR 0.80. This keeps us right in the middle of our target range of 40% to 60%, and represents an increase of over 14% compared to last year.
Now, let's turn to the next page and look at our P&L for the full year 2013. So revenues were slightly down, as Frank talked about, due mainly to adverse currency movements. However, organic growth was around 3% for the year. MAIL EBIT increased significantly mostly due to onetime effects like the utilization of the stamp provision this year and the charge for the VAT settlement last year. 
DHL EBIT increased slightly, but was actually significantly improved considering positive onetime effects that we had last year and significant currency headwind, that we had this year. So MAIL wasn't quite as good as it looks and DHL was quite better than it looks.
Financial expense improved significantly due to the overall low interest rate environment and lower interest expenses on provisions associated with, for example, the large pension funding that we did at the end of 2012. Tax expense declined and the effective tax rate was far lower than we expected due to some favorable audit closures, both early in the year, so we knew about those, but also late in the year. So in Q4 and even towards the end of Q4. And we were also able to activate more tax loss carryforwards than we originally anticipated. As a result of these positive developments, net income and EPS increased by around 28% for the year. 
On to the next page, we have a look at DHL margins, where we also were quite satisfied with our margin performance in DHL overall. In particular, EXPRESS could increase its margin by more than 1% to just under 9% for the full year. And this was a result of scale effects and efficiencies stemming from investments and initiatives that we have implemented over the last several years and also naturally the volume and revenue growth that we've been able to achieve. 
Global FREIGHT and FORWARDING could stabilize the margin at 3.3%, despite higher spending on NFE, and I'll come back to that in a minute, and lower revenues and also volumes. This was due to our selective market strategy and also strict cost control.
Supply chain margin increased to 3.1% as the benefits of new, more attractive contracts improved our overall contract mix.
And on the next slide, you'll see the P&L for Q4. And Q4 was, as usual, our strongest quarter of the year. Revenues also declined slightly, but we had our best quarter in terms of organic growth with 4.2%. EBIT increased by 7% over the very strong Q4 that we had last year. MAIL declined slightly as the benefits from Letter and Parcel volume growth could not quite offset the increase in factor cost, in particular, labor costs. 
DHL improved significantly with 13% growth over Q4 of 2012, led especially by EXPRESS and SUPPLY CHAIN. And the good results in financial and tax expense that I mentioned already were especially evident in Q4. This combined with the growth in EBIT, led to a 44% growth in net income just for the quarter.
And looking on to Page 8, as mentioned, we have very strong cash flow for 2013, and a great finish to the year in Q4. We saw the typical seasonal pattern in 2013, where the second half is much stronger than the first half and certainly 2013, was no exception.
In Q3 and Q4, we were able to preserve and even build on the outperformance that we had already achieved in the first half compared to previous years.
In expanding on free cash flow performance on the next page. In Q4 of 2012, most of you know that we have the approximately EUR 2 billion pension funding, which from an accounting point of view, is a reduction in operating cash flow. Correcting for that pension funding, you see a much cleaner comparison in the right 2 columns of cash flow performance just for Q4. Here are better operating earnings, a very good performance on working capital reduction with contributions from both receivables reduction and increases in payables and lower cash out for CapEx, all contributed to the free cash flow generation of over EUR 1 billion.
As mentioned, we had some timing effects, which make part of the very strong cash flow generation transitory in nature. In particular, we booked a fair amount of CapEx, just toward the end of the year, where the cash out will occur or has occurred in 2014. We estimate that in total, these transitory effects amount to between EUR 300 million and EUR 400 million with the largest effect being the just mentioned CapEx effect.
On to the next page. We're very pleased to be able to reduce our net debt by around EUR 470 million for the year, with the big reduction of around EUR 1 billion in Q4. Adjusting for the pension funding, we did at the end of 2012 of EUR 2 billion, we actually would've been cash positive again at the end of 2013 as we were in 2010 and 2011.
We expect to again follow our seasonal pattern in 2014, so that our net debt should increase during the first half then improve considerably during the second half of the year.
And now, over 2 pages, we'll take a look at each division's performance. And we'll start with the Mail division, where revenues increased also in Q4, due to the stamp price increase from the beginning of the year. Increased traffic due to the SEPA preparation. For those that don't know, SEPA is a new vehicle for electronic payments that's being rolled out first in the Eurozone and then later in all of the EU in 2016. It was supposed to have been implemented on February 1. That got delayed at the last minute to August 1. Nevertheless, there was a lot of mail traffic, both the businesses and private individuals, instructing them how to be compliant with SEPA. And that really had a benefit for our MAIL business in terms of volumes in Q4. 
We've also seen that EBIT, while on a satisfactory level, declined slightly as the benefits of revenue growth could not quite cover the increase in factor costs, most importantly labor cost. The cash flow trend is distorted by the pension funding from the end of 2012, where 95% or EUR 1.9 billion of the EUR 2 billion pension funding is attributed to the MAIL division since most of the retirees are MAIL retirees.
CapEx increased significantly year-over-year, and compared to the first 3 quarters of this year. As we spent more on expanding and improving our Parcel infrastructure, in particular for the Parcel project 2012. 
And moving on to EXPRESS. The division continued to perform very well in Q4. Revenues were significantly affected by currency movement and to a lesser extent, by smaller divestitures. Organic revenue growth was close to 6%. EBIT increased by over 14% and the operating margin increased by 120 basis points to 9.6% in Q4. And the primary drivers for the improvement are continued strong TDI volume growth, driving scale benefits, as well as the efficiency benefits enabled by investments in the ground and air network over the last years. Cash flow was very strong with an increase of 19% compared to last year. 
And moving now to Global FORWARDING and FREIGHT. They really have continued to be affected by trends that we've seen in previous quarters. Revenue declined due to continued weak volume trends, driven by an overall weak market environment and a particular impact on us due to our sector and customer mix. With our leadership position in airfreight, we've been especially affected by structural changes causing down trading in technology or modal shift in technology and a weak engineering and manufacturing sector. 
In addition, our road freight business is largely concentrated in Europe, where the economy has been comparatively softer compared to other regions. And of course, we're implementing the comprehensive change initiative called NFE amid these weak market conditions. And in Q4, we spent more than in previous quarters on NFE implementation. 
In recent months, we've seen signs of recovery in volumes, though the trend in gross profit margins remains challenging. And last but not least, SUPPLY CHAIN, on the next page, the SUPPLY CHAIN division continues to perform well, benefiting from a strong trend in new business generation and the accompanying benefits from a continuously improving contract mix that we're able, as a result, to achieve. EBIT benefited from net positive onetime effects in Q4 of around EUR 30 million, but nevertheless, increased by around 28% even without that effect. For the full year, positive and negative onetime effects for the division, just about fully offset each other, so that the improvement for the full year was around 5%, with an increase in EBIT margin from 2.9% to 3.1%. Cash flow was very strong in Q4, with the biggest contributor being a reduction in working capital.
And wrapping up on the last page of the presentation. MAIL EBIT has clearly been stabilized above EUR 1 billion, our longtime target in strategy 2015. We've made further progress on DHL profitability improvement with strong improvement in EXPRESS. We had a very strong 2013 cash flow performance. However, with the mentioned timing effects, and we confirm again our 2015 group guidance. Please remember to save the date for our Capital Markets Day on April 2nd in Frankfurt. We'll be very pleased if you're able to join us. And now, we will be happy to answer any questions you might have.

---

Thanks, Frank, thanks, Larry. And operator, if you could start the Q&A sequence, please.

Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and warm welcome to the presentation of the Sika Results 2013. I'm happy to see you all here. I will give you the highlights of 2013, and after, Adrian Widmer, will present the details in -- the results in more detail, then I will come back with our Strategy 2018 and outlook for the ongoing business here. 
We had a very exciting year 2013, I'm very happy with what our employees delivered in all our markets. We had, for the first time, sales of over CHF 5 billion, and also we had record numbers in all our key financial indicators from the operating profit to the net profit to the operating free cash flow. 
We are very happy also to see our growth momentum, which picked up throughout the year. As you remember, we started very slow in the first quarter of the year, and then we have an amazing growth momentum in the following months and quarters. 
We grew in all regions, even in Europe with some crisis market, we could grow. And of course, our growth engine, the emerging markets, in our case, did not lose any speed. We finished the year with over 17% growth in local currency, and despite all the currency devaluation in some of these markets even in Swiss francs, we were over 11% sales growth in Swiss francs in these emerging markets. 
So we are very proud of our numbers, I think, what our people delivered around the globe for 2013. Maybe even more important than the numbers, I think, is the investments we did for the future of Sika. We opened 10 new factories in the growth markets around the world. This is a record number. We never opened 10 factories in 1 year. This is our commitment to our growth strategy. Also, our research and development departments around the globe worked with full force. Some details, when you look at our profit and loss statements, we have a very nice through flow here from the growth in Swiss francs of plus 6.5%. And based on the increase in gross margins, which we could achieve, and our disciplined cost management,  the operating profit increased by 20.9% and the net profit by 23.8%. 
Very important for us also the free cash flow, here with the high net profit, we also achieved a lowering of our networking capital, which gives us a record result here in the operating free cash flow of CHF 432 million, which is a plus of 43%. 
I want to share some reports here with you regarding our regions. As I said, we are very happy we could grow in all our 4 regions, even in Europe, we had a very nice growth here, partially driven by the acquisitions, but also we had organic growth here in Europe, Middle East and Africa. Very happy to see that the crisis markets in Spain, Portugal and Greece, they have bottomed out, and we are confident that from now on, we will also see growth in these markets. We have then from the acquisitions side, we were very happy that last year we had many opportunities to welcome great companies to join Sika. What is even more exciting for us is that this growth takes place not on the countryside but in the cities. So we see bigger cities, more cities and we see the so-called megacities. This is very exciting for us because the bigger the city, the more Sika products you need to use. Why? Because you have the high-rise buildings. The high-rise building needs a totally higher concrete quality compared to low-rise housing. So if you want to build high-rise buildings, you need very high specification on your concrete and we are of course, very happy to support this with our products. At the same time, all these megacities or the high-rise buildings they have flat roofs. Our roofing and waterproofing products, they are for flat roofs. We are not a tile manufacturer for the pitched roofs, we do our membranes and our liquid PU and acrylic products for flat roofs, and you can imagine that this city trend is a huge driver of our product demand for our products. 
At the same time, you also built wherever you have space and land, you're not concerned so much with water in the ground like we were before, so you build this high-rise building, they go very deep in the ground, and they are also built in the areas where you wouldn't built before in the past, so you need plenty of good waterproofing to make these buildings happening. 
Then of course, all these buildings, the stand outs for safety, for fire standards, also for earthquake resistant, as you can read in the media is increasing year-by-year and you need solid Sika adhesives and bonding products to make this happening in the buildings. 
Last but not the least, these megacities have a totally different demand and higher demand for infrastructure. What does it mean? You need the subways, you need these special highways, elevated highways, you really have to invest totally different in the infrastructure to keep these cities running, and you can imagine all these infrastructure projects from subways to bridges to high-rise highways, they need factor 10x Sika products compared to regular building for infrastructure maybe on the countryside. 
So we're very excited about the urbanization and the megacities, and believe we can play an important role here for the future of these cities. 
When we go to another leg of Sika, in the motor vehicle industry, you'll see the trend for lighter cars, for electrical cars, for safer cars, we have that in the newspaper every day. And one key trend behind this is that these cars are using new materials. You all read about the BMW i3. That's the first mass vehicle built completely out of carbon fiber. And this carbon fiber cannot be welded anymore like the traditional steel body of a car, it has to be bonded. And they're using large amounts of adhesives, as you can imagine to really bond all these different carbon fiber parts together. 
We have different trends also for other materials, the modern car is not a steel car anymore, they use a combination of steel, of high-strength steel, of magnesium, of aluminum and all these different material mix cannot be welded anymore, has to be bonded. So we have a huge increase of bonding applications in the motor vehicle industry, and we are very confident that this is a very important megatrend for us in the future. 
We have then -- the third megatrend, which is increasing the trend for Sika products is sustainability. Yes, all are aware of that. It's a huge task for everyone. So buildings in the future have to be better isolated, have to be better sealed, and this can be done, of course, with fantastic sealing solutions from Sika. Also, the durability and the life cycle concepts for this buildings, you need high quality to make this building last a very long time. You see the gentleman here enjoying the flat roof here in the megacity, and this green roof is only possible because we have a special Sika membrane system underneath, which allows to grow plants and grass on the roof. 
Last but not the least, also our products have a big challenge. We want to be, of course, we want to be the front-runner with green products. We don't want to harm any user with our products and we have big developments to have safe chemistry available for the consumer and the applicator. 
So these are the 3 megatrends, which I want to present to you, which we believe is a strong driver of the future growth. It of course, it doesn't come overnight. The construction industry, the motor vehicle industry is conservative, they have a long planning period, so you will see a positive effect of 1%, 2% or 3% each year for our markets, but I think for a very, very long period of time. 
When you look at the competitive situation, you notice that our industry is still very fragmented. When you look at the construction chemical market, the market is CHF 50 billion big, maybe a little bit bigger, Sika is the largest competitor in this field, the market leader. And if I add the next 4 competitors total market share is only 26%. So here's also plenty of room for us to consolidate the market and to grow the market. 
When I look at our position, I think we are in excellent shape, excellent position with our target market concept, which we introduced 1 year ago on 7 target markets. We are focused with our core competencies of bonding, sealing, damping, reinforcing and protecting for this 7 target markets to make the right additives for the concrete, provide liquid and membrane solutions for waterproofing, the same for the roofing to have our epoxy polyurethane, floorings for factories but also for hospitals, for office buildings. We are one of the leading companies in sealing and bonding for construction and for the motor vehicle industry. And last but not least, we offer the right repair and refurbishment solutions in all our application fields. 
I think this is a good position to be in. Our footprint, I think, is very strong. We are the market leader already in construction chemicals. We are the leader in adhesives, maybe #2 or #3 biggest adhesive company in the world. Our focus on innovation has been our history for over 100 years. We have currently over 800 people working in the labs around the world on new products and new product introductions for our customers. And in 2013 alone they were writing 73 patents. 
In the emerging markets we believe we are the first movers. You have seen the list of new factories in these markets in 2013 alone, and we believe, here, we can further push here and be the market leader clearly in this emerging markets. Our global footprint, we are close to the customer already now, we operate over 160 factories around the world. We are maybe one of the few companies who really have a global brands and, for sure, the strongest brand here globally in the industry. 
I think one of our key success factors is our company culture. We are very entrepreneurial-driven company. We give a lot of responsibility and empowerment to our people. Also, especially to our people in the countries. General Manager of the country doesn't wait till someone in Switzerland pushes a button, they make their own decisions and usually, they make the right decisions and they move much faster compared to centralized organizations. Last but not least, we have a solid financial position which gives us the freedom to act also in the future. 
So we defined our Strategy 2018, we call it building trust, and we believe the Sika growth model, which we defined will ensure our long-term success and our profitable growth for the company in the future. We believe we have a excellent position in our 7 target markets. We can provide a full range of solutions to our customers for all these megaprojects around the globe. Innovation is the core of our company. This will continue. The acceleration of the emerging markets makes us very confident also for the future growth. And last but not least, we have our Sika spirit, our sets of principles and values, which makes up the entrepreneurial spirit of our company. 
We have defined the Sika's values and principles for the first time in writing. I think you also have a handout for it because today is our official launch also of these statements of Sika. 
If you look at our growth model, in 5 points, it's very is simple. This is what our 16,290 employees move everyday. We want to penetrate the market with our full range from roof to floor, we are doing new buildings, same as refurbishments. You have to imagine we do in markets like Switzerland, U.S., or Germany, maybe 80% of our sales is related to refurbishment, while the emerging markets, 95% is new build. So we have a very good balance from new build to refurbishment, makes us also, I think, very crisis resistant because we don't rely on 1 area only. 
Our global technology leadership is what really drives the company. Wherever you go, in our business they talk about new products and how to solve the customer problem. Accelerated buildup of emerging markets. We opened 6 new factories in 2012, another 10 factories last year and for this year, we target to open 8 new factories. Acquisitions, we're in a good position. I think we did about 50 acquisitions in the last 12 years. Last year, we were quite active, maybe one of the most, or the most active year in Sika's history. Here I think we have a good process and good principles to also create value through these acquisitions. And last but not least, this model only works because we have the people behind. We have people who see themselves as entrepreneurs, who are empowered by us, who get the responsibility to do the job. 
Our Targets through 2018. We, of course, we will continue our growth strategy. We believe we will achieve 6% to 8% growth annually until 2018. The share of the emerging markets will further increase to somewhere 42% to 45%. From the margins side we believe that the double-digit EBIT margin we achieved in 2013 is not a one-time event. We believe that we can achieve this now year-by-year. 
Same for the operating free cash flow, important also for us to do our own financing within the groups, also here we target to be above 6% of net sales for the future. And return on capital employed will stay above 20%, and also our A- rating is an important element to be able to be strong and self-sufficient on the finance side. 
This is my explanation and introduction to the Strategy 2018. This strategy is already now implemented in Sika, it's based on all country plans and we are executing already with full force. 
Now I would like to come to the outlook 2014. We believe in line with the strategy we will see 6% to 8% growth for 2014. We will continue to build up the emerging markets. We have plans for 8 new factories this year, all of them in the emerging markets. 
For Asia/Pacific, we see a continued good situation in China and in Southeast Asia, maybe with the exception of Thailand. We don't know if how the unrest develops but as we know, this political unrest can go away in Thailand quite fast, but also maybe can be a bigger problem. But overall, we are very confident. We're also confident that we will slightly grow in the OECD countries in Japan, Korea and the Pacific area, we believe with the new products, which we introduced in these markets that we will also grow in these mature markets. 
Latin America, I think we'll see a little bit more trouble in 2014 compared to 2013. We have the Venezuela case, we have the Argentina case, we don't know the slowdown in Brazil. I was in Brazil in January this year, I think in the third week, and the people said, normally we don't work very hard until the Carnival, which this year is very late in March, and then we have the Soccer Championship in June, July, and we have the general election in October this year. So we have also some uphill battles in Brazil this year. However, we are confident that overall, we would have a double-digit growth again in Latin America, even so the market might be a bit more bumpy compared to 2013. 
North America. I think it's time now, after we saw a very nice development of the residential building sector, that the industrial and the infrastructure segment will also show some signs of growth in 2014. So hopefully, we can achieve single-digit growth, around 5% to 6% in North America. This would be my expectations at this point in time. 
Then in EMEA, we had, I would say, a better-than-expected market environment in 2013, and we also believe that this very slow recovery will continue into this year, plus we have the growth regions of Africa and the Middle East, where we expect, of course, a bigger growth. 
On the margin side, we believe we will have rather stable margins with all the little bumps ahead from the exchange rates and also taking all these new factories into operations. We believe that the margin will develop proportionately to the sales growth in 2014. 
Good. Then I think we are finished with the formal presentation, and we are very happy to answer questions.

5107401.transcript_text1:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Beiersdorf's Analyst Meeting. It's our pleasure to have you all here in our headquarters in Hamburg today. As you know, we had already published our preliminary results on January 16. What we have here for you today is then the full set of data and lots of interesting details about the year 2013. 
We will start our meeting today with a message from our CEO, Stefan Heidenreich, and I'm happy that he is here today because he had to undergo complex knee surgery not too long ago, still is not mobile and will need some more time for recovery. So I'm really glad you're here, and you're going to talk about the progress that Beiersdorf has made in the year 2013 based on the Blue Agenda. We'll come to that in a second.
Our CFO, Ulrich Schmidt, is going to speak about the financial details of the year 2013. And then at the end of the meeting, as always, we're going to have a question-and-answer here with you. 
So I suggest we start now and I hand over to Stefan Heidenreich.

---

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Beiersdorf's full year financial analyst meeting. Thank you for your interest in our company's performance in financial year 2013. Together with my colleague, Ulrich Schmidt, I will now give you an update on the group's financial performance in 2013, as well as an overview on the operational and strategic development of Beiersdorf. 
Ladies and gentlemen, 2013 was an important and successful year for Beiersdorf. The group made gains in market share, increased sales and improved its earnings. Beiersdorf is back on a sustainable growth track.
In 2012, we developed and started with our Blue Agenda. In 2013, we further deeply implemented the Blue Agenda within the organization. The results so far, our brands are back, we are gaining market shares in our core categories, we are significantly expanding our presence in the emerging markets and we are strengthening our position in Europe. In short, we are pleased with the 2013 results. We are seeing a continuous, sustainable upward trend for Beiersdorf.
Turning to the financials. We increased organic group sales by 7.2%. In nominal terms, the growth rate was at the level of 1.7%, as a result primarily of the strong euro. 
Net sales for the year were EUR 6.141 billion, even excluding special factors improved by 10.7% from EUR 735 million to EUR 814 million, representing an EBIT margin, excluding special factors, of 13.2% compared to last year's 12.2%. 
Profit after tax, excluding special factors, rose from EUR 480 million to EUR 537 million. The executive and supervisory boards will propose to the shareholders' meeting a dividend of EUR 0.70 per share.
To the Consumer segment. In 2013, the Consumer business segment recorded organic sales growth of 7.0%. In nominal terms, sales rose by 1.1% from EUR 5.048 billion to EUR 5.103 billion. Each of the group's core brands contributed to this positive development, with NIVEA delivering 7.5% growth; Eucerin, 11.5%; and La Prairie, 7.5%. 
EBIT, excluding special factors, saw an increase of 5.2% to EUR 638 million, representing an improvement in the EBIT margin, again excluding special factors, from 12.0% to 12.5%.
Turning now to the regions. In Europe, the business recorded an organic sales growth of 0.9%. In Western Europe, for the first time since 2008, we were able to deliver sales growth. In our home country of Germany, we saw a very pleasing performance. We also saw significant sales in the United Kingdom and Spain. And in Southern Europe, there were initial signs of recovery. In Eastern Europe, sales remained more or less at last year's level, with a slight decline of minus 0.4%. The Americas region was able to deliver strong organic sales growth of 9.0%. North America saw growth of 4.6%, and Latin America, 11.4%, with especially strong growth in Brazil. Most of the other Latin American markets also delivered good rates.
We also recorded strong sales growth in Africa/Asia/Australia region. Organic sales increased by 19%. All of the markets in the region achieved significant growth uplift, in particular, China, India and Japan.
To tesa. For the reporting period, the tesa business segment increased organic sales by 8.5%. Nominal sales rose by 4.7%, from EUR 992 million in the previous year to EUR 1.038 billion. 
EBIT, excluding special factors, moved up from EUR 129 million to EUR 176 million, an increase of 36.3%, representing an improved EBIT margin of 16.9% compared to last year's 13.0%. 
All regions were successful, with especially strong growth rates in the U.S. and Asia. Key growth areas were the electronics and automotive industries. This strong performance once again demonstrates the sustainability and strength of tesa's innovation powers.
Ladies and gentlemen, these positive developments result from the strategic decisions made in 2012, laid down in our Blue Agenda and systematically implemented in 2013. All the business activities, priorities, focus on strengthening our brands, first and foremost, NIVEA; second, increasing our innovation power; and third, systematically expanding our presence in the emerging markets while strengthening our position in Europe.
To brands. Beiersdorf has a portfolio of outstanding and globally successful brands. Above all, we are recharging the iconic NIVEA brand. Our disciplined and focused brand strategy has enabled us to sharpen the brand profile and, thereby, win market shares. 
Our new brand logo and new packaging designs for NIVEA significantly increased brand recognition among NIVEA consumers. This has been demonstrated by several representative consumer panels. Recently and importantly, NIVEA was again voted the most popular brand among Germans. 
Innovation. The new products we have launched on the market are resonating well with our consumers. New products such as body, In-Shower; face, Cellular Anti-Age; and deo, Stress Protect generated significant market momentum in 2013 in all launch markets. For example, NIVEA In-Shower was one of the best sellers in the body category, already in the first year. We also saw growth in the face category, mainly driven by the launch of NIVEA Cellular Anti-Age. 
To markets. As part of the company's strategic development, we have sharpened our focus on the emerging markets without losing sight of our traditional markets. In 2013, we successfully expanded our position in the emerging markets and improved our structures. These regions now account for more -- and this is for the first time, than 50% of the Consumer business segment total sales, to be precise, 52%. The construction of new factories and regional development labs in China, Mexico and India are important steps towards better identifying the specific regional consumer needs and integrating these into our expanding product portfolio. To be a little bit even more concrete, our new development center in the Chinese city of Wuhan is already operational. Our new Mexican plant, a big plant, and regional lab will be completed in summer 2014. And in India, we're planning a new production facility with more than 300 employees. That is expected to be completed by 2015.
To the outlook. Ladies and gentlemen, let me close my presentation by giving some guidance on 2014. In 2014, we will systematically continue our profitable growth path on the basis of our Blue Agenda. We will also benefit from a slight recovery in the global economy, which we are expecting in the industrialized nations. By contrast, we expect the developing and emerging countries to see weaker performance than in the previous years. 
For 2014, we forecast for the Consumer business segment sales growth in the excess of 4% to 6%. The operating EBIT margin should be slightly above this year's level. As regards tesa, we expect sales to slightly outperform the market, which is forecasted to grow by 2% to 3%. Tesa's EBIT margin from operations is expected to be slightly below the prior year's level. Based on the forecast for the 2 business segments, we expect the group sales to grow by 4% to 6%. The consolidated EBIT margin from operations should slightly exceed the prior-year figure. 
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your attention.

---

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. I'm happy to present some more financials. So, first of all, give us a lot of credit. So let's have a look to the facts and figures. 
Here, we see the development of the group. If you have a look towards the like-for-like, sales of 7.2%, you'll see that we have a devaluation effect of 5.5%. It's coming out of 3 factors. First of all, you'll be aware that we have the strong euro, so that rest of the world translate into this euro, that's the first effect. Secondly, we have strong devaluation of a number of emerging market currencies, especially with the Indian rupee and South African rand. We have seen it also in Brazilian real. And thirdly, we had a substantial effect from Venezuela because we were applying actual exchange rates last year. And that's a very conservative approach that took some sales in nominal terms.
If you look to the EBIT and profit after tax, you have a difference between reported and those excluded special factors. What have been the special factors? First of all, last year, we had EUR 37 million coming from restructuring of China and coming also out of impairment calculation in Turkey. We have increased our share to 100%. This year, we had a rather normal -- this year 2013, we had a rather normal year, without a lot of extraordinary factors, so that we have EUR 43 million better result in extraordinary.
If we look to the different regions, you have seen part of that slide already, so we had a very balanced situation in Europe. We're growing our market share slightly. We had a mix situation in Americas, first of all, the single-digit growth in North America, above the market and strongly above the market in Latin America. Now we have been affected by the devaluations of the currencies in Latin America. Like I was mentioning, if we have excluded Venezuela, we would have seen more than 15% of growth in Latin America. 
We have very strong growth in Africa, Near East, Asia. The countries have been extremely well in terms of growth had been India, Middle East and South Africa. We have done good growth in Japan and in China.
We are especially satisfied seeing that the gross margin are stable. First of all, we need to make you aware that we still depend on our production network in Europe, which means that we invoice in euro to part of the regions. That compensated that. Secondly, it's also compensating the stronger growth of emerging markets that normally have lower gross margins than Europe. And thirdly, we have also had an effect from the Venezuela reporting, where we had reported high gross margins in the past using official exchange rates and now had applied market rates.
We come to the share of sales and EBIT. Emerging markets now, as you see, is contributing 31% of the EBIT and has a steady development. Together with our strong growth, we are gaining more #1 and #2 positions. We are also increasing our market share and, therefore, we are generating natural profitability in those markets and that's a trend that we are seeing also for the next years.
So in tesa, we have a number of special applications. We called it projects, and also our calls that we've had over the year. That's an example. We can see in electronics, we had a number of applications in tesa that was in smartphones, tablets, MP3 players or PDA and the number of applications in these machineries. If you're interested in that, I have taken a folder that will show you that in a deal like that, you have up to 12 applications for tesa, and that's a substantial business. Now it's difficult to forecast what business will be over this year, next year, because normally, the lifespan of tools like that is rather 12 months -- 6 months, 12 months. So it depends on the tenders that are going, to which extent you can qualify for a tender.  
What we have seen is a steep increase in our investments. The biggest project we are having is a big Mexico plant. We'll have production in that plant in first quarter, start of this year. We'll also bring over more and more production volumes from North America to that plant. We'll close down the old plant in Mexico City in the first half of next year. 
Secondly, we have a new headquarter for tesa that will open in 2015. It's also having a place for maybe 1,000 tesa people who used to be in that area of the town.
The guidance, you've seen already. Mentioning this, I'd like to make you aware that, again, like we've done in Venezuela, we'll do a very conservative approach this year for Argentina and we'll apply actual exchange rates for Argentina when calculating like-for-like, and that will, of course, have an effect like we have had an effect applying those rates already in 2013. Now we'll have that effect for 2014 as well. 
That's the end of my presentation.

Have you started thinking about North America yet? And can you maybe remind us how big Venezuela and Argentina are of your Latin American sales?

---

Let's start with Western Europe. And as such, I mean, I think we are very, very pleased in Western Europe. It was next to the west to the emerging market where we saw growth early on, Western Europe is now quite nicely growing. And we're not growing 1% or 2%, we're growing close to 10%. So we are very pleased in Europe. Things are turning around there. And margin-wise, it's always the same. Once you grow in this business, you also make nice margins. So the margin development in Europe is still strong despite all the factors of pricing, of trade, of what can we count on. But it's overall in a very good development. We always had margin, but we've also gone back to growth. I think North America is a similar one and, it's such that we are finding our way better to growth. My biggest headache is more to your question on the resource question per se. Okay. No more questions? Then I would say -- Harold has a final one. Final, final?

---

A, B and C. No knee-jerk reaction on people, but are you basically suggesting that you need more people from the outside and the inside to deliver the growth ambitions which you have, is that what you basically said?

Well, I think really, predominantly, it only can happen from the inside because this is also, I think, the bench we probably -- if you look at that, it's probably -- that's a funny thing that probably some insight, in Beiersdorf, we have a strong first bench now. The next bench hardly exists. And then below that, we have great talents again. So we missed one if you want, how do you say, [German] one generation, right? And that layer we have to fill. We have taken a lot of strings up. The question is -- the thing is more when you look at -- I give Southeast Asia. I mean, we are growing significantly in Vietnam. The more successful you are, the more you attract great talent. And I think we are -- we are on the roof. Our younger ranks look pretty healthy and pretty good for what is coming up. And here and there, we have -- also have to take people from outside to fill the big gaps we have. So it's a mixture of everything at the moment. But that will be one of the most important questions, getting the deeper questions solved over the years to come, with growth we expect there.

---

And then 2 sort of small ones. On tesa, Ulrich, you said -- you discussed about the life cycle of products, that it's hard to guide. What are you trying to say is that the -- what tesa supplies have got quite short life cycles so, therefore, it's hard to predict in the near-term? Is that what you're trying to say?

Yes, okay. This is in electronics, in the industry?

---

Just electronics, yes.

---

Not in general.

---

And how much is electronics, again, of tesa?

---

Might be 20%.

Okay. And then finally on Western Europe, you said your panels in December and, of course, early this year look healthy and I think you mentioned the word growth, 10%. So should one interpret that your start to the year is healthy?

Like you always ask, much better than my knee. But you see me smiling. We started good. I'm very happy, very happy and especially happy because Jan, Feb last year, we also run against quite some big comps. So you could argue, are they keeping the growth rate? But from the numbers -- and I'm not telling you anything, from the numbers you've seen so far, it looks pretty good. So there is a lot of work ahead of us and we also have to see what eventually our friends from competition are going to do. Okay. Nice final question, and I think that now this concludes our Q&A session. Thank you very much.

5687431.transcript_text1:
Thank you. Welcome to this telephone conference on the occasion of H&M's first quarter results 2014. I have our CFO, Jyrki Tervonen, here with me, and we'll be happy to answer questions after the presentation. You'll find the presentation slides to this telephone conference on hm.com. 
Please look at the slide, First Quarter 2014. H&M group sales were good in the first quarter and we kept on taking market share. Sales, including VAT, amounted to SEK 37.5 billion, an increase of 13% in a market still affected by challenging macroeconomic conditions in many countries. In local currencies, the increase was 12%. Gross profit increased 13% to SEK 17.6 billion, corresponding to a gross margin of 54.9% compared to 55.2% a year ago. Markdowns in relation to sales increased marginally compared to Q1 2013. 
The overall market situation for external factors, such as cotton prices, the U.S. dollar and cost inflation, was more or less neutral for sourcing to Q1 compared to last year. Looking at the sourcing period through the second quarter 2014, the market situation for the external factors remained more or less neutral to slightly negative. Cost inflation increased towards the end of the sourcing period. 
Cost control in the H&M group remains very good. In the first quarter costs in comparable stores decreased slightly compared to the same quarter last year, both in absolute terms and as a share of sales. 
SG&A increased by 13% to SEK 14.2 billion in the first quarter. The increase is entirely related to our expansion and substantial long-term investments in IT and online as well as the broadening of the product range and the establishment of the new fashion brand, & Other Stories. 
Among other things, the increased investments made it possible to open H&M's online store in France already on the 13th of March. Our long-term investments are very important as they are aimed at further strengthening our market position and securing future expansion. These long-term investments will continue, and in 2014, costs will be at a higher level than in 2013. During 2014, these costs may be divided unequally between the quarters. As Q1 is H&M's smallest quarter, the cost increase has a higher percentage impact on profits in Q1 than in the other quarters of the year. 
Operating profit increased by 9% to SEK 3.4 billion. Excluding the long-term investments, the profit increase would have been 14%. Operating margin was 10.6% compared to 11%. 
Profit after financial items increased by 8% to SEK 3.5 billion. After a tax rate of 24%, net profit increased to SEK 2.6 billion, equaling earnings per share of SEK 1.60, up from SEK 1.49. 
And now for some other key figures, please turn to the slide, Key Data. Stock-in-trade as of the 28th of February amounted to SEK 15.9 billion, an increase of 15% in SEK and 14% in local currencies. The increase is mainly explained by the expansion in stores and online. The level and composition of the stock-in-trade are considered good. 
Cash flow from current operations was SEK 2.7 billion compared to SEK 3.8 billion a year ago. The main explanation is higher tax payments in the quarter. 
Investments in terms of CapEx totaled SEK 1.6 billion. And for the full year, we expect CapEx of between SEK 9 billion and SEK 9.5 billion at today's exchange rates. 
The financial position of the group remained strong. Liquid funds amounted to SEK 18.2 billion. And return on equity was 37.2% rolling 12 months compared to 36.3%. 
And now, some words on H&M's expansion. Please turn to the slide, Expansion. The global expansion of the H&M Group continues. In the first quarter, we opened a net of 60 new stores. And at the end of the quarter, the total number of stores was 3,192 in 53 countries, all brands included. For 2014, we plan to open around 375 stores -- new stores net within our expansion target of increasing the number of stores by 10% to 15% per year. China and the U.S. are again expected to be the largest expansion markets. Later today, for example, the first -- the very first H&M store in Hawaii will open. It's a flagship store in the best location in Waikiki, Honolulu. We see room for continued expansion in other existing markets and in new markets. In 2014, we will open more H&M flagship stores than last year. Planned locations include, for example, East Nanjing Road in Shanghai and Weinstrasse in Munich. In New York, where we opened a spectacular H&M store in Times Square recently, 2 more flagship stores are planned to open this year on Fifth Avenue and Herald Square. 
Next week, on the 5th of April, Australia will become a new market for H&M with the opening of a flagship store in Melbourne. It will be a 3-level store in the historical General Post Office building, which is a real landmark in Melbourne. 
In the second half of the year, the Philippines and India will also become new H&M markets with openings planned in Manila and Delhi. 
Next year, expansion will continue in the Southern Hemisphere. We will open the first H&M store in Lima in Peru and the first store in South Africa. 
Expansion continues also for the newer brands of the group like COS, & Other Stories, Monki, Weekday and Cheap Monday, as well as H&M Home. COS has over 90 stores in more than 20 markets and a very good performance. Last year, COS opened around 20 new stores and at least as many are planned for this year. New markets for COS this year will be Australia, the U.S. with stores both in New York and Los Angeles, and South Korea, as well as Switzerland, which opened in February. 
& Other Stories develops very well with 8 stores to date and at least the same number will be added in 2014. & Other Stories will also open in new markets: the U.S., Belgium and the Netherlands. Both COS and Stories will launch online sales in the U.S. in 2014, and Austria and Ireland will become new online markets for Stories. 
We also extended our sports range, H&M Sport. Please turn to the next slide. We have a strong offering, and we are constantly working to further develop and broaden our product range. One example is the updated H&M Sport range, which has been very well received by customers. The new H&M Sport is available in selected stores in 18 markets and online. Continued rollout to more stores and countries is planned, as well as further broadening of the sports range. 
Our brands reach more and more customers, and we are expanding H&M's online presence to more markets globally. Please turn to the slide, H&M Online. Following the successful start of H&M's online store in the U.S. last year, we launched Shop Online in France this March. Initial reception by our customers has been very good, and the global rollout continues. Next in line will be Spain and Italy, early autumn, and we also plan to open H&M online in China at the end of 2014. 
And now, before we start the Q&A session, just a few comments to summarize. If we look at current trading, sales increased 12% in local currencies from 1st to 25th March compared to the same period last year. And looking ahead, we still have respect for the macroeconomic situation that remains challenging in many markets. But we are optimistic about the future for the H&M group with many great collections, a strong market position and great potential for continued expansion. We keep investing long term to strengthen the position of the group even further. 
And with that, we are now happy to take your questions. [Operator Instructions]

5687431.transcript_text3:
I had -- I was wondering, on the comparable store development for SG&A, which was down this year in absolute terms and I believe it was down last year again so it's been very, very controlled there. How do you look at that going forwards assuming positive like-for-like growth on the sales line? How should we look at that development?

---

That's correct, they were slightly down in comparable stores in Q1 and also I think last year as well. In the long term, of course, it's hard to always come down in comparable stores. Of course, we are working to trying to find efficiencies in the store operations, but of course, in the long run with the underlying cost inflation, et cetera, so we of course need positive like-for-like development.

---

And are there any particular initiatives you're taking there to have that impressive development at the moment?

---

There are a lot of initiatives in the stores. And of course, as we have said previously, we are looking to better tools for planning our sales and staffing the hours in a more correct way that we don't make, so to say, easy mistakes trying to find the calendar effect, et cetera. So we are working and trying to find new tools to help the stores to plan better. And also in different areas for electricity consumption, we are looking in how to be more efficient in the consumption because the prices are increasing in many countries. So there are, of course, a lot of different initiatives that we are constantly working on in our daily operations.

---

So question on the OpEx impact, please. I mean, it obviously looks like it was around SEK 170 million in Q1 in terms of the impact from the long-term growth investments. I mean, I just wondered whether we should expect the full year impact to be around 4x that? Or will the impact reduce in the coming quarters in terms of an absolute amount, as well as a percentage of sales.

---

Yes, as we said, in connection with Q4, the long-term investments during 2014 will be on a higher level than 2013 and our best estimate for the full year is that it will be in the range of SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million on a yearly level. But always to remember that can differ from quarter-to-quarter and also the impact, of course, is higher in a small quarter like Q1 compared maybe to Q2 or Q4. But that's our best estimate. And as you know, all bigger projects, there are so many dependencies so it can vary, but best estimate on a yearly level is SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million.

---

Okay, great. And just one more, please. On the China online launch, why is that taking place after the launches in Spain and Italy? What additional steps need to be taken to start online in the China market?

---

For every online launch, there's a lot of adaptions to each country. And obviously, since we now have France up and running and some other countries within EU, it's much easier to launch in Spain and Italy, which are in the EU. China is, of course, very different in very many aspects and therefore more complex.

---

This is Vick Mohan in for Omar. So wondering if you could you talk a bit about the competitive landscape globally and if you see new competition affecting your business in any region.

---

Yes, I think, in general, fashion apparel is perhaps one of the most competitive industries in the world to start with, and I think competition is always, by default, getting stronger and stronger because everyone wants to improve. But at the same time, of course, there are new competitors coming aboard and developing well and there are others who have problems so -- and it varies, of course, from market to market. So that's the reason why -- I mean, since there is -- it's so tough competition, we can never relax and sit still. It's always about improving things. Constant improvement is one of the most important values in H&M.

---

And secondly, do you see, kind of the promotionality that affected your gross margins a bit, do you see that continuing this year or subsiding and leveling off a bit?

---

It's very difficult to say because it varies from market to market, but I mean, we are present today in more than -- in 53 countries, and of course, we have to adjust to the prevailing marketing conditions everywhere. And if you start with the U.S., I mean, it has been extremely intensive last year with promotions and markdown activities and of course we have to respond to that.

---

Against the SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million longer-term investment expected for this year, would you expect a similar sort of envelope for next year? Or should that level of investment start to fade as of 2015?

---

What we can say about 2015, the long-term investments will still be on a high level, but exactly the amount, that we have to come back to in connection maybe in the full year report. But these investments, they are not only here and now, they will continue and also going more and more to omni-channel. We have to also update our technology in the stores, et cetera, et cetera. So our estimate is that they will remain on a high level in 2015 as well. But we have to remember that a lot of those initiatives that we have taken or taking now, they will also start to generate revenues and some of them already have, but not maybe in full scale. So of course, in the long term, these investments are aimed to generate revenues and bottom line. So we see them as very important.

---

All right. And secondly, could you just develop slightly your commentary vis--vis a pickup in sourcing cost inflation as of the end of second quarter. What sort of areas are you seeing? Where are you seeing that inflation coming through?

---

Well, actually, we think this is positive because it's something we've been actively pushing for, especially in countries like Bangladesh and Cambodia, for sustainability reasons and we see that increased salaries there leads to better stability and more sustainable situation, of course, so that's actually very positive.

---

And I also think -- yes, sorry. And I also think this is becoming more and more important for our customers. I think if you don't do these important investments, I think that will be a mistake. I think everybody of us, me and most probably all of us, are going into that direction, understand the necessity of thinking sustainable in all areas in life. So I think that's also very, very important aspect to have in mind.

---

I see. So the inflation is coming through from the wage inflation, right?

---

Primarily, yes.

---

Yes. And I'm sorry, just to confirm then because the dollar is at sort of $1.38 or whatever to the euro right now, so you're not seeing that as a benefit to offset some of this wage inflation or...

---

It's definitely in the short term a positive, absolutely. But the total picture of all these external factors are becoming more negative. But that is not the same as saying that the margins will go down because that's a totally different thing as we've said many, many times before. It's of course up to us how we handle it and how we work with them and of course how we position ourselves and work with the customer offering.

---

My question's actually about some of the new and more geographically distant markets that you're entering this year and in the coming years. Can you talk a little bit about how you're handling distribution for those markets and logistics? Are you starting to build distribution centers for them now? Are you fulfilling from other locations? And how are you thinking about that in the long term?

---

Well, one of the views about continuing to grow with the same pace every year is that you gradually build up a logistic infrastructure. So for us, it's not a big thing. Of course, it's a lot of work to set up a new country, but we have now a lot of good experience, good people and good processes in order to scale this up to country-to-country -- next country to next country and we have already a setup, as you know, in the Southern Hemisphere and we are scaling this up. So it's nothing dramatic.

---

My question on the investments there, the SEK 170 million for this quarter and the continuation in the rest of the year, does this include investing in your click-and-collect capability? And can you remind us where you offer click-and-collect? If I remember well you do not offer that yet in the U.S. Any plans there?

---

It's interesting that you mentioned. One, I mean there are a lot of different things included in these long-term investments where it's primarily IT and online, but it's also, just to remind you, the & Other Stories and H&M Sport, et cetera. And of course, we are investing in platform-related IT questions but also in expansion to set up organization and staff, et cetera. And of course in improving the features like click-and-collect could be one of them. But it's not just that, of course not.

---

But do you plan to offer click and collect in the U.S. anytime soon?

---

I mean, as I said, at any given point of time, there are lots of different features that we want to improve and click-and-collect is one of them, but I can't tell you when or if it's going to be.

---

Okay. All right. One more question, please, if I may then. In terms of -- a little bit more short term-ish this one, I'm afraid. In terms of your March sales, the one that you've reported there, should we be aware of any calendar effects? And how do you see calendar effects progress into next month because of the difference in Easter from year-to-year in March and April. Maybe you could help us understand how this could deviate.

---

Sure. Again, Easter is very difficult to quantify. But it's true that now, this week, right now, we are meeting last year's Easter week. And so I would say that it is a slight negative effect this year. I mean, the calendar impact is slightly negative. But it's important always to look at March, April and I would say May, together, because you have these -- every year, you have shifts of these holidays like Easter and other holidays and also when -- the spring weather is very volatile as well. So when you look at our monthly figures some years back, they are very volatile. And just to remind you, it seems like last year it was a weak month, but it was upon a very strong 2012. I think we increased 24%, 26% or something. So yes, to summarize, you should look at the 3 months together.

---

Okay. So that means that then even April that looks extremely -- that looks relatively strong last year, if we see it on a 2-month or even 3-month basis, then potentially it was not as weak last year so potentially we could expect a bit of spillover into April from March. Is that what you're implying?

---

I didn't quite follow you there.

---

No. I mean, in terms of because you said that March last year wasn't as weak as it looked, should we then assume that also April year last wasn't as strong as it looked?

---

Well, yes, of course, it goes in both ways. And if I said -- I also said that the Easter week we are facing now is a slight negative and will be reversed, so a slight positive in April, of course.

---

The first question I have is on these long-term project costs -- the SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million. Can I just be clear that, that is incremental growth in long-term cost spend, the SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million versus last year? So in aggregate, what is that level of spend, first question.

---

We prefer not to aggregate the total long-term investment there. We think that we are making a huge investments, but we prefer not to exactly quantify the aggregate amount of investment. But we wanted to give you a better guidance of what we're talking about for 2014 compared to 2013 and then our best estimate is that the increase will be around SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million during this year compared to last year.

---

That is very helpful. And the second question on cost is, were the -- was the FX impact on your operating costs very similar to the impact on sales? You used to give [ph]...

---

Yes, they increased 12% in local currencies.

---

Fantastic. And then on inventory. You described the composition and level of inventory as good. I think that's the first quarter in about 6 or 7 that you've been able to use that adjective. Does that mean that there's a chance that we could start to see markdown recover from here? I mean, you have just a multi-year soft comp at the markdown level.

---

It's far too early. We are beginning of the season, so it's far. But of course, if we continue to have a strong development in the top line and then of course our aim is also to be more efficient than better when it comes to markdowns. But yes, let's see. It's far too early. It's still 2 strong months ahead of us and we don't know how the turnover development will be.

---

Understood. And sorry, one final cheeky question. The contribution from net new space and net new online stores to revenue, was that similar in Q1 to Q4? Suppose a marketing factor [ph]. What was the like-for-like? You used to disclose it.

---

The like-for-like in the quarter was positive, but we don't quantify the exact number.

---

Just one simple question for me. In terms of the gross margin, is there a difference between different geographies on the gross margins? So is there a -- as your geographic mix changes, is there any sort of geographic mix shift, either upwards or downwards in the gross margin that we should be thinking about?

---

Of course, there are slight differences between the different countries but no major, and starting from the customer offering, our price spread between different countries is actually, I would say, very small and smaller compared to most peers. So no, there isn't any simple pattern for geographical reasons depending on our expansion, no.

---

And if you were to overlay the markdown that you've seen over the last couple of years on top of that pretty standard gross margin, does that make a large difference in gross margin by territory post markdown?

---

Could you repeat again, please? I'm trying to understand what you're aiming at.

---

Once you -- is your level of markdown primarily in a certain number of countries?

---

Okay, I got you. It's of course depending from country to country, but it varies over time due to competition and how much we have bought, et cetera. So again, there is no simple pattern in that and it's not focused on a certain -- a few countries. It's spread pretty evenly across the group.

---

Just one more on these long-term investments, if that's okay. I'm just wondering when we're thinking about the costs of going in here, particularly with those related to the launch of online, are these costs that you very much consider to be one-off that once an online store has launched and if we look a few years forward once all of your global online stores have launched, these costs drop out? Or are any way these costs related to kind of just the ongoing running costs of having an online offer?

---

Some of the costs are, of course, one-off, but a lot of those costs will still be taken when we open up Spain and Italy and China. And also when looking at the different cost structure, comparing normal retailing compared to online, of course, the cost structure is quite different. It's so much more IT-intense when opening up an online store. So they will, of course, still be generating costs but also generating top line and bottom line in the future. But it's important to maybe stress that it's not only technical solutions that is driving costs. One should maybe think that this is one huge, big store where we need people for merchandising the goods, we need a logistic chain. So there are, of course, a lot of different, different additional costs that is connected to launching a new online market. So I don't know if that was a clear answer to your question, but some of them, of course, are one-offs but there are still investments and costs to come.

---

Okay. No, that's very useful. In terms of if we do think about this, therefore, as one big store as you say, over what kind of period of time does it take to get kind of leverage out of that big store? How do you expect that to flow through as these online businesses kind of gather pace in those key markets?

---

It's very difficult to tell you, but, I mean, the reason why we invest so much in this is, of course, that we see it's very, very interesting and it's going very fast now. So we see that the multichannel strategy is very interesting. To have the store network in combination with online and a strong brand is very, very important than exactly when the payoff is not that interesting. Because before you get the scale, the volume and et cetera, you have to have the platform, the organization, you have to have the people, but you don't get the full scale revenue and profitability in the beginning. So of course, when it's up and running, of course, then it's going to more normal operation, then it's not a long-term investment. And also when looking at, for instance, our new formats, for instance, & Other Stories, of course, we have been opening 8 stores last year, planning to open at least 8 this year as well. But before we have the volume, before we have the full economies of scale, the bottom line is, of course, not on that level that we want to have it in the long run. So you can also classify that, that it's a long-term investment before we are up in that volume and the economies of scale when it's really going to benefit and give a bottom line that we are expecting in the long run. So in a way, the stores are in normal operation, but you are not there in full scale where you want to be. So in a way, that, of course, you can classify that as well, that's a long-term investment.

---

: Fraser Ramzan (Analysts)
Right. But you wouldn't do that for an H&M store, for example, would you, although presumably most of those do not drag on margin when you first open them.

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
Exactly, exactly. You're correctly right. It's totally different to open up one additional H&M store compared to open up a new format.

---

: Fraser Ramzan (Analysts)
But a new H&M country might drag on your margin, though. Would that go in long-term investments?

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
Yes, exactly. That could be, but we don't. We don't call that for H&M. There, we have a much better foundation in the group to take care of a new country. In smaller formats, we don't have maybe that broad, broad base. But for opening up a new H&M country, of course, it will have a lot of start-up costs, for sure.

---

: Fraser Ramzan (Analysts)
Right. So I apologize hogging the phone here. So with your investments being SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million incremental in the current year, that, on my calculations, is about 0.5 percentage point drag to your operating margin as a business and that will be sort of in addition to whatever else you might achieve as a business. Because I think we all get a little confused between absolute percent to sales here when you talk about it.

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
Yes, for this year, if you have been calculating. But we have to see next year on what level we will have these long-term investments increase compared to 2014. But yes, as you said, you can see it as this will be affecting the EBIT if it's landing SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million, that, of course, will give that affect.

---

: Andreas Lundberg (Analysts)
Andreas Lundberg with ABG Stockholm. Can I ask you about the Q1 leverage here? ---

: Nils Vinge (Executives)
No, not really. I mean, there was a slight positive like-for-like, absolutely, but there's not much leverage on that because you always have inflation increases, et cetera. So the increase is all about the expansion in stores and online and these long-term investments. That's exactly why we decided to quantify them to show that on the running business, we have 100% control and it's doing very well.

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
And to add in, they are according to our plan. So we have planned for this increase in the cost OpEx, so it's no surprise for us.

---

: Andreas Lundberg (Analysts)
Could I ask you on your sourcing costs because they were structurally much higher today given your increased focus on sustainability?

---

: Nils Vinge (Executives)
I would say, yes, of course, we invest a lot in sustainability but it also pays off. So it's a win-win, I would say.

---

: Geoff Lowery (Analysts)

---

: Nils Vinge (Executives)
No, it doesn't.

---

: Simon Bowler (Analysts)
It's back on the old topic, on the SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million. Just looking to understand how you calculated that number, so if I was to use the new store analogy, one could calculate that cost from considering just the start-up costs or you could consider the start-up costs and the net trading performance of that new store. How did you come to that SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million?

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
Yes, it's according -- when we are looking at the investments we have done, and remember, this is not only the online and IT investment, there are also a lot of other connected costs that we are taking forward for development, our existing assortment, et cetera. But we have purely looked into our budgets and plans, what we are planning to do during the year and how that will affect our cost increase in those specific areas that we are classifying as long-term investments and that is some of the IT projects that we are classifying long-term investments online, online expansion to new countries to build up the new platform and also looking into broadening our existing offer. Those is purely that we are looking how much we need in staffing up the organization, how much adaptions we have to do in existing technology and assistance, et cetera, and then we adapt in this amount. It's simple as that.

---

: Simon Bowler (Analysts)
Okay. So there's no kind of net trading performance within there. So if opening up online is initially loss-making, for example, then the kind of net loss wouldn't be included in that figure?

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
No, no.

---

: Nicklas Fhrm (Analysts)
Could I ask you on online versus physical store rollouts. Given your longer-term guidance and hopes to grow by 10% to 15% per annum, in the case that the online channel actually even in your business plan achieves basically the same penetration as in several of the markets that you operate in, would you still open up the same amount of physical stores to fulfill the long-term guidance range?

---

: Nils Vinge (Executives)
We still see huge potential to open up physical stores despite the fact that online and e-commerce is growing. So I mean, 10% to 15% is a number we feel that we can grow, we can keep for many years. And as long as we can do that, with continued high profitability and quality, we will continue. But of course, somewhere in the future, I'm sure that we need to slow down, or I mean, online, et cetera, will change the picture. But as of today, no -- no changes.

---

: Nicklas Fhrm (Analysts)
Would you care to leverage on where that threshold lies? Do you think you -- let's say that you derive 5% of your total group revenue from online sales or 10%, would that, do you think, change the rollout of actual physical stores?

---

: Nils Vinge (Executives)
I don't think it's that simple. There are so many other things in the total equation. And I mean, just to remind you, we've had online sales in Sweden for many, many years and we still add new stores because there is a need for it in some places still. 
Any more questions, please? If not, I would say I would like to thank you all very much for participating in this conference call, and we'll come back for the 6 months' results on the 18th of June.

---

: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)
Are there any more questions?

---

: Nils Vinge (Executives)
No. I just said since there were no questions, again, I repeat, thank you very much for participating, and we'll come back for the 6 months' results in the 18th of June. Goodbye.
