6192150.eventHeadline: China Overseas Land & Investment Ltd., 2013 Earnings Call, Mar 13, 2014
6192150.transcript_text1:
[Chinese] Hong Kong investors to the 2013 annual results press conference -- annual results announcement for China Overseas Land & Investment Limited. We have Hao Jian Min in the center, who is the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; next to him, Mr. Xiao Xiao, Vice Chairman; and then, Mr. Chen, Yi Executive Director; to the far left, our Executive Director and CFO, Mr. Horace Nip; next to me, Mr. [indiscernible] Sung, Investors Relations Officer. 
Mr. Hao will take us through the performance of 2013.

---

I'm delighted to be able to meet with you here. I would like to thank you for your long-term support for the company, and I would also want to say hello to those watching our webcast. 
Today, I'm going to focus on 4 areas in my presentation. I will try my best to shorten the time so that there will be more time left to make exchanges with you.  So I want to thank you again for your support. 
First of all, I would like to take us through the annual results for 2013. For 2013, we realized turnover of HKD 82.47 billion, year-on-year growth of 27.7%. Together with the turnover of our JV corporations, the total amount is HKD 100.47 billion, year-on-year growth of 29%. Profit attributable to shareholders, HKD 23.04 billion, growth of 23.1%. And the core net profit increased by 20% to HKD 18.96 billion. We have realized the annual net profit rate of 27.9%. Excluding security housing and the 3 repo projects, it is 35.1%. EPS totaled HKD 0.82, a growth of 23.1%. We proposed a final dividend per share of HKD 0.29. Total dividend for the year, HKD 0.47, an increase of 20.5%. 
The next chart is about the growth of funds of our shareholders which increased by 26% to HKD 109.97 billion. And the net asset value per share, HKD 13.5; the return at 23.4%. 
By the end of the year, we had cash HKD 41.48 billion; total long-term debt, HKD 69.4 billion. Net gearing ratio slightly increased to 28.4%. We continue to realize a rate that was lower than 40%, sustaining our financial viability. 
Next, we can see the segment results highlights. During the period, we realized turnover for the property development segment, HKD 78.62 billion, which was 95% of our total figure, a growth of 28%. For the rental income, it increased to HKD 857 million, an increase of 46.5%. For the development segment, we realized a profit of HKD 27.32 billion, an increase of 8.6%. Investment portion, HKD 4.2 billion, increase of 1.4%. 
And you can see some financing situation. From 2013, we obtained for the first time from Fitch, BBB+ investment rating. We were also readjusted to BBB+ and Baa1 by S&P and Moody's. So once again, our viability is very well recognized. 
In October last year, we successfully issued security notes of maturity of 5, 10 and 30 years. Total amount USD 1.5 billion, and the interest rates were 3.375%, 5.375% and 6.375%, respectively. So it was another round of successful launch of long-term debt providing more assurance concerning our long-term development. 
This is a chart showing financial resources and debt structure. Cash at hand, HKD 41.48 billion, 9.6% was Hong Kong dollars and 15.2% was U.S. dollars, and the remaining, renminbi. Together with HKD 8.76 billion undrawn bank facility, the total usable resources was HKD 50.24 billion. 95% of our debt is long-term, and you can see this further optimizes our debt structure. Corporate debt, HKD 32.69 billion; bank loans, HKD 40 billion. 42.3% is Hong Kong dollars, 45.7% in U.S. dollars, and 12% in renminbi.
Next, we shall look at the business review of 2013. For the whole year, contracted sales achieved HKD 138.52 billion; GFA sold 9.234 million square meters. If you look at different districts, for the Mainland part, contracted sales was HKD 136.94 billion. For the outer delta region, HKD 43.99 billion, making the greatest contribution to the group. The corresponding figure for Hong Kong and Macau was HKD 1.58 billion. Receivables exceeded HKD 124.4 billion. 
For the first 2 months of the year, you can see some figures. I have already disclosed this information. The realized contracted sales HKD 24.32 billion, and subscription of HKD 7.79 billion, about to be confirmed in the coming months. Next, you can see projects completed in 2013. The group completed 35 fresh projects and JV completed 10, total of 8.39 million square meters. And according to our calculation, we have already sold 84.4% and 72.6% of saleable GFA for the group and the JV, which is very satisfactory. 
Next, completed inventory. Total GFA 1.34 million square meters, which is at a very healthy level. Next chart, property and booked for 2013. Booked GFA, 7.32 million square meters. Total value, HKD 111.1 billion by the end of the year for our JV projects. 4.35 million square meters have been presold. For the next chart, our land acquisitions. In 2013, 24 lots have been added to our reserve, covering Beijing, Shanghai and Xi'an. Total GFA 12.11 million square meters. Equity premium, HKD 42.58 billion. 
This is the situation for 2014. Beginning from the year until now, we have acquired 7 lots. GFA, 5.285 million square meters; equity premium, HKD 17.57 billion. This is the total landbank situation. In 2013, we have entered for the first time, [indiscernible] Harbin, Fuzhou and Wuxi. In 2014, we entered Zhengzhou. So we have entered 32 first and second tier cities, together with the 14 first tier cities covered by COGO, we have been covering 46 cities. 
Next chart, investment property situation. By the end of last year, we have total GFA of 2.6 million square meters and 2 million loaned to commercial properties, taking up 77%. Under operation, 600,000 square meters. Rental situation is very good, covering Hong Kong, Beijing and Chengdu offices and also the Unipark in Jinan. We're talking about over 90% of occupancy rate. And the rental rate has increased. The rental income has increased to HKD 857 million, a growth of 46.5%. 
The next section is about the macro situation. In 2013, as you can see in the chart, these are some economic outlook for China, and I believe that you already have such information, so I won't go through them in great details. The growth came down to 7.7%, but the economic structure is actually more healthy. So the fundamentals are very stable. In the future, urbanization, industrialization will continue. There could be some uncertainties and difficulties, but we trust that the overall quality of our economy will continue to improve with stable growth. 
Next, you probably are very concerned about liquidity in the financial market. I trust that you have done a lot of analysis already and therefore, I will not go through the details. Basically, I just have a brief conclusion. We see very stable and healthy fundamentals for fiscal policy and the increase of m2 have slowed down to 13%. So there will be slowing down of loan balances, but it is more than sufficient to support the realization of the annual GDP growth of 7.5%. Taking on with the Golden 10 rules being issued, commercial banks will be more prudent in allocation of their credits. So overall development of the market will be very stable and well balanced. This chart is again about liquidity. As we all know, with the speeding up of the reform measures of the financial system in China, there will be more stringent supervision. So perhaps there will be some fluctuations in 2014. There would be some defaults leading to the possibility of accidental tightening. But there will be a return of the normal situation very quickly. 
Concerning overseas markets, many advanced countries have been improving in terms of their economic situation, and there is capital inflow again. The appreciation of renminbi and also the interest spread will not go through fundamental changes in the shorter term. 
Next, investment and financing management. You can see some measures we have implemented and also advantages enjoyed by the group. The centralized fund management, we have a dedicated committee responsible for the allocation of funds, so that we are actively responding to any possible risk and changes in the liquidity market. We have a dual platform which continues to be very effective, ensuring healthy flow of funds, and it is sufficient to support our future investment and development. 
This chart, it is about dividends of urbanization and the contribution to GDP growth rate. I'm sure you have plenty of such information so I won't go into any details. 
We are experiencing this great opportunity presented by urbanization. For a very long term, this is going to provide new economic growth point. There will continue to be investment need for infrastructure, public facilities and housing. Third tier cities will continue to benefit from the growth of population, and first and second tier cities will also continue to benefit in terms of industry upgrades and improving of environmental quality. So concentration of population will lead to improvement of living quality, especially it will be reflected in the added value to property sector of the first and second tier cities. 
Next, some statistics concerning the property market in the past decade and some outlook information. You will see very stable growth concerning the volume of sales and the price of property. Together with further economic development and urbanization measures, we believe that the 1 billion square meter level will be sustained per year in terms of supply of residential units. We believe that the increase of supply has to be supported by the increase of sales investment. In different places, there could be different structures, so in the future, first and second tier cities will continue to see more or less an equilibrium in the supply and demand structures. 
This chart is about our value chain. Some previous practices. Again, I won't go into the details because I trust that you already know about our past, so I don't want to be very repetitive. 
The final part, guidance and strategy. I trust that you're very concerned about this. So I will tell you some details now. You can see our target for 2014. We would like to sustain 20% growth of our net profit. In terms of completion, we will sustain a very stable progress so that we can control our cost within reasonable limits. 10 million square meters to be completed, plenty of projects. GFA will be 12 million. Contracted sales, we will continue to focus on our target of HKD 148 billion. 
I trust that you will ask about this, so I just wanted to provide you with the answer now. Saleable resources, HKD 220 billion. 
We will not casually acquire land without careful considerations. Newly added land reserve, about 10 million square meters; CapEx, HKD 110 billion. HKD 50 billion will go into the newly acquired land. For different projects, HKD 46 billion. Another HKD 14 billion are to be payments for previously acquired land lots. 
This is the final chart. You can see the breakdown for property to be completed because of some requests we have received. You wanted some further breakdowns according to different regions. Anyway, we're happy to disclose this. In Hua Nan, Hua Dong, Northern, Hua Bei, Western and Hong Kong and Macau, you can see the GFA completion targets.  Hopefully, this is more convenient for you to do your calculation analysis. 
So basically, I have taken you through everything. We will now take questions from you. Thank you.

We'll now move on to Q&A. For those who have questions, please raise your hand.

---

I have a question for Mr. Hao. It seems like the macro situation, your review is quite cautious. So we just looked at the guidance in terms of sales. Are we too conservative? What about cash expenses? You seem more proactive. If you look at land acquisition, the money involved has increased by 27%. In construction expenses, another increase of 27%. So Mr. Hao, considering sales and expenses, why is there such a discrepancy? In terms of our finances last year, concerning sales absorption rate, and what about on the return of our cash? Final question, on Page 1, gross profit rate, security housing and some other projects have been excluded. So concerning the security housing, is it because in 2013, the ratio of security housing compared to in the previous years, it was quite big, that is why you excluded that portion?

---

Can we know where you're from?

---

I'm from Credit Suisse.

---

I think Horace will provide some answers about the financial figures, and I will take the other questions. First of all, I want to thank you for supporting our macro projection. When it comes to sales and expenses, I would like to tell you 2 things. Traditionally, I'm sure you already know this, that we are always on the conservative side or we're in the middle. Today, I feel it is very versatile and different factors can affect it. That is the situation of the industry. So any across-the-board concepts or comments would not mean much to me. And about the turning point or is it going to crash next year or good performance next year, they were not that meaningful in the past decades. We focused on fundamental demand. For example, you have heard that we tried to resolve fundamental housing needs. After the development of more than a decade, how many property companies existed in the market 10 years ago? What was the total sales level? Compare that to today's situation. You will see that the situation is totally different. So diversification in the market is unavoidable. And it may happen any time. My understanding is, as an enterprise, we should pay more attention to your own resources and your capability. When I attend internal meeting, I said the following, "We should pay more attention to the opportunities in the market". What is the level of capability of your management and operational philosophies? You should pay attention on micro things. If you'll continue to focus on the macro level, we can no longer see anything like a property developer who will always make a profit. That era is over in every corner of the city in different regions. You are facing very fierce and direct competition. It will only become more keen. Two years ago, I also shared with you my liking of fluctuations and different situations. Otherwise, you cannot tell the good from the bad. It is not surprising. I think you should divert your attention to larger areas of concern. Perhaps my concerns are different from your concerns because I have adopted this analysis from the corporate perspective. I wonder, you have seen the figures, the 300 million. The first 100 million is about urbanization. We have seen a migration of village population into various cities. The 100 million people moving into cities will continue to have demand for housing. So we need policies to support this movement. And then, our renovation or refurbishment will cover another 100 million. That is creating a lot of pressure to different cities. I think this morning, our Premier talked about removing poverty zones. This is something that we must proceed with. So the 100 million living in poverty regions, they will also be relocated to other cities, presenting us with more opportunities. The last 100 million, we're talking about the movement of people from Western regions to the Eastern regions. So if you put all these figures together, you would understand that these are unprecedented opportunities. People used to say the overseas markets are performing quite well. What is the growth in United States? What about Europe? Do you know? So these are the opportunities presented to us by the new round of urbanization. I still think very positively about the property industry, but can you actually leverage on the opportunities presented in the market? The property business does not necessarily mean you own a gold mine. You need to turn the oil into gold. So further diversification is inevitable, and it's only natural. The second question is about the payout ratio. We wanted to keep it at 20% or more. And for so many years, we have been upholding this payout ratio. Many of our shareholders suggested -- many shareholders said that "Pay less, develop more". So we cannot pretend we didn't hear that. So we didn't want to pay too much. If you look at the return for our shareholders, it is much better than the dividend payout, so it's only reasonable for us to not to pay out too much. So we would like to keep it at 20%. And this is one of the principles for the company. You talked about the sales question. What's that again? Oh, yes, for this year -- for last year was 6:4. This year, first half, perhaps a bit more. Maybe between 60% to 70%. For the second half, 30% to 40%. The actual split, well, it's depending on the timing of us obtaining the permits for presale. So there are many of such projects in June. So roughly speaking, 60% to 70% for the first half, 30% to 40% in second half. That is the allocation of our resources at the moment.

---

: Carol Wu (Analysts)
Mr. Hao, I'm from DBS. My name is Carol. I have 2 questions. The sales condition of the first 2 months, there's a drop compared to 2013. I don't remember seeing this historically. What is the reason? You don't have anything to sell, or you don't want to launch them yet? What is the reason for holding on to such projects? The media's saying that perhaps you cannot supply certain projects because they have not yet been completed. Can you explain the reasons? If you look at acquisition before 2012, the growth was about 1% per year. And then in 2013, there is this sudden surge. First 2 months of 2014 also very substantial land acquisition. What are the reasons driving you to fill the need to expedite land acquisition? Are you more able to sell today and, therefore, you want to acquire more land to propel faster growth? I'm just noticing some difference.

---

: Jian Min Hao (Executives)
All right. You've asked a few questions. Actually, the sales of the last 2 months, as I have shared with you, January and February in China is very special time because sometimes we have the Chinese New Year in January, sometimes we have it in February. And that affects, to a very big extent, the overall sales condition. The week or longer before Chinese New Year and 1 to 2 weeks after, people just feel bored because they don't have anything else to do. They are taking the time off work so they come to our flats to have a look. They are not real buyers. So don't feel too troubled. It doesn't really show a growth or decline. It's not a matter of holding on to a flat or property or unable to sell. This is not happening. And I can tell you what happened. We did not obtain the presale permits maybe because the price was too high or because of the Chinese New Year. So when we don't have the permits, we cannot sell. And that happened to quite a few of our projects. But in March, things will improve gradually. And then, after the 2 congresses are concluded, we'll look at some new policy directions and we'll address our strategies as well. So basically, we're not holding on to any inventory or our ability [indiscernible] or anything like that. So please don't be too concerned with a drop of 5% or 10%, it's not that meaningful. Your second question is about land acquisition. To be honest, in 2013, our target is 8 million square meters. Last year, we acquired 12.11 million. I wonder if you have looked at the breakdowns. That covered 4 projects, taking up 6 million square meters. Shenyang, Changchun, Yantai and another one in, I think, Nanjing, that international community. Just these 4 projects took up 6 million square meters. So we're talking about projects under negotiation. These are 4 mega scale projects. The Nanjing one, almost 1 million square meters. The one in Changchun, 1.2 million, 1.3 million, and then, Shenyang, 2.3 million, and Yantai a little over 1 million. The land premium is not that high. Most of them only went out 700, 800, the one in Shenyang 2,000 only. So in the past, we have used a small amount of resources to obtain very quality inventory that will support very positive growth in the future. If you look at our financial situation, as I presented, we have plenty at hand. We can buy more if we want. For example, when everyone wants to buy, we take a step back and stay calm. But I can tell you, I feel in January and February, many companies went out of cash. So the situation in Guangdong last year, well, many companies actually withdrew from the bidding process because of the lack of funds. So it is really about finding the right opportunities. So it is not about changing our operating philosophies or strategies. We are just doing what is normal. Thank you.

---

: Unknown Executive (Executives)
Thank you very much. Next question? In the middle.

---

: Brian Leung (Analysts)
I'm Brian from Morgan Stanley. First question, land acquisition. 10 million square meters to be acquired in 2014 at the value of HKD 50 billion. Are you talking about more premium land lots closer to first and second tier cities? That's the first question. Second question, the 2013 acquisition level was the highest. And then 2014 perhaps another new heights. So after 1 to 2 years of acquisition, we should be able to see huge increases in sales level. So can we expect China Overseas to sell a lot more in 2015 and beyond? That is the second question. And third question is about profit growth. According to your budgets, in 2014, the completion rate will increase by 11%, and profit will also increase. Does it mean that the profit level in 2014 will represent a very huge increase over 2013?

---

: Jian Min Hao (Executives)
Well, thank you for the questions, to be honest. Land acquisitions, yes, it was a high level. And for 2014, are we buying premium land lots? Well, all these are projections. Perhaps, we feel that there are good opportunities. And therefore, we have made the financial arrangements or even we feel that there are some very good opportunities in the market. I'm quite surprised that you saw right through us. Well, that is exactly the reason why we have made the financial arrangements. But of course, sometimes construing the kind of projection, it's a kind of guessing. So I'm hoping what you see is the same as what we see. So hopefully, it is going to be a year of very good harvest. Growth in sales and profits. Well, we talked about 20%. But in actual arrangement, we did more, or at the end, we cannot complete the projects. So I think what you're thinking is the same as what I am thinking. I will definitely reserve more. It is a kind of insurance or security. I think our judgment is very much aligned. But there are things that I cannot say but you have said them for me. Thank you.

: Unknown Executive (Executives)
Next question in the front, the third row.

: Unknown Analyst (Analysts)
I'm Oscar from [indiscernible]. Two questions. Just now, Mr. Hao mentioned the future will be very diversified. We need to look at competitiveness. In the past 2 to 3 years, some market leaders have launched strategies moving abroad or providing supporting services or they have geared towards the commercial sector. ---

: Jian Min Hao (Executives)
Thank you for the very good questions and quite difficult to answer, but I think we can make the following exchanges. Well, every person will have different views. At the press conference many reporters asked about similar questions. Network property or finance property and then another term, very liberated ideas, we're talking about people in the early 20s. There were so many terms. And I said, "You must understand what that means". They are talking to me with Internet language. Actually, we will only do what we know and what we are good at. Going overseas? How big is this market? In China, 300 million people are waiting to be housed. I'm not saying that going overseas is a bad idea. But if you're in the property sector, you must know the country, you need to know the local laws, the local customs and local people. If you want to be successful, you have to rely on these local knowledge. I know you work in multinational enterprises. Perhaps, you can help me out. I haven't heard much good news concerning with these markets. So let's just wait and see, perhaps I am more conservative. I just want to do what I'm good at and what I understand. So that is our core competitiveness. So in order to sustain stable growth, we need to minimize the risk. We must have manageable risk. And you talked about diversity just like what the reporters have said. They kept talking about the Internet. I don't really understand. I can't talk in Internet language. I just want to be careful and focus on what we truly understand. That is the direction and objective for our group. You talked about the commercial segment. Perhaps, I haven't told you much about this. Perhaps, I can disclose something. We have focused on the macro situation. In the next 5 years, we would like to take up 20% of market share. It's not empty talk. We are doing it, perhaps you don't feel it. I can share with you some figures this year: under operations, 600,000 square meters commercial space. In 2014, 650,000, and then, in 2015, 1 million and 3.8 million office space. In the coming 2 years, 2.2 million will be completed. Another 2 million-odd square meters to be completed in the following 2 or 3 years. We have been doing something that covers 2 directions of development, so we want to continue to walk on 2 legs. Commercial property is like having a daughter. Many developers have been focusing on the commercial segment with too much focus sometimes. You need to consider all the different elements. Otherwise in the future, it will become your burden. It will eat into your financial resources, and you cannot get rid of them. When you develop and accumulate to a certain level, when it becomes a burden, it will become a huge burden and you will be truly terrified. We don't want to go down that path. We want to be stable in our growth. We want to only create good property with good return. Right now, the rental to cost ratio is about 15%. Within 10 years, we need to break even and we can achieve that. The practical life is 70%. If you cannot break even in 10 years, you cannot make any good profit. So commercial property has taken up a healthy portion of about 20% of our total business. You talked about capital injection, I have already disclosed everything that I am permitted to. So it's not me refusing to tell you. Sometimes, we need time for the different departments to complete the funding [ph] procedures. So in terms of capital and technical support, we have been receiving them from our mother company in a continuous manner. So it just takes time. Please believe us. We would like to complete the deals as quickly as possible. Do you want me to go slowly? Does anyone want us to go slowly? No? Then we will move ahead. But it doesn't mean we can control the speed. Perhaps, we need 3 years for a certain contract. When can we actually complete them? When I have something that can be disclosed, I will tell you right away. So I have to ask you to wait. Is it going to be 1 year, 1.5 years? You also talked about our mother company in other aspects. Perhaps I can invite the chairman of the mother company to join us one day and you can just listen to him. I can only tell you that our mother company has provided great support to us. So I will try to invite him over next time. See if you can get anything out of him instead, okay? Thank you.

---

: Unknown Executive (Executives)
Thank you. Next question?

---

: Jian Min Hao (Executives)
There was another question, about COGO. Yes, I totally forgot. I'm sorry, it wasn't intentional. I really just forgot. Beginning from the day of acquisition of COGO, COLI has been seeing it as an effective extension of our business in terms of branding and also performance growth. I've already talked about this in the past. COGO is getting a lot of support from COLI. We only have a handful of companies while others may have dozens of companies because we want to be deeply rooted in where we belong. Many changes will continue to take place in the property industry. In a mature and sophisticated enterprise, sustaining very good growth, we'll have to think about what it is good at. How to maximize your resources, utilization. That may be different in different cities, and it may be different for different projects. Gradually, you will feel what I am saying. They could be 2 companies of similar scale and reserve, and in the same city they may have very different performance. We were talking about Hangzhou in January. I can tell you the story. The company cutting prices. They sold the property. They obtained the money, they bid for another also in the same city three days later. It was in the same city, but different districts, different projects. So to be more straightforward, if you want to be successful, you cannot keep making the same mistakes. Otherwise, it's almost impossible to sustain growth or good performance. The error rates cannot be over 10%, otherwise your performance would be affected. So I would like to ask you how many companies can actually keep it at 10%? COGO has seen -- COLI has seen COGO as a very important extension of our business. But since no reporters are here, we can talk about whether COLI wants to sell it. How is that possible? We said so. It's developing so well. I remember last year, I told you, I'm very delighted that they really understand how to survive and develop in a third tier city. They have really found a way. We need different methodologies and different concepts for different places. Some other companies, they want to do this city and tomorrow they want to shift to another city. They don't even know what they are doing. Their performance will suffer. We're talking about development in different regions with a separation of more than 10 years. So I suppose I have already answered the last of your question without violating the Hong Kong Exchanges rules. Anymore questions? Well, I can tell you we will continue to support COGO's development. Thank you very much.

: Unknown Executive (Executives)
Next question?

: Jian Min Hao (Executives)
2013, HKD 187 billion. Well, our sold-out rate was about 75% to 80%. Basically, around 80%. I don't think we have gone beyond 70%. Otherwise, our financial situation will be very difficult because we pursue high sold-out rates. When it comes to commercial segment, you can have a rate project or collaborate with another entity. I think stable cash flow is very important. We need the capital. But of course, the rating organizations will have something to say. So we are looking at ownership of the property and also taking in rental income. This is not a burden to us and, therefore, in the past, I've already told you about this. Your financial situation or the project you face will be very different considering how much commercial property you own. We have gathered some information recently. Some property enterprises have decided to quit. They wanted to sell the business. We have obtained some information. Is it going to be a trend or there will be more opportunities? We will have to wait and see. And then, Internet, is it affecting our business? Of course, I know how people spend is being chased by the Internet. I am still learning. And I hope you understand now this. For the property sector, there are simply too many uncertainties. First of all, it is not investment. It is not manufacturing. Property sector combines different things. So you cannot compare it with any other industry. It is not a good comparison. Through the use of Internet and IT measures, perhaps we can promote changes in some parts of our business. Perhaps, that is very reasonable because we already have the social resources at hand. So GDP ratio, I don't even know where to begin. It's such a huge topic. Are you saying that the Opera [ph] sector is kidnapping the Chinese economy? Or this person is not using a mic, the interpreter cannot hear. Nothing is coming through.  Well, first of all. Development of the Chinese company according to some economic data, we can see 7.5% growth or more will mean stable growth. Perhaps, there's some conspiracy theory. I don't know, but I think stable growth of Chinese economy with a good structure is achievable. We have the fundamentals. We have the data supporting this. This is all along what I think. You talked about some conspiracies. And so I have said, anything across-the-board, anything positive and negative but if it is across-the-board, don't pay too much attention to it. It is not objective. Some people will say, "Oh, it is going to collapse". How can you say so? Unless the Earth is going to explode. Some people just want to terrify others. It is not rational. We have to look at the real situation and all the relevant elements. Perhaps, if you're a news reporter, you would like to hear something shocking. Yes, it will collapse tomorrow. It will be the headline on the newspaper. It has value because they're selling newspaper but you are rational people here, aren't you? Thank you very much for the questions.

---

: Unknown Executive (Executives)
Final question?

: Unknown Analyst (Analysts)
Mr. Hao, you talked about 300 million people creating huge demand. They're from the West or poor areas. What about the affordability? How are they going to propel further urbanization? So I really want to ask about the affordability of these 300 million people. Is it going to create any pressure on the company?

: Jian Min Hao (Executives)
Where are you from?

: Unknown Analyst (Analysts)
Chinese University, Hong Kong.

Research institution. So we have the same background. Thank you for the question. 300 million. Yes, indeed, affordability is different. In different cities, there will be different situations. : Unknown Executive (Executives)

6777450.eventHeadline: Sasol Ltd., H1 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 10, 2014
6777450.transcript_text1:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, good afternoon and good evening, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the conference call today. Joining me from Sasol here in Johannesburg are Paul Victor, our acting CFO; Bernard Klingenberg, Group Executive for South African Energy; Riaan Rademan, our Group Executive for Mining and Business Enablement and Ernst Oberholster, Group Executive for International Energy Technology and New Business Development. Also dialing in from our North American head office in Houston is Steve Cornell, Executive Vice President for International Operation; and connecting from our Hamburg office in Germany, Fleetwodd Grobler, Group Executive for Global Chemicals. 
Today, we announced another excellent groupwide performance. To contextualize the half year and before we run through the presentation you have in front of you, let me start by reflecting on the recent past. As a company, we've come a long way in the last 2.5 years. Looking back for us at Sasol, FY '12 was all about goal setting and consolidation. During that time, we carefully assessed our areas of competitive advantage and where we could do better. We drove operational improvement and focused on safe, stable and reliable operations. We refined our strategic agenda and narrowed in on 2 broad regional strategies: first, our-nurture-and-grow strategy, primarily here in Southern Africa, where we seek to enhance our strong position in the region; and secondly, our expand-and-deliver strategy, which is underpinned by our North American aspirations and specifically our U.S. growth program. 
At our results announcement in September last year, I told you that our 2013 financial year would be a watershed for Sasol. After all, in FY '13, we consciously moved away from coal to liquids growth and stepped up our gas-to-liquids ambitions. At the same time, we accelerated our low-carbon power generation initiatives and drove safe and more efficient operations. Now as part of this step change, we reprioritized our project pipeline to deliver tangible and sustainable value and crucially, we focused the entire company on a single set of priorities, which included the urgent need to address our cost creep. To ensure that we are a more effective organization, the management team signed off on a redesigned operating model, with simplified structures, streamlined decision-making layers and fit-for-purpose functions. 
Now turning to FY '14, from July last year to date, we have been laying a solid foundation across the organization for what will be a new era in Sasol's history. The hard work of the past several years is already paying off. Although in management's view, this is only the beginning. The full benefits of the new Sasol will only be realized from our 2015 financial year onward. The strong results we announced today are a testament to our ability to leverage our unique value proposition, optimizing the macroeconomic impact while managing the factors within our control. 
Here, through deliberate interventions, we are increasing volumes, driving business performance enhancements and moving forward on our strategic growth projects. 
Turning to Slide 4. Let me start with an overview of what you'll hear today. I'll begin by providing you with a snapshot of how we are creating long-term shareholder value. Next, under the heading of delivery and growth, I'll highlight the key milestones we achieved during the first half of the 2014 financial year. What is most notable is that we continue to deliver strong headline earnings growth notwithstanding a still very uncertain, and to some extent, volatile macroeconomic backdrop. I'll then update you on the progress we are making with our business performance enhancement program. Paul will then go into more detail on our financial and operational performance. I'll then come back on to talk to you about the advancements we've been making on our key capital projects before opening it up for any questions you may have. 
Moving on to Slide 5. The true measure of our success is our ability to create value for our shareholders, and in turn, our stakeholders. If we look at the graph, you see there in front of you over the past 20 months, from July 2, 2012, to March 7 of this year, Sasol share price increased by 71% from ZAR 340 to ZAR 582. We acknowledge that given our business model, we are impacted by the move in crude oil prices, the rand-dollar exchange rate and country- and continent-specific factors. 
To some extent, these factors influence the result of companies worldwide and are not unique to Sasol. It should also be borne in mind that macroeconomic factors do not only positively impact an organization's results. In analyzing our company's performance over the last 20 months, the weaker rand and a slight improvement in chemical product prices support our earnings growth. While on the flip side, crude oil prices had a slightly negative impact. In addition, and particularly within our South African environment, the above-inflation growth in labor and maintenance costs and ongoing electricity price hikes also adversely impacted our numbers. In calculating the effects on our share price performance, we've taken both the positive and negative into account as illustrated by the second bar on the graph. In instances where macroeconomics support a company's value proposition, management can easily become complacent. However, being a consistently successful business is all about leveraging the positives and limiting the negatives, whatever the microeconomics. At Sasol, being complacent is not an option. The lighter blue bars to the right of the graph, highlight the role played by decisive leadership in managing the factors under our control, including optimizing volumes, enhancing organizational structures and systems, executing on our capital projects and continually driving our business performance. 
Looking at it differently, if we consider the contribution of these controllable factors on our performance, from July 2012 to the end of December 2013, we added an additional ZAR 3.7 billion to our operating profit. This equates to an increase in our headline earnings per share of 10% on top of a previous record earnings base. The value created here is due to the contributions made across the group, most notably through an improved operational performance over the period. 
Going forward, and as depicted on the right-hand side of the graph, we see even more upside as we secure additional business performance improvements and execute on our growth program. Here, our U.S. cracker, along with its derivative units, is first up. In addition, we are confident that our growth ambitions will continue to be underscored by our progressive dividend policy. You saw this again today with our announcement of record interim dividends. 
Looking at Slide 6. Record financial results aside, we fully recognize the direct link between top-class business performance and a higher purpose. As the slide is self-explanatory, I will not talk to the specifics you see listed here. 
Let's instead move onto Slide 7, which highlights our key milestones for the first half of the 2014 financial year. Safety remains our #1 priority and is a strategic imperative for our sustainable operation. We have over the last 2 years seen marked improvement and ended our half year with a recordable case rate excluding illnesses of 0.3. Over the period, our star safety performance was the ORYX GTL joint venture in Qatar. By the end of February, the facility completed over 11 million exposure hours, equating to 919 days without a recordable incident. In addition, the plant had over 17 million hours work without a lost time injury, here totaling 1,528 days. This is a remarkable achievement in the industry. 
Turning next to our operational performance. In September, our Synfuels team successfully completed the facility's largest-ever shut down with more than 155 activities executed, utilizing an additional 36,000 people on site daily. In turn, our flagship GTL joint venture ORYX set a further noteworthy production record. Over the period, the plant recorded an average utilization rate of 94% as it benefited from a shutdown early last year. 
As part of delivering and growing sustainably, this past half year, we advanced a number of key projects and initiatives. Last month, we were granted an extension of our Secunda mining rights to 2040. This approval was critical, not only for our mining operations but more importantly, it will go a long way to ensuring an uninterrupted supply of liquid fuels and chemicals for several decades to come in South Africa. 
In January, and with the support of our keynote speaker, Minister Rob Davies, from the Department of Trade and Industry, we successfully inaugurated our ethylene purification unit in Sasolburg. The project was completed on time and within its approved budget, and will increase ethylene volumes for our polyethylene plants by 47,000 tons annually. These volumes are a key input for the local plastics industry. 
Turning to our ongoing technological advancements. At the end of last year, we were proud to launch our Sasol turbodiesel 10 part per million product. This is the lowest-sulfur-content diesel offered on the African continent, moving South Africa closer to international clean fuel specifications. 
Turning to Slide 8. In terms of our overall half year FY '14 results, Sasol maintained a strong operational performance across the value chain. Here, it was encouraging to see the chemicals businesses contributing significantly to the group. Also noteworthy was Sasol Synfuels' ability to deliver sustainable volumes, notwithstanding its largest shutdown ever. Having achieved 3.7 million tons over the period, normalized production volumes at Synfuels were up by 3%. 
As we incur costs to ensure plant stability and the weaker rand continues to exert pressure on our South African businesses, we were pleased to maintain our normalized cash fixed costs below South African PPI of 6.4%. Excluding once-off, operating profit was up 33%. Headline earnings per share off a record base was up by 26% to ZAR 30.19. Cash generated from operations was up 50% to ZAR 28.1 billion. As a result of the group's strong performance, an interim dividend of ZAR 8 per share was declared. This was a record interim dividend, up by 40% and well in line with our progressive dividend policy. 
Moving on to Slide 10, and before I hand over to Paul, let me provide you with a quick update on our business performance enhancement program. Since launching the program in 2013, we've made significant progress in rightsizing and repositioning Sasol. Having finalized the design of our new groupwide operating model, including the top management structures, we are on track to implement our new platform on July 1. By the end of June, we will have reorganized the majority of our senior management structures and refined our financial reporting processes. This reorganization will significantly reduce the company's top management decision making layers. 
By way of example, we have reduced the number of group executives subcommittees from 57 to 9, an 84% reduction. In addition, we have reduced the total number of meetings within our governance structure from 580 per year to 160, a 72% reduction. The management team intends on using this extra time wisely, focusing more specifically on enhancing the productivity over existing operations and on driving our strategic growth ambitions. Together with the implementation of our new management structures and related corporate governance framework, we are introducing key system and process changes. The new operating model will also result in simplified and fit-for-purpose functional support to the business.

Although, overall we benefited from a weaker rand/dollar exchange rate, the impact of a weaker rand added a further 4.9% to our total cash fixed costs. Growth and study costs added a further 0.4%, while the implementation costs of our business enhancement program amounted to a further 0.4% or ZAR 190 million. 
Labor, maintenance and energy remain the main drivers of our cost base, with labor comprising approximately 55% of our total cash fixed costs. Labor costs per head for the year are expected to increase ahead of our a PPI inflation. Energy cost inflation in South Africa is likely be just over 7% for the 2014 financial year based on the Eskom increase announced by NERSA. Our strategy to contain energy costs has seen us successfully ramp up our electricity generation capacity in South Africa to approximately 70% of our own requirement. Our investment in plant maintenance over the past couple of years has successfully delivered plant stability and improved volumes across our key businesses. And lastly, strides taken in our business performance enhancement program also contributed to this positive stream in cost trends.
Moving to Slide 14. Operating profit was supported by a mostly favorable macroeconomic environment during the first half of the 2014 financial year. The weaker rand-dollar exchange rate was the largest contributor to the increase in operating profit, boosting operating profit by 37%, improved product prices added a further 7%. It is extremely encouraging to note the positive impact of increased sales volume of 7% across the group. This is on the back of a 7% increase in sales volumes for the 2013 financial year. The total increase over the last 18 months amounted to ZAR 3.7 billion in real terms on a record 2012 earnings base. However, operating profit was negatively impacted by once-off items of ZAR 5.7 billion, as well as year-end adjustments such as the provision for share-based payment expenses and higher depreciation charges relating to our Canadian shale gas asset, shut downs and statutory maintenance, as well as new plants. 
Moving to Slide 15. The SA Energy cluster continues to underpin the group's profit and cash flow generation with a 28% increase in operating profit. Sasol Mining's operating profit increased by 4% despite higher operating costs. Profits were supported by higher sales prices to Sasol Synfuels and weaker rand. Sasol Gas 34% increase in operating profit includes a gain of ZAR 453 million on the disposal of our investment in Spring Lights Gas. Excluding remeasurement items, operating profit increased by 11%, supported by a 5% increase in sales volumes and marginally improved sales prices. 
Sasol Synfuels remains the largest contributor to the SA Energy cluster's operating profit. Operating profit increased by 30% and operating margin expanded by an impressive 6.4% to 51%, the highest level since 2009. Profits were driven largely by a weaker rand, as well as better-than-expected production volumes despite the largest shutdown in Sasol Synfuel's history. Management's ongoing efforts to contain costs, coupled with improved plant stability resulted in cash unit costs increasing by 6.9% in line with inflation. 
Sasol Oil's operating profit increased by 22%, benefiting from improved refining and sales margins. Sasol Oil's cash fixed costs were also contained to within inflation. Production volumes were 12% higher, largely due to the postponement of a planned shutdown at Natref to the second half of the calendar -- of the financial year. 
Moving to Slide 16. Focusing on our international energy cluster. Sasol Synfuels International's operating loss decreased by 4%. Growth and study costs, previously expensed, declined significantly with the U.S. GTL project moving into FEED. This benefit was partially negated by once-off items incurred by the SSI business. 
ORYX GTL recorded a 10% increase in operating profit, driven by the increase in volumes and a weaker rand. The facility achieved a year-to-date average utilization rate of 94%, which is 4% higher than our previous guided range. ORYX GTL is the flagship for our GTL technology and its continued strong performance reinforces our GTL value proposition. Sasol Petroleum International recorded a disappointing operating loss of ZAR 6.1 billion for the period. 
In Africa, Mozambique and Gabon performed well, delivering 6% higher volumes, and we are making good progress with our growth programs in Mozambique, which David will provide more color on. Although Gabon's oil production is slowly declining, we are maturing additional volumes to sustain the life of the asset. Our Canadian upstream asset generated operating loss of ZAR 6.5 million impacted by ZAR 5.3 billion impairment, coupled with the depreciation charge of ZAR 1.3 billion. Although the asset remains under pressure in the short term due to low North American gas prices and high depreciation, cash flow generated from this operation still remains positive. We continue to execute our approved production program in conjunction with our now new JV partner, Progress Energy, and we'll be able to ramp up activities once we see an increase in the gas prices. 
Moving to Slide 17. In November, Talisman announced that it reached agreement to sell its 50% share in the Montney shale gas asset to Progress Energy. As previously indicated, Sasol took a decision not to exercise its right of first refusal in respect of this asset. Talisman's disposal, coupled with a further decline in the conditions in the North American gas market, prompted us to take an impairment review of our 50% share in the Montney asset. As a result of our evaluation, we impaired our Canadian shale gas asset by approximately CAD 550 million or ZAR 5.3 billion to a carrying value of CAD 1.1 -- apologies, CAD 1.1 billion. 
In our impairment review, we have used a more conservative gas price outlook compared to what we use in evaluating our potential GTL and chemical investment opportunities. I want to reemphasize that despite this impairment, we believe that our Canadian shale gas assets continue to provide a strategic hedge for our GTL plans. 
Moving to Slide 18. We have seen an overall recovery in sales prices and volumes in our chemical businesses. The focused business turnaround plan in our South African Polymer business has yielded positive results. Polymers reduced its operating loss to ZAR 351 million from ZAR 1.1 billion in the comparative period. This is mainly attributable to a 7% higher production volume increase and improved margin. The EPU5 plant commissioned in October 2013 has brought significant stability and financial benefit to our C2 value chain. The C3 stabilization plant, which is expected to come on stream middle of the calendar year 2014 is expected to further improve feedstock availability to the local business. 
Our international Polymer business contributed a profit of ZAR 194 million. This excludes a final loss on disposal of ZAR 198 million for our Arya Sasol Polymers company in Iran. Effective 16 August 2013, Sasol no longer has any investments in Iran. 
Solvents delivered a strong operational result despite a challenging economical climate. Improved sales volume, tight cost control and a weaker rand supported the increase in operating profit to ZAR 358 million. In December 2013, we signed an agreement to dispose most of our Solvents Germany asset. This resulted in the impairment of ZAR 466 million. The disposal is still subject to the approval of the European antitrust authorities. Once approved, it's expected that the loss on disposal will be recorded in the second half of the current financial year. 
O&S remains the largest contributor to the chemical cluster's operating profit and the second largest contributor to the group's operating profit. Operating profit increased by 75% to ZAR 2.7 billion or an increase of 40% in euro terms. Operating margins expanded almost 2% to 10.4%. Our U.S. business continues to benefit from improved margins on low U.S. ethane prices coupled with high production and sales volumes. 
Focusing on operating profit in other chemical businesses. Wax increased its operating profit by 24% on the back of higher volumes, favorable prices and a weaker rand. Moving on to Slide 19. Our continued focus -- our continued strong cash flow generation from our foundation businesses is evident from a 50% increase in cash generated by our operations amounting to ZAR 28.1 billion. This, together with our deleveraged balance sheet, which reflects our ungeared position of 0.8% at half year, positions us uniquely to fund the steady advancements of our attractive growth projects and deliver on our progressive dividend policy. We have spent ZAR 20 billion of capital investment in the current financial year to date, in line with our expectation of which approximately 54% was in South Africa. We have maintained our capitalization estimate for 2014 of ZAR 42 billion and ZAR 50 billion for 2015. Approximately half of these capital investments over the next 2 years will be spent in South Africa. A large portion of our future growth capital investment will be allocated to our mega growth projects, which is in line with our growth strategy. 
Turning on to Slide 20. Taking into account our record headline earnings per share, the ongoing strength of our financial position, the current capital investment plan and our progressive dividend policy, we have increased the interim dividend by 40% to a record ZAR 8 per share. Our dividend yield of approximately 4% and our total shareholder return of 122% in rand terms over the past 5 years continues to position Sasol competitively with our peer group, reinforcing our commitment to consistently return value to our shareholders. Despite our recent strong share price performance, we remain confident in our ability to return further value to our shareholders through sweating our existing current asset base, executing on our growth projects, achieving our business performance enhancement program target, as well as delivering on our progressive dividend policy.

In the near term, we anticipate stable oil prices, slightly improved U.S. natural gas prices, a progressive recovery in chemical product prices and flat refining margins. We assume a slight strengthening in the rand/dollar exchange rate from its current level. We expect an overall solid production performance for 2014 financial year. 
Sasol Synfuel's volume guidance remains unchanged to be between 7.3 million and 7.5 million tons, international ORYX GTL to maintain full year utilization rate of above 90%, and in Canada, we anticipate marginally decreased production due to reduced drilling activities and fewer new wells coming on stream. B01BN57.transcript_text1:
Good afternoon, everybody, and thank you for coming. Once again, we would like to begin our strategic presentation with a video that speaks louder than words of who we are and what we have done. You have just seen how our strategy has been turned into investments and saving for the country, growth and efficiency for the company, profits and return for our shareholders. All tangible results, achieved with a sustainable approach, a close attention to sustainability, essential for responsibility and respect for our stakeholders. Terna's management style is genuinely reflected into the ethical principle and regulation of our code of ethics, but it is also recognized by the inclusion of our stock in the main sustainability indexes. 
Well, after this very brief opening, I leave the floor to our CFO, Flavio Cattaneo, who will recommend the new targets. Later on, Andrea Crenna will comment the 2013 results.

---

Thank you, Luigi, and good morning, everybody. Well, thanks to our continuous effort, the ninth addition, kicks off with a 33rd consecutive quarter of growth. The ability to translate processes and action into concrete result is our footprint consolidated in years of tough operating and financial discipline. 
Revenues are up by 5%, while EBITDA by more than 6%. The EBITDA margin stepped forward, exceeding 78%, our historical peak. Group net income reached 5 1 4, EUR 514 million, with a double-digit growth year-on-year. This result has more than doubled the level of 9 years ago. Net debt at EUR 6.6 billion is in line with our guidance, while the over EUR 1.2 billion CapEx is of high quality level with 80% incentivized investment. 
Later on, Mr. Crenna will further comment the result, while I'd like to introduce the strategic target starting from our long path to growth. Since '05, Terna has invested almost EUR 8 billion with a peak EUR 1.2 billion, annual spending in the last 3 years. We feel the infrastructure's gap between Italy and the rest of the Europe, generating up to now more than EUR 5 billion savings for the system. The savings will triple, including all the future benefits. RAB recently exceed EUR 12 billion, doubling the '05 asset base. Operational and financial efficiencies further enhanced earnings, which on a cumulative basis, amounted to EUR 4.2 billion. I remind that 30% of these earnings has been generated by our entrepreneurial approach in our traditional activities. Now consider it a key driver for our dual strategy. 
The combination of this path and some external condition have gradually changed the general framework and the challenges we have to face. Indeed, as expected, the interim review brought the WACC market -- sorry, down from a 7.4% to 6.3%. Fortunately, the positive impact of RAB evolution offset WACC revision, confirming total grade fee substantially flat year-on-year. As a result, our efforts have been adjusted to preserve good profitability and sound credit metrics. 
Well, getting to tomorrow, as you see on Page 8, we are confirming our dual strategy with the strong vision that the value creation is shaped on the solid floor on traditional activities and the encouraging potential of now traditional activities. NTAs are [indiscernible] and intermittent are down. On the contrary, the potential is a natural and fundamental evolution of Terna's value. 
So looking at target on the next slide. For the first time since '09, our 5-year CapEx target in the grid is below $4 billion. Nonetheless, annual RAB growth is expected to grow to 5% and the blended return will reach 7.7%. On nontraditional side, we are confirming the potential of EUR 900 million over the amount of contracts already included in the plan. Differently from last year, today, we rely ongoing deals that bring our overall effort to EUR 1.3 billion. Notwithstanding lower WACC, the EBITDA margin will exceed the 79% in '18, while the net debt on RAB ratio is confirmed well below 60%. 
Looking at the traditional activities now. The grid development needs are confirmed in the region of EUR 8 billion. But on a grid project selectivity and some delays by local opposition have reshaped the spending now shift over the longer time frame. The plan foresees EUR 5.6 billion by '23, and the rest beyond the 10-year horizon. This whole thing is obviously reflected in our 5 year CapEx plan. 
In which, as anticipated, we'll spend of EUR 3.6 billion dollars, more than half of the spending is concentrated in the first 2 years. The mix is still compelling, over 80% will be remunerated with a framework of incentives when known in the next 2 years. In the longer run, as expected, CapEx will normalize at the lower level. 
Few more words on storage now. We are pioneers among the first in the world in the extensive application of storage system as element of the grid. CapEx will be around EUR 200 million over the EUR 60 million already spent. We are progressing well, both in power and energy intensive project. We are currently executing the first phase of the power intensive project, the so-called storage lab consisting and the testing of different technologies. The testing concern the first 60-megawatt and the remaining 24-megawatt that will follow soon after. Energy intensive project are located in 3 sites in southern Italy, 2 of them already fully authorized and ongoing. 
Now moving to RAB and blended returns. Giving the higher starting RAB, growth rate stand in the 5% area, already incorporating the new CapEx profile and the recent inflation trends. B058ZV4.eventHeadline: Coca-Cola Icecek A.S., 2013 Earnings Call, Mar 10, 2014
B058ZV4.transcript_text1:
Good morning, and good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2013 results conference call. Today, our CEO, Burak, will briefly talk about our operations; and our CFO, Orhun, will share with you the financial review. Following Burak's closing remarks, we will start Q&A session. 
Before we begin, please kindly be advised of our cautionary statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking management comments, including projections. They should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary language contained in this earnings release. A copy of the earnings release and financials are available on our website at www.cci.com.tr. 
Now let me turn the call over to Burak.

---

Thank you, Deniz. Good afternoon, everyone. I am very delighted to say that we've exceeded 1 billion unit cases of volume for the first time in 2013, supported mainly by the double-digit volume growth in our international markets. Turkey volume returns to growth in the fourth quarter of -- in 2013. This was a result of successful campaigns to reenergize the volume growth in Turkey after the weak third quarter. 
I am particularly pleased with the margin improvement in our international markets, driven by strong performance in our key international markets namely Pakistan, Iraq and Kazakhstan. In 2013, our efforts to improve balance sheet health continues with a very successful U.S. private placement in May and a Eurobond in October. With these successful debt issuances, total duration of our debt portfolio extended from 1.2 years to 5 years. 
Last year, our consolidated volume growth was 13%. Turkey sales volume increased by 1% despite the decline in the third quarter and the challenging market economic conditions in the second half of the year. International operations contribution to volume growth was 32% in 2013, as all key markets posted strong growth numbers. 
Turning to volume breakdown, we are very happy to say that CCI has a more balanced portfolio of business than previous years. International sales volume is now 46% of our total volume in 2013 and up from 39% in 2012. This was achieved by the high-organic growth in Central Asia and Pakistan, as well as acquisition of Al Waha in South Iraq. In 2013, the share of the sparkling category in total mix was at 73%. Sparkling category posted 13% strong growth, driven by brand Coke and Sprite, particularly in international operations. Still category grew by 11%, with a strong growth of Juice, Iced-Tea and Water segments. 
Now let me briefly touch base on the operations, beginning first with the Turkey operations. Following the decline in the third quarter, Turkey volume turned to positive 2% growth in the fourth quarter of 2013. The growth was achieved in spite of the persistent uncertainty due to TL's sharp depreciation and also weakening consumer sentiment in the second half of the year. Sparkling beverage category contracted by 1% in 2013, while Coke Zero posted double-digit growth, driven by the relaunch campaign in the first half of the year. The immediate consumption packages shared in the total sparkling mix increased by 100 basis points to 18% in total in 2013 on the back of successful new package introductions in the first half of the year. 
Still Beverages, excluding water, grew at high-single digits in 2013, driven by juice and iced-tea categories. In Juice segment, Cappy posted volume growth, supported by the help of new flavors. Fuse Tea continued to grow at high-double digits. The water category contracted by high-single digits, mainly by contraction of our HOD business. This was in line with our strategy to balance water volume growth and to manage profitable details to category. The non-ready-to-drink tea business grew at double digits, driven largely by the loose Black Tea segment. 
In addition to successful Rock'N Coke and Fanta Youth Festival in 2013, very successful consumer promotions and activations supported volume growth, especially in the fourth quarter. We have also started a Connect Campaign in Turkey in 2013, brand Coke features 200 most popular names on the both IC and HC packages. Connect promotion brought high advantage and significantly increased our brand equity scores in the marketplace. 
Moving on to international operations, in 2013, we continue to strengthen our market position in our key international markets. Pakistan sales volume was up 22%, driven by strong local marketing campaigns, cooler injections and increased our outlet penetrations. Brand Coke, Fanta and Sprite continue to grow double digits in 2013. In Pakistan, we have activated very successful Ramadan promotion with the help of 1.25-liter PET package. Iraq volume more than doubled in the back of inclusion of Al Waha and continued strong growth in Northern Iraq. In South Iraq, we have started Coke production in March of 2013 and initiated consumer activations in Baghdad as well. CCI maintained its #1 position in North Iraq and currently build in our outlet penetration in South. In 2013, our market share in Iraq in Sparkling was 26% in total. 
Central Asia maintained its high growth trends and grew by 19%, thanks to growing economies, market share gains and improved execution. Our largest operation in Central Asia, Kazakhstan, grew by 24%, while all categories posted market share gains. Brand Coke grew 60%, hence, our sparkling market share in Kazakhstan posted strong 6.1% increase, reaching 48% in 2013. Fuse Tea sales growth was at high-single digits, posting share gain as well. 
Now I would like to turn the call to Orhun for an update on the financials. Thank you.

---

Thank you, Burak. And Good afternoon, and good morning, everyone. Before I start walking through our financial performance for 2013, as always, let us remember that between the 31st of December 2012 and 31st of December 2013, the Turkish lira has weakened some 19.7% against the dollar, whereas the average devaluation was about 6%, 6.2%. And again, the annual inflation on a year-on-year basis was 7.4% in the year. 
Now if you move over to the financial statements, that would be on Slide 11, the 2012 numbers you see here, as you would all remember by now, are pro forma numbers, whereas the Pakistani business is consolidated in full, so that's directly comparable to the numbers in 2013. I'm happy to again underline that we have delivered, in line with our guidance for 2013 and for the ones who have joined our call roughly a year ago when we were discussing our 2012 results and giving a guidance for 2013, we'll recall that we have done a little bit better in terms of how we have grown our EBITDA and extended our margin in the year. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. On behalf of the Investment Analysts Society, we would like to thank Sanlam at the outset for hosting us here today in the presentation for the results of the year ended December 2013. The director [ph] from sales, the executives, members of the board, we thank you. 
Sanlam has its origins almost 100 years old. I don't want to preempt anything about what happens in 2018, but it was formed in 1918. It was incorporated as an enterprise to mobilize investment savings in South Africa through various investment products. This company has done that over the years and particularly in the formative years in the '30s through to the '70s when it formed closed investment trusts as a medium of investment. And in those trusts, it invested in small enterprises. And over the years, those small enterprises are today major enterprises in South Africa. Many of them are listed. Some of the market capitalizations today far exceeding that of Sanlam. Sanlam's market capitalization takes it into the top 50 companies in South Africa. But there are many ahead, and there are many unlisted companies and there are many below that owe their origins of capital and investment to Sanlam. 
Sanlam has always been a company that's been on the forefront of investment enterprise in South Africa no more so than today, as it embraces a new social and economic order. And so it's with great interest today that we thank you not only for inviting us, but to share in the results of what has been achieved over the past 12 months, and gain insight as to where this company is going to in the future and playing such a vital part in the enterprise of -- for all South Africans. Thank you.

---

Thank you so much for that introduction, and the advertisement as well. Ladies and gentlemen, it's a pleasure to welcome you all here at the -- our annual results presentation on 2013. Before I really start, I would like to welcome a few special guests, some of our board members here: our Chairman, Desmond Smith; other board members, Philip Rademeyer; Rejoice Simelane; Bernard Swanepoel; a few staff members here from the EXCO, Temba Mvusi; Tema Gametsi [ph]; and so. And people who'll join me in answering questions and doing part of the presentation here: Kobus Mller, our Financial Director; and Andre Zeeman, our Chief Actuary and also Chief Risk Officer. We would like to also welcome some of our other partners here: the FSB, our regulator; SARS, our big partner; and some business people here from our businesses, welcome. 
Ladies and gentlemen, our presentation as usual will focus a bit on the operating environment, which I'll cover, to set the scene for the results. I think the results are meaningless without taking into account what we had to deal with. And then I'll give you a strategic overview of the business, some of the main results and where we're heading. Kobus Mller, our Financial Director, will talk a little bit about the financials, give you the actual results and the feedback. And I'll end off with the outlook and priorities that we have for this year, things that we'll be tackling, and our vision for the future. If we take the period 2006 to 2012 for which we have data, we've seen a very large number of people becoming part of the mainstream economy, people who have been excluded in the past.
