So there's a big drive to also create that synergies and help Santam to grow their business. Then organizational capacity to support growth is critically important. As issues arise, we move people from our -- from mainly from our Sanlam Retail business, from our Investment business, from Santam, to come and join the Emerging Markets team to strengthen that. Some on a project basis if we have issues, some others on a more permanent basis, but it's a critical component. And the other issue is the compliance and governance and reporting. We have rigid standards and very high standards in terms of what many of the countries we deal with have been exposed to in the past. So it's quite a journey to make sure that they're reporting the management, the risk management and the other issues that we face within these countries are at the same level in what we have over here in South Africa. So there's an ongoing focus of training, support and in the areas of compliance, reporting and so forth. So that's going fairly well. On the investment side, the focus is firstly to maintain the investment performance, the good performance that we've seen. Most of the value investors struggled in 2012, with momentum investors doing well. We've seen some return to value investments doing better. And last year, you could see it in our results as well, so it's about retaining what we have. Particularly, we have a fixed benchmark. I think a big area for us is to improve institutional fund flows, to improve retail funds flows, where the margins are substantially higher and so. And in order to affect that, we changed the business quite substantially, and separated essentially the product factory, the investment component, from the 2 markets that we have. So we've set up a much more client-centric structure that we will be leveraging off. In addition to that, we will expand our African funds proposition. We already have an African property fund. We would like to develop our African debt fund in there. We have an African equity fund, listed equity fund, and we have other 2 opportunities; not only with our own money, but increasingly to draw money in there and so forth. And once or twice, you get a setback -- some of our people have been locked up just before the weekend for not having the right visa. The people behind the counter ran out of time, and the last 5 people and the people, they just said well, we don't have time for you guys. You have to sleep in our facility here overnight. Not the greatest kind of accommodation you'll get from that. But overall, things are going fairly well. Cost effective solution across the value chain, critical. We bought Satrix, it's doing well. Optimizing the active versus passive management business models, I think we're doing that fairly well at the moment. We need to do much better on the passive side. We've paid a fair amount for Satrix. But we think, in South Africa in particular, that there's still scope for the ETF -- for that whole ETF space to grow quite substantially. And then this business depends very much on what happens in the Retail business. It depends a lot on what happens in other areas of Sanlam. And I think there's a lot of improvement that we can make in terms of collaboration and efficiencies. We don't -- we get small amounts of our own flows into the Retail business. If you look at the bigger picture, into our own Investment business, I think we can do better there. In Santam, the story there is quite clear. It's been a tough 2 years. I'm very happy with the progress that we're making in getting the premium increases through, in doing better risk underwriting and so forth. And already last year, as opposed to 2012, we were much better and had smaller exposure to particularly [ph]  These hailstorms and several of the floods and so forth, through deliberate actions that we've taken in this business. I think growth is important in this business. We've seen market diversification, we have a few special projects in place there: The investment in the Sanlam Emerging Market partners. Santam RE [ph]; the Specialist businesses and then MiWay, which has really been making a tremendous contribution towards growth in the personal lines market. The size and quality of the risk pool, we do much better. We're really addressing a whole range of things there. There are a number of key projects that we're implementing to better underwrite on a scientific way. Up until now, it's been major groups and so forth. We have a project in that. We would like to take the scientific underwriting that we follow in the direct model and implement some of the key characteristics of that, also in the personal lines broker market. So we're working on that. There is a big drive through the value chain to get efficiencies going, the focus is on cost. I think we can do much better on the claims side still. We are really optimizing a lot of that, but it's -- it requires a new look, particularly now that the rand is weak, and a lot of what we have to replace is simply imported stuff. And then, we have a number of strategic projects also that I've already mentioned, going through that. So overall, there's more than enough to keep us busy, and we think you know that we can make a tremendous impact for the year. For the outlook for the rest of year, we're getting the improved traction in the developed economies, the twofold impact. It will be supportive of economic activity in Emerging Markets, maybe not immediately. We've already seen there's sort of a year lag when it happens, but we feel a positive that eventually, with the increased traction in developed markets will have a trickle-down effect to ourselves. But more importantly, in the shorter-term, the tapering of quantitative easing will result in volatility in the currency. We think the weakening of the currency has been overdone. The investment market performance is on a high, we're relatively expensive, and we don't necessarily expect the same kind of returns going forward. In fact, we're much more cautious about the future. For us, a big focus is bedding down new acquisitions. We've been investing quite a bit, and we'll be pulling quite a few people from our existing businesses, SPF and so, to strengthen the team that we have within our Emerging Markets business. So making sure that we actually get what we plan. Big issue in South Africa is regulatory. I think it would be the regulatory pressures then changes that we see. Retirement reform is a big issue. You would have heard the Minister of Finance speaking in the budget about costs in retirement form. As an industry, we've agreed that if we can get certain things in place, particularly compulsion, and particularly, if we can keep preservation by keep -- in keeping their retirement funds on the platform, without it being disappearing every 6 months for people moving jobs and so forth, we can drive down cost quite substantially. We'd like to do that. The big beneficiaries will be, of course, the clients, but also businesses like ours, where you get compulsions in countries like Chile and Australia and so forth. Private sector has benefited tremendously from what's happening there. So we really work with the regulatory authorities and particularly Treasury there, to create an environment where everybody is better off. Commission changes, a critical thing for us, because it affects the people that we deal with. We're working on that, fees, independence, tied agents and these kinds of things. So it may have some impact on us. I think we're really well placed with the models that we have in place. This year, I've already spoken about, it is finalizing our approaches and making sure that the stuff is bedded down and properly entrenched, and then the big, sort of, 
[Audio Gap]
a few questions still around Solvency Assessment and Management, which is all around capital. We think there will be more clarity on how it will impact us. We're busy with Quest 3 [ph], and once we have the results of those, we can again, a gauge on the results on the industry, and how it will impact the industry and so forth. So quite a few things. Ladies and gentlemen, and that brings the end to our story. I think in summary, very good results. As team, we've been together for quite a while. I've been with, as you know, I think, it's the 11th time, 11th year that I've been up here, reporting on our performance. Certainly within the life and savings industries, it's the best performance that we've had. We've been carried many years by Santam. This year, we were able to carry them. And in spite of what's been happening there, we're pretty proud of the results, and we think it's fairly solid. I would like to open the floor now for questions on a few things, and Andr, if you and Kobus can join us, there on the chairs, I'd really appreciate that. If you have a question, please put up your hand. People will get to you with the microphone and then introduce yourself and we -- and fire away.
B0L6750.transcript_text3:
I'm a bit like a hare in a spotlight here. I can't see too well. There's a question there. Risto?

---

Yes, hi, it's Risto from Standard Bank. Two questions. The first one is, I would like to know whether the board debated a special dividend? And if yes, what was the pros and cons of going with a substantial increase, normal dividend instead? The second question's a bit more technical. You mentioned that there's 1 or 2 major issues in SAM outstanding. Could you maybe expand on what the major issues are, and what's the relevance of those to Sanlam?

---

Okay. I think the first one on the special dividend, the board every year, over the past 10 years, have debated the issue of a special dividend. Because we've always had surplus capital, the issue was, do we invest it in other opportunities and so forth? We don't see the normal dividend and the special dividend being related to at all. Because the normal dividend simply refers to the cash flow of our operations in that given year. And we tried to pay out as much as possible, with a steady sort of an increase, with a dividend coverage of around 1.1. And that is how we arrived at the dividend, the normal dividend of ZAR 2. So it's supported by the cash flow from the business, and what we expect into the future, and that will be rising. The special dividend simply refers to the ZAR 4 billion of surplus cash that we have available, and then we measure that amount relative to the opportunities that we have, share buybacks or investing more into shares of our partners and the partnering businesses, what sort of return can we get on that? Investing into new business growth, or returning it to shareholders? We think we have a good pipeline of projects and available opportunities for the ZAR 4 billion that we have that justifies not paying a special dividend. And the timeframe of that is such that in the foreseeable future that we'll be able to spend the ZAR 4 billion. That was the sort of board decision, and how we derived that. The previous year, we paid a special dividend, where we had 4.2 surplus. We saw a good pipeline, but we knew that some of the projects would be further down the line. We'll be adding capital to that. And instead of sitting on the surplus, we've decided to pay a special dividend of ZAR 0.50, which is around ZAR 1 billion. Not a massive number, but steady. This year, we think there are other opportunities with higher sort of returns, like the stuff that you've been seeing. So that's the special dividend story. Kobus, would you like to add anything?

---

No, I agree with you, and I think that's exactly the point.

---

I'm happy that we think the same.

---

Must I take the same question? I think in general, as the basis developed up to now, I think we can live with it, in general terms. There's a couple of things that's been tested in Quest 3[ph]. And after we've seen the industry results, some decisions will be taken about that. I think for us, probably the major one-off, the items that's tested is, whether you allow any diversification benefit for participations. And as you know, I mean, since we are a diversified group, we have big participations in Santam, things like that. So I think that will have an impact on how big the cover level will be in the end. I don't think it will be crucial this way or that way, but it will impact on sort of the, how the numbers will look.

---

Yes, and just to give a bit more, I think flesh to Andr's answer there, we don't necessarily have to get any diversification benefits from the SAM process. But as a business, we'll just say, over and above that, with this amount of capital, because we're well diversified, we don't think we have to have the same cover as a business that doesn't have that. So -- and we'll specify that ourselves in looking at the capital. As we understand the process, there's enough room for that, so that's why Andr says it doesn't really matter on this side or that side. But in the end, optics do drive a lot of the process, and we have to understand what's going on. We don't want to be seen as having lower capital available as some of our peers and therefore being more risky. And those are the kinds of issues that we'll have to debate and address. At this moment in time, there are a number of issues that are simply up in the air. We would expect more, with our -- with the FSB people being here, working with us on SAM. They understand where we're going and we're in this together. We see that also as a partnership. Another question?

---

Morning, Johan. Larissa from Barclays. Your -- in your Emerging Market businesses, we saw relatively modest growth compared to some of what we've seen in prior years on the present value of sales. But your margin increased quite nicely, it went from 5.6 to 7.4. And then we also saw quite a nice bump in the new business profits. Can you maybe give us a little bit of color as to which countries and which products are really coming through that affected that?

---

Kobus, would you like to?

---

I think, as I've indicated, I mean the -- we did see substantial growth on the recurring Premium Life business, in most of the areas where we saw those products, and that reflects in the increase in the value for new business as well. And what you should now realize that what we report is a combination of investment business, short-term business and life business in those numbers. So it is -- that just -- will distort it somewhat. And in particular, where we saw bulky single premium business, it also distorts the year-on-year comparison of the overall number, in particular in Namibia, where we had very low-margin new [ph] trust business, that is no longer in that, in the comparison, so. But the profitable business, the Recurring Life business is really what reflects in the value of new business  [indiscernible].

---

Yes, and in the areas that we would like to continue and focus on like exactly, the new Life Recurring business and particularly the risk part of it, where we do -- are getting healthy margins, that part has been growing very, very well. Across the board. Any other question? Great. Do we have anybody? No questions, then? Nothing? What is left then is to thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for attending. We really appreciate your support. We work hard during the year to produce a set of numbers. It's been a pleasure to share that with you. We're very proud of what has been achieved in the past year. We think it will be a tough act to follow in this coming year, but we have a few, few things up our sleeve -- sleeves, and I think we're well set to continue on this journey. In particular, I think the strategy is fairly robust. We're well diversified in terms of regions, we're well diversified in terms of how we reach clients, not only intermediated, although it's still the main focus, but we have direct businesses. We have group schemes. We have affinity businesses. We're in different areas and markets in South Africa. We've been able to increase our footprint, and so forth. So overall, in terms of products, methodology of distribution, market segment and so forth, we feel pretty good that we can weather a lot of the storms we see coming our way. Always a few jokers in the pack, in particularly regulation. Increasingly we see the things that we get in the U.K., spilling over to South Africa. In fact, many of the policies are simply copied and implemented here, or at least discussed from that level. I think we have a good working relationship, together with the rest of the industry, to try and make and create then, a good business that's better for clients in the first, for customers. But also for the businesses, if they do the right stuff. And we're fairly confident and happy with the progress that's been made, and so we look forward to another set of good results for this year. Thank you for the support.

Detlef will go through the business units, sea, air, road and contract logistics performance. We're very proud that now Detlef is able to present a new team, clear, average age below 50, and mixture of internal and external. I'm very proud that the breeding within the company of Markus Blanka going through the management development concept of finance and administration Kuehne + Nagel via London, Euribor, Hong Kong and then Corporate Finance has resulted in giving him the opportunity to be my successor, to be the CFO of the future. So we have the outgoing and the incoming CFO here. Very proud that we were able to build that [indiscernible] talent and very important for the stability of the company and the culture -- to maintain the specific culture of the company. You all know how specific Kuehne + Nagel is if you come to cost control, cost management and even in a correcting market environment, we will, of course, never lose that ability.

Detlef will go through that.

Yes. The operating group general managers tend to be optimistic. They nearly always slip a few points of organic growth during the course of the year from what they forecast at the beginning. But I'd say, if you wandered around the groups right now, there's a slight feeling of optimism about the economy compared to the last 2 or 3 years.

In terms of the TSS acquisitions, it looked a bit higher in the bar.

---

Maybe that's it. Okay. Yes, I'll go back and look at that.

---

Then the other issue is capitalization of software, as well, maybe?

---

No, but everything else should tie. Like -- they come -- like it's the same number is going in both, it's just must be a matter of what we put in the bar tied to our financials versus the MD&A as it has EBITA in them.

---

Yes, you're right. That's probably is what it is.

---

It's for sure would be a way of financing Constellation if other sources of capital were not easily available. Right now, I feel that other sources of capital are available and that we don't need to do that.

---

Okay, great. I guess the second one is more on management structure. You talked a little bit, I think, first off to Scott, maybe in one of his questions, just about the cost and the margin. Well, hopefully, it's already there because we're over 8,000 right now. So -- but your underlying question is a legitimate one, and that's how do you manage something with hundreds of business units. And we're obviously studying people who've done before to see how they've done it.

Fair enough.

Okay.

---

We're going to keep acquiring a lot of small businesses. I wouldn't see us touching this largely rich transaction market until we felt we had exhausted the small business acquisition market. So it's a -- I would say, much less attractive business model than our core business model.

---

And so there's no -- the core is still in place, which is 20 to 30, perhaps 50, smaller deals per year?

---

Absolutely. And I would not do anything to put that at risk or to divert capital from that.

---

---

Absolutely.

---

So I think, 2 different issues there. One is I think we pay market for both. And so in the small transaction market, they tend to trade at lower multiples then very large businesses that have been optimized. In the large transaction market, usually, you've had fairly sophisticated though perhaps, short-term oriented shareholders owning these businesses. They may or may not have had software expertise to bring it to table. If it was a strategic acquire and they decide that software is hard or not as good a fit as they thought, those distressed assets can be very attractive to us. If it's an economic recession, it may not be that the softer assets are suffering, it could be that the parent business is suffering and they're looking for ways to free up capital. What we discovered during recession, John Billowits and I at that time, John was the CFO, went around and visited all private equity groups because we thought we were going to have a heyday buying up troubled software businesses. But what we discovered was they all came through the recession in pretty good shape. So despite the fact that they were leveraged to the gills, they managed to do fairly well. So I don't think you see a lot of distress because of financial leverage type opportunities, even during recessions. I think it's more of the sort of strategic disposition market. You don't need, if you're getting them at attractive prices, to leverage them up. And I think there's real benefit to not having management worry about both financial risk and operating risk. If they're focusing on building a great business as opposed to meeting bank covenants, I think they're going to do a better job of building that business. And so financial leverage to me is a last resort as opposed to a first resort inside of our operating groups. But the parent company, it may be a different issue as I've studied the high performance conglomerates over the years. What I've seen is that nearly all of them have used increasing amounts of leverage over time, particularly, if they are fairly diversified. I think we'd certainly qualify for that category. The trick, of course, is to end up with the right kind of capital in the business. Capital that you feel good about, that is long-term oriented and that you can live with. Well, we are quite different in our approaches to branding and things of that ilk. What I find wonderful is they're intelligent, open to rational argument and I suspect will end up somewhere in between, although I'm not about to end up with a pink and blue logo.

---

---

So this is one of the debates that comes up with the board all the time, which is, should we buy quality companies or companies that are great value? And I think we have the capacity to do either, but they tend to fall into natural categories. So the businesses that people have built over 20 or 30 years that are independently owned by founders, tend to be high quality businesses. They love their clients, their products and their people. And they pour, usually the proceeds of the business, back into building those things. Hence, they are inherently high quality businesses. A business that has been a subsidiary of larger business and has been sold, has been mismanaged, let's say, and is being sold distressed, often has lost some of its franchise, some of its key employees, some of its products have gotten longer in the tooth and will be more of a long-term challenge. So those are the 2 sort of broadish categories you tend to run into.

---

And what are you seeing more this year versus last year? Or is it the same? Or...

---

I would say, mostly we're seeing the mom-and-pop businesses that are 25 to 50 people, maybe 100 people, that have been built up over the years. They tend to be nice businesses.

---

Okay. Excellent. And then on the vertical side, where are you seeing the highest opportunities for growth; healthcare, automotive, logistics as you sort of look at the private sector opportunities?

---

Yes. We tend to be kind of cyclical, so we're usually looking for the things that are suffering right now. And so there aren't very many, unfortunately, sectors that are suffering. But if there is one, we're probably looking.

---

I wanted to follow-up on Paul's line of questioning, and I dearly hope you didn't answer this, I might have missed some of the answer, Mark. It certainly would affect the economics of whatever business we buy. But there are some heartening trends out there in the industry. So the original promise of SaaS was pay as you go, and a lot of the models were monthly pay. What we're seeing is that sales force has started to change the way they're charging. I saw a stat and I can't remember where, but I think it's between 80% and 90% of their revenues are now, annually in advance. So the economic model of SaaS, I think, is recognized that it's way better to collect the dough in advance. And with the leader in the SaaS world going there, I think others will follow. And so I'm hopeful that, that will become a norm in the industry and it won't be any different from a normal conventional maintenance model from an economic perspective.

---

Just, Jamal, I wanted to kind of pin you down a bit on the tax rate, at least on the income statement. I think in the past, you've said 10% to 15%, and it will probably creep towards the high end of that range. What -- I mean, is that commentary still hold with the combined company in the next year?

---

Yes, definitely. I mean, the tax rate at TSS average is probably higher than what's CSI's was, so it -- that wouldn't bring it down by anyway -- it's not -- material enough to bring it outside of that range.

---

Okay, and lastly, the -- any worthwhile commentary on what would give rise to the bargain purchase gain in the quarter? Is that more of an accounting construct than anything else?

---

Yes. Again, it's just an acquisition we found, where the assets weren't of value to the seller, better of value to us.

Thank you for joining the Q4 call. And we are always happy to meet with shareholders. So if you'd like to meet in person, just give us a call and we'll make the time to see you at our office. Goodbye now, and we'll talk to you on the Q1 call. Thank you, Melanie.

Well, whenever you have intelligent managers they, of course, believe that they're doing a great job. And when you come in and say there are some best practices that you might consider, they -- because they're smart people, can explain to you the hundreds of reasons why those best practices won't work. So we're sort of going through that phase right now. We're trying to expose them as much as we can to the people and the practices at Constellation. I'm very hopeful that over time, some of those will transfer to TSS. And so, my expectation and hope is that we can help them run those businesses better, and presumably, some of that will show up on the bottom line.

---

: Thanos Moschopoulos (Analysts)
Okay. In the MD&A, you comment that you're looking at selling a minority stake in TSS. And since that's not something that you typically do, could you provide some color on your thinking there?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
It was part and parcel of the transaction. We have not historically had minority shareholders in subsidiaries. The managers and shareholders of TSS wanted that ability to reinvest, and so that was negotiated as part of the transaction.

---

: Thanos Moschopoulos (Analysts)
Okay, and finally, how should we think about management's available bandwidth and then your term with respect to completing more M&A. So does TSS slow you down in any way, shape or form, while you're digesting this acquisition? Or on the contrary, could TSS actually sustain or accelerate your pace of M&A given that you now have more of a team in Europe that can help you identify more targets?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Well, there's certainly one school of thought that having me spending time with TSS, keeps me out of the hair of the general managers of the other operating groups, and hence, the business will do better. And I don't anticipate personally being involved in any large transaction for the next year or so. So it'll be business as usual at head office, with the exception that I'll be spending time with TSS. And down the operating groups, I don't think they're really affected other than I am trying to get them involved in sharing best practices. So I don't see any real bandwidth issue, Thanos, in terms of TSS. Obviously, banging through 30 little acquisitions a year is nontrivial, and the operating groups have been doing it for a few years. It should be lovely to see that ramp to 50 a year and that will be the challenge providing that integration capability. The ability to bring those companies into the fold and bring them up to speed is a challenge that a lot of the operating group general managers have to deal with.

---

: Thanos Moschopoulos (Analysts)
But is it fair to assume that since -- with TSS, you're buying a team that had done M&A previously? Might that help you, over a long term, scale up your M&A deployments?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
As you may have noticed and I don't recall specifically, they've already completed one acquisition since June that's became part of Constellation. And I anticipate that they will very quickly fall into the same sort of cadence of acquisitions that our other operating groups have.

---

: Stephanie Price (Analysts)
Just a bit of a follow-up to Thanos' question. In terms of the pipeline for larger acquisitions, are you seeing more larger deals after doing a couple of big ones this year? And what does the pipeline look like?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Two questions in there. What does the pipeline look like and what is the large company pipeline look like. Large acquisitions tend to be in the pipeline for relatively short periods of time, from NDA through to close. They tend to be broker transactions that got a life of, let's call it, a couple of months, and you run to a clock that is set by the brokers and the vendors. Hence, we don't see those a long time before they happen, and when they do, we tend to go very quickly because that's how they drive you through that process. And I guess what I'm trying to say is, there's very little visibility on the large transactions, and when they're going to happen and when they're going to enter the funnel and how quickly they'll level the funnel. Back to the smaller transactions, the ones where we, call it, the owners stay in touch with them as opportunities arise, talk to them about how it might work, and then hopefully, having built a relationship, sort of gradually move towards an acquisition. We see those a lot further out. And right now, the funnel is not particularly robust. It's back sort of mid-last year kind of levels and I have no real sense of what that means because as we've said before, the predictive power of our M&A funnel is very, very poor. Obviously, Q4 was a big surprise compared to what we expected, both on the large transaction front and on the small transaction front.

---

: Stephanie Price (Analysts)
Okay. And in terms of organic growth in both the public and private businesses, can you talk about the outlook going into 2014? Organic growth has been pretty strong in the last couple of quarters.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Yes. The operating group general managers tend to be optimistic. They nearly always slip a few points of organic growth during the course of the year from what they forecast at the beginning. Right now, I'd say they're modestly optimistic. But given that history of slippage, you have to look at that with a somewhat jaundiced eye. Now there are some outliers where they actually hit their organic growth forecast and I went back and did an analysis of this about a year ago. So my ability to forecast based on their forecast is limited. But I'd say, if you wandered around the groups right now, there's a slight feeling of optimism about the economy compared to the last 2 or 3 years.

---

: Stephanie Price (Analysts)
Okay. And just one for Jamal. On the -- can you talk about the adjustments between in the TSS income statement in the bar and your Q4 report? It looks that the TSS margins in the bar were a bit higher than in your Q4 report. Is that just translation -- currency translation?

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
It shouldn't be. So are you saying that the margins in the bar are different than in our MD&A?

---

: Stephanie Price (Analysts)
In terms of the TSS acquisitions, it looked a bit higher in the bar.

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
It could be that one is EBITDA. Are you doing EBITDA to EBITA?

---

: Stephanie Price (Analysts)
Maybe that's it. Okay. Yes, I'll go back and look at that.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Then the other issue is capitalization of software, as well, maybe?

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
No, but everything else should tie. Like -- they come -- like it's the same number is going in both, it's just must be a matter of what we put in the bar tied to our financials versus the MD&A as it has EBITA in them.

---

: Stephanie Price (Analysts)
Yes, you're right. That's probably is what it is.

---

: Paul Steep (Analysts)
Mark, maybe we can talk a little bit about the TSS, the statement that you're investigating or looking to adopt some of the financing techniques of, maybe some of the private equity peers to compete a little more effectively for deals of certain sizes. What do you entail that sort of envisioning down the road as we go here in terms of leverage, comfort levels?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
That really comes down to management, the TSS and what they want to do. I've seen private equity firms leverage firms to the hilt, drive for cash flow, pay down the debt, do recaps, and basically run their business around a financial model rather than operating model. I've seen other private equity firms use something they call a leverage build up, where they use leverage but they also acquire and they build their financing facilities, so they can continue to acquire. And you don't get as much financial leverage there, but you get some, hopefully, strategic and operating leverage. So it'll be an evolving thing, Paul. This is a team that is very sophisticated and capable of doing either of those approaches. I obviously much rather see them build the business as opposed to melt the business. And I'm pretty sure that's where we'll end up going.

---

: Paul Steep (Analysts)
Is there the potential to go back and refinance and implement this strategy across some of the other groups in the business?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
It's for sure would be a way of financing Constellation if other sources of capital were not easily available. Right now, I feel that other sources of capital are available and that we don't need to do that.

---

: Paul Steep (Analysts)
Okay, great. I guess the second one is more on management structure. You talked a little bit, I think, first off to Scott, maybe in one of his questions, just about the cost and the margin. But as you steam towards 7,000 staff across the overall group, what about the need for additional structure? Or you feel like it's pretty much just organically getting built in, we're sort of assuming that in the cost base as we go?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Well, hopefully, it's already there because we're over 8,000 right now. So -- but your underlying question is a legitimate one, and that's how do you manage something with hundreds of business units. And we're obviously studying people who've done before to see how they've done it.

---

: Paul Steep (Analysts)
Fair enough.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
All of our businesses are dealing with the issue right now. And what tends to happen is, like many of the things inside of Constellation, we bubble up people who have both the ambition and the talent inside the organization to roles that are increasingly large. So someone who ran a function often ends up running a business unit; someone who run a business unit, ends up running a group of businesses; and someone who runs a group of business units, end up running an operating group. And that's worked well for us over the years, and I feel really comfortable with the quality of people that we have in the organization and their cultural alignment with the organization. And it means that we can run the place with relatively low overheads compared to command and control type organization.

---

: Paul Steep (Analysts)
Okay, and last one for me, just maybe revisiting what we talked about, I guess, March 7 of last year around some of the European margins and the impact. And we spent some time on that call talking about, we weren't sure how long it was going to take to bring them on plan. It seems like you made great progress there -- would appear, there's good progress there. What's played out, I guess, over the last, almost now it's a year?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
So there's definitely been progress, but it's been uneven. Some of our European operations are doing far, far better than others, and we're learning a lot about operating in Europe. I wouldn't call us masterful yet, in terms of our ability to manage European critical market softer businesses and be great owners of such businesses, but I think we're learning.

---

: Nikhil Thadani (Analysts)
Mark, just going back to some of the previous questions. Could you maybe talk a little bit more about some of the best practices that you could adopt as a company, based on the TSS acquisition for further larger deals down the road?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
That's a big question. So the most obvious thing is benchmarking. You compare business units to each other, and you look at how they differ and you try and understand whether there's legitimate differences or merely differences in execution. If it's execution, then you work on execution.

---

: Nikhil Thadani (Analysts)
Okay.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
It's compensation. It's a host of different things. It's kind of like trying to describe a building as a whole as opposed to the individual bricks that go into it. If you pick a brick, I can talk about it. But there's an awful lot of bricks in the building.

---

: Nikhil Thadani (Analysts)
Right. Okay. So fair enough to say that, I mean, based on the TSS acquisition and the fact that there's enough bandwidth, you would not be sort of constrained in any sort of way for further larger deals, just from a management capacity and bandwidth point of view, right?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
No. I think I said the opposite of that. I personally will not be able to go work on a large transaction for the foreseeable future. I think each of our operating group managers has that capacity. But within their realm, there may only be a low handful of large potential transactions that they'd want to go chase, nearly always somewhat strategic. ---

: Nikhil Thadani (Analysts)
Right, right. Okay, fair enough. And just a couple of quick housekeeping questions. Does TSS have any sort of expense seasonality, which is similar to what Constellation might have?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
I'm not close enough to their tax issues to understand whether they run into that Q1 tax and HR contribution issue that we run into in North America.

---

: Nikhil Thadani (Analysts)
Okay, and just one last one. Then overall, how should we think about the tax rate going forward? Maybe not on a quarterly basis, but just sort of rough ballpark.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Well, I think long term, I would think about tax rates going up. It appears that governments everywhere are keen to shut down whatever tax structures that are available and move everyone towards marginal rate. So as we've said, year-after-year, if we were to stop acquiring, our tax rate would go up dramatically. We're in the fortunate position that right now in both the U.S., Canada, when you acquire, particularly if you acquire assets, you can write them off relatively quickly for tax purposes, and that shields our short-term tax rate.

---

: Blair Abernethy (Analysts)
Mark, I wonder if you can just touch on maintenance renewal levels in the sort of December, January timeframe and the pricing environment, and also how does that -- how do renewals look at the TSS business?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
We have so many clients that it would be very, very hard to do that on a monthly kind of basis. What we do is once a year send out a request to the operating groups and generate the stats for the year. And we usually publish that around May, early May, and you'll be able to sort of delve into that in some detail. There's pricing, there's attrition, there's new adds and there's acquired maintenance, broken out separately, and hopefully, adding up to our overall net maintenance revenue.

---

: Blair Abernethy (Analysts)
Okay, great. And then, in terms of Software as a Service, you've talked in the past about, maybe starting to disclose your business, your Software as a Service offerings. So what's your thinking at this point on that?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
So we had a discussion in the board yesterday. We have the information. We are recently comfortable that we've got a crisp enough that we could share it. I'm a little uncomfortable that the cost of goods sold associated with a lot of the SaaS, and hosting and transaction-based models are not clear yet to us. And, hence, if we tell you that SaaS revenues are x percentage of overall maintenance revenues and we can't answer the subsequent question of whether that's a good or a bad thing, I'm not comfortable. And so we're going to get some more information before we start sharing that information.

---

: Blair Abernethy (Analysts)
Okay. Great. And Jamal, just one for you. In the business -- in the bar report, it notes the service revenue of EUR 166 million last year for TSS. What was -- how much of that was maintenance revenues versus what you would consider consulting services or IT Services?

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
So in the MD&A we break out the different revenue streams for TSS, is that the number you're actually referring?

---

: Blair Abernethy (Analysts)
Yes, I think that's what I'd like.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
So I think Blair there's more detail in the MD&A.

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
Yes. Like in the MD&A, we break out license, PS [ph], hardware and maintenance occurring, right?

---

: Blair Abernethy (Analysts)
Okay, great. I just saw the minor breakouts.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
What's the page?

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
It's Page 12 of the MD&A.

---

: Paul Treiber (Analysts)
Mark, I just like to pick your brain for a moment on sort of the longer term strategy and the move to financially levered deals. And so, I think in your letter last year, you mentioned that it will be a fundamental change to move to those type of structure. And in particular, considering the use of stand-alone debt financing and that the return is below your hurdle rate if you don't use the leverage. My question is, what do you see is the opportunity? Or why go this route considering the hassle of having to put in place the financing structure versus your model in the past, which has been, acquire a lot of small businesses?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
We're going to keep acquiring a lot of small businesses. I wouldn't see us touching this largely rich transaction market until we felt we had exhausted the small business acquisition market. So it's a -- I would say, much less attractive business model than our core business model.

---

: Paul Treiber (Analysts)
And so there's no -- the core is still in place, which is 20 to 30, perhaps 50, smaller deals per year?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Absolutely. And I would not do anything to put that at risk or to divert capital from that.

---

: Paul Treiber (Analysts)
So is it -- is this more of a, just putting your toe in the water? And it's almost an experiment at this point, before delving into it at some point when the smaller market is exhausted?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Absolutely.

---

: Paul Treiber (Analysts)
Okay. And then thinking also about these financially leveraged deals, it's probably safe to assume that you're paying closer to market rates for the assets in the smaller ones. So is there inherently more value-creation opportunity based on time in the market and making opportunistic acquisitions during market duress? So like in 2007, 2008?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
So I think, 2 different issues there. One is I think we pay market for both. And so in the small transaction market, they tend to trade at lower multiples then very large businesses that have been optimized. In the large transaction market, usually, you've had fairly sophisticated though perhaps, short-term oriented shareholders owning these businesses. They may or may not have had software expertise to bring it to table. If it was a strategic acquire and they decide that software is hard or not as good a fit as they thought, those distressed assets can be very attractive to us. If it's an economic recession, it may not be that the softer assets are suffering, it could be that the parent business is suffering and they're looking for ways to free up capital. What we discovered during recession, John Billowits and I at that time, John was the CFO, went around and visited all private equity groups because we thought we were going to have a heyday buying up troubled software businesses. But what we discovered was they all came through the recession in pretty good shape. So despite the fact that they were leveraged to the gills, they managed to do fairly well. So I don't think you see a lot of distress because of financial leverage type opportunities, even during recessions. I think it's more of the sort of strategic disposition market. You don't need, if you're getting them at attractive prices, to leverage them up. And I think there's real benefit to not having management worry about both financial risk and operating risk. If they're focusing on building a great business as opposed to meeting bank covenants, I think they're going to do a better job of building that business. And so financial leverage to me is a last resort as opposed to a first resort inside of our operating groups. But the parent company, it may be a different issue as I've studied the high performance conglomerates over the years. What I've seen is that nearly all of them have used increasing amounts of leverage over time, particularly, if they are fairly diversified. I think we'd certainly qualify for that category. The trick, of course, is to end up with the right kind of capital in the business. Capital that you feel good about, that is long-term oriented and that you can live with. And that's the challenge that I've got right now, is trying to figure out what the best sources of capital for Constellation are long term. Did I answer the least part of your question, Paul?

---

: Paul Treiber (Analysts)
Yes. And I think that the follow on to that is, I think the comment about the dividend and your flexibility around the dividend. And is that more about using it as a source of capital if there are the right opportunities available?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Yes. The dividend has got me torn. Finance theory says if you need the cash and you're paying a dividend and there's no transaction cost, it's a legitimate place to go and raise capital, so to speak. At the same time, we feel this obligation to the people that came in to help us transition out our private equity shares -- shareholders, 2 or 3 years ago, or over that period of time to maintain the dividend because that's one of the things that attracted them. And so we're torn between sort of 2 poles. However, what I wanted to do is signal to shareholders that the dividend is always up for consideration by the board. If we were to stumble across an attractive acquisition for one of our -- in one of our key verticals and needed the capital, we would sacrifice the dividend, absolutely.

---

: Paul Treiber (Analysts)
Okay. And just lastly on TSS specifically. It seems like in the past, just looking at the past annual reports, they had a slightly different strategy than the way you've run your business. I think they used a little bit more integration of the units in more sort of like a branding strategy across the units. From a philosophical point of view, I mean, do you think that you see that model changing towards the way you run the business more? Or is that -- are they dead set on that strategy on the way they run that business? Or is it sort of a blending of the 2?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Well, we are quite different in our approaches to branding and things of that ilk. What I find wonderful is they're intelligent, open to rational argument and I suspect will end up somewhere in between, although I'm not about to end up with a pink and blue logo.

---

: Ralph Garcea (Analysts)
I mean, just looking at your pipeline going into 2014 versus last year, are you seeing better quality targets that need less restructuring? As you sort of take a first look at these companies? Or the quality sort of remains the same year-over-year?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
So this is one of the debates that comes up with the board all the time, which is, should we buy quality companies or companies that are great value? And I think we have the capacity to do either, but they tend to fall into natural categories. So the businesses that people have built over 20 or 30 years that are independently owned by founders, tend to be high quality businesses. They love their clients, their products and their people. And they pour, usually the proceeds of the business, back into building those things. Hence, they are inherently high quality businesses. A business that has been a subsidiary of larger business and has been sold, has been mismanaged, let's say, and is being sold distressed, often has lost some of its franchise, some of its key employees, some of its products have gotten longer in the tooth and will be more of a long-term challenge. So those are the 2 sort of broadish categories you tend to run into.

---

: Ralph Garcea (Analysts)
And what are you seeing more this year versus last year? Or is it the same? Or...

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
I would say, mostly we're seeing the mom-and-pop businesses that are 25 to 50 people, maybe 100 people, that have been built up over the years. They tend to be nice businesses.

---

: Ralph Garcea (Analysts)
Okay. Excellent. And then on the vertical side, where are you seeing the highest opportunities for growth; healthcare, automotive, logistics as you sort of look at the private sector opportunities?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Yes. We tend to be kind of cyclical, so we're usually looking for the things that are suffering right now. And so there aren't very many, unfortunately, sectors that are suffering. But if there is one, we're probably looking.

---

: James Keating (Analysts)
I wanted to follow-up on Paul's line of questioning, and I dearly hope you didn't answer this, I might have missed some of the answer, Mark. But rather than keying on size and the considerations, really a decide [ph] on the need or desire for debt, I wonder if we could just focus on the idea of complexion of a deal and whether maintenance and events, as having been such a great model with the encouragement of more SaaS, may change the complexion of the acquisitions and therefore, the cash flow dynamics, such that debt may be more of a requirement. Is that a consideration?

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
It certainly would affect the economics of whatever business we buy. But there are some heartening trends out there in the industry. So the original promise of SaaS was pay as you go, and a lot of the models were monthly pay. What we're seeing is that sales force has started to change the way they're charging. I saw a stat and I can't remember where, but I think it's between 80% and 90% of their revenues are now, annually in advance. So the economic model of SaaS, I think, is recognized that it's way better to collect the dough in advance. And with the leader in the SaaS world going there, I think others will follow. And so I'm hopeful that, that will become a norm in the industry and it won't be any different from a normal conventional maintenance model from an economic perspective.

---

: Scott Penner (Analysts)
Just, Jamal, I wanted to kind of pin you down a bit on the tax rate, at least on the income statement. I think in the past, you've said 10% to 15%, and it will probably creep towards the high end of that range. What -- I mean, is that commentary still hold with the combined company in the next year?

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
Yes, definitely. I mean, the tax rate at TSS average is probably higher than what's CSI's was, so it -- that wouldn't bring it down by anyway -- it's not -- material enough to bring it outside of that range.

---

: Scott Penner (Analysts)
Okay, and lastly, the -- any worthwhile commentary on what would give rise to the bargain purchase gain in the quarter? Is that more of an accounting construct than anything else?

---

: Jamal Baksh (Executives)
Yes. Again, it's just an acquisition we found, where the assets weren't of value to the seller, better of value to us.

---

: Mark Leonard (Executives)
Thank you for joining the Q4 call. And we are always happy to meet with shareholders. So if you'd like to meet in person, just give us a call and we'll make the time to see you at our office. Goodbye now, and we'll talk to you on the Q1 call. Thank you, Melanie.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our analyst conference call. I would also like to take this opportunity to welcome those who are viewing the conference via webcast. Together with Roland Iff, I am pleased to report to you on another very successful year for Geberit. Our presentation is structured as follows: first, I will give you a retrospective overview of 2013, and comment on sales development over the past year. Roland Iff will then present the financial results. Thereafter, I will introduce the most important new products we will launch this year, and give you an overview of prospects for both the construction industry and Geberit. We will then summarize and take your questions.
In 2013, the Geberit Group was able to further improve the already very solid results achieved in the previous year. Sales amounted to CHF 2.29 billion, corresponding to an increase of 3.6% in local currencies. The operating cash flow improved by 10.5%, reaching CHF 593 million. At 25.9%, the EBITDA margin exceeded our midterm target corridor of 23% to 25%. The operating results also significantly increased by 11.9% to CHF 511 million, despite increased personnel expenses and maintenance costs. The EBIT margin reached 22.3%. The net income increased by 12.5% to CHF 436 million, corresponding to a margin of 19% on sales. The earnings per share increased by 14.1% to CHF 11.59. At CHF 444 million, the free cash flow exceeded last year's excellent performance by roughly 14%. The free cash flow was mainly used for shareholder payouts amounting to CHF 248 million. 
For 2013, the Board of Directors proposed a distribution of CHF 7.50 per share to be distributed as regular dividends. This corresponds to an increase of about 14%. The Board of Directors decided on a maximum 5% share buyback program to be executed over the next 2 years. This corresponds to a buyback volume of around CHF 530 million. 
Last year, we introduced various new products. Among others, we successfully launched the new shower toilet AquaClean Sela in April. With its simple and modern form, the appearance of a normal toilet bowl and the innovative technology inside, it's a very convincing product. Following initial supply shortages, we will be able to exploit the full potential of this product in 2014. 
Our portfolio of actuator plates was completed. The Sigma10 family, pictured on the left, include the full range for our WCs and urinals, and has been certified as water efficiency at the highest level. Furthermore, it allows touchless flush activation. The new design of the Sigma50, picture on the right, now comes with a frameless plate. 
Besides the convincing weight reduction, the new electric welding machine for drainage pipes also allows for faster change of tools. The new version of the Geberit Pluvia roof-drainage system combines the existing advantages with a significant noise emission reduction. 
The total environmental impact declined by 2.1%, despite currency-adjusted group-wide sales growth of 3.6%. We also achieved a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and water consumption by 2.7%, respectively, 3.5% versus the previous year. It's also worth noting that the Geberit recycled 84% of all production-related waste. 
8 apprentices and 2 custodians spent 2 weeks in Bucharest hospice for seriously ill children and adults. During their stay, they installed the sanitary infrastructure in the newly built hospice. In addition, they voluntarily supported the patients. The project was planned, funded and carried out on-site by Geberit. 
Additionally, Geberit's cooperation with the, development organization, HELVETAS, was also continued. 
Last year, Geberit invested roughly CHF 100 million or 4.3% of sales. This corresponds to an increase of 14% versus the previous year. Capacity expansions and modernizations each represented 1/3 of the total investments. Investments into rationalizations and new products each accounted for 1/6 of the total investment. I would like to continue by introducing a few selected investment projects. 
In India, our new production plant in Pune started its production activities. The plant produces concealed cisterns that are customized to meet the needs of the Indian markets. Overall, the investment for the plant build-up amounted to CHF 10 million. 
In Ruse, Slovenia, we broke ground for a new plant in April. The investment will amount to CHF 18 million. We also started with the expansion of our Italian plant in Villadose. The total investment into this extension will add up to CHF 15 million. 
Organic growth and the rollout of growth initiatives contributed to a further increase of the headcount. Overall, the number of employees at the end of the year 2013 increased by 92, respectively, 1.5% and reaching 6,226 employees. Sales per employee also increased to CHF 368,500. This correspond to a plus of 3.6%. 
Besides investments in innovation, sustainability, production plants and all employees, the close relation to our customers remains as an essential element of Geberit's success formula. 
Last year, roughly 30,000 customers came to our 25 training centers for initial and follow-up trainings. Roughly 80,000 customers participated in more than 1,000 external events. We were present at important 15 trade fairs, and we introduced sales apps that bring additional value to our customers. 
As we already presented and commented on our 2013 sales figures at our conference call in January, I will concentrate on the essential. 
In addition to the organic growth of CHF 79 million or 3.6% in local currencies, a positive currency effect of CHF 25 million, or 1.1%, contributed to the growth. Overall sales increased by CHF 104 million, or 4.7%.

As in the previous year, we achieved a double-digit sales growth in the North American residential construction sector. Material cost, as a percentage of sales, decreased from 27% to 26.1%, also due to slightly lower raw material prices. The purchasing prices declined throughout the year, however, in Q4, this trend slowed down significantly. 
An increase versus previous year was recorded in personnel cost. The cost increase of 1.3% is in line with the increase in the workforce, which grew by 1% or 64 employees on average. Further cost increases for tariffs last year around 2%, and slightly higher bonuses for employees and management were compensated by lower pension-related expenses and lower cost for our share participation programs. The additional employees, due to the volume growth, were mainly recruited in the European production and sales companies. 
Marketing expenses, which in the last year was due to the AquaClean campaign and growth initiatives, have been growing significantly, were down by almost 4% in 2013. In total, other operating expenses increased by 3.6%, which is slightly less than the 2013 sales growth.

The previously mentioned increase in operating expenses led to a negative effect of minus 0.3%. Positive currency movements had a partially compensating effect. The overall net margin effect between sales and purchasing prices in 2013 was positive, and more than compensated the negative effects from the increase in sales reductions. All in all, EBIT margin increased by 1.4 percentage points compared to previous year.

This, compared to the operating results, over-proportional increase is attributed to a slightly lower tax rate and an improved financial result. Loss on foreign currency positions had a partly compensating effect. The over-proportional EPS growth of 14.1% to CHF 11.59 is driven by the share buyback that was completed in 2012. 
At CHF 444 million, Geberit achieved free cash flow well above the previous year. Besides the development of the operating cash flow, a favorable development of the net working capital was the main driver of the over-proportional increase in free cash flow. Despite the growth in sales, which was mainly generated in the second half of the year, net working capital decreased in the fourth quarter. 
Investments. Intangible assets were CHF 10 million, above the lower -- somewhat low previous year's level, mainly due to the already mentioned production-related projects.

Pension liabilities, on the other hand, decreased. This is, on the one hand, the result of higher interest rates, and on the other hand due to the, again, improved capital coverage of the Swiss pension plans. The equity ratio increased again last year. After 71.3% at the end of 2012, it now reached 74.8%. The financing of the group remains very solid, and we continue to have a basis for an attractive payout policy.

We foresee a mixed picture with uncertainty in Austria, Belgium and Scandinavia. We expect further declines in France, the Netherlands, Southern Europe, as well as in Central/Eastern Europe. 
For North America, we expect the continuation of the ongoing recovery in the residential building sector. On the other hand, non-residential construction still presents an unclear picture. While we expect positive development for the private sector, the outlook for the public sector remains uncertain. 
After the slowdown of growth in 2013, we again expect a single-digit growth rate in China. In the case of India, we continue to be optimistic and expect positive growth rates in both residential, as well as commercial construction. 
In Southeast Asia, we also foresee a continued positive trend, however, with local differences. 
For Australia, we expect positive development on the building sector. 
Despite the ongoing difficult political situation in North Africa, we remain overall positive for the Middle East/Africa region. We especially see positive growth prospects for the Gulf region and South Africa.

In the last 50 years, Geberit has delivered more than 60 million concealed cisterns, and thus enabled a totally new design in millions of bathrooms. Over time, the continued development has led to installation systems that are a major pillar in today's Geberit product portfolio.
This year, we will celebrate its anniversary with gala events in 6 European cities. 
The newly built production facility in Ruse, Slovenia will replace the current existing plant, which we moved into in 1965. As already mentioned in the review,  the groundbreaking of the new plant took place in April last year. Today, the new facility is already considered a reference for green production in Slovenia. In parallel, new production flows would increase the productivity. The new plant should start production in the third quarter of this year. 
And every year, we will initiate and implement a series of important initiatives to meet our ambition of continuously optimizing our business processes. Optimization in production and logistics are targeted in various projects. With technology upgrades in the IT environment, we are staying up-to-date and we will pilot the shift of collaboration tools, as well as the CRM system to a cloud-based technology. With our initiative, Geberit Digital, we are currently working on optimizing our digital presence on search engines. 
Innovation. We'll continue to enjoy a high focus this year. We aim to guarantee a strong and stable product pipeline throughout the upcoming years. Our tradition of social engagement projects will be continued this year, with the support of a center for the education and rehabilitation of children and youngsters in Varanasi, India.

Further increases in productivity, once again, ensured a competitive cost structure. This can only be realized year-by-year through state-of-the-art production and logistics processes. Overall, we confirm our strong and sustainable cash generation ability. We remain very careful in our assessment of the construction industry outlook for 2014. We anticipate an overall weakening of the construction sector in Europe. In Asia, we expect a moderate single-digit growth for China, while we see a reduced but positive growth in India. We remain confident for the markets in the Middle East and South Africa. And for North America, we anticipate a solid recovery, especially in residential construction. 
I am convinced that Geberit's fundamental values represent an exceptionally solid basis for the further development of the company. We are positively positioned in Europe, with a strong position in those markets with a positive outlook. We offer a wide range of new products, and also have dedicated solutions for developing countries. We've proven that we are able to grow profitably even under difficult market conditions. The continuous optimization of our business processes and a clear focus on cost will enable us to continue to operate profitably in the future. Our strong cash generation ability remains undiminished for the future. 
Beside this trusting cooperation with our partners, the entire management places great value on a sustainable leadership of the company. 
Year-over-year, we generate positive organic sales growth in local currencies, except in 2009. We have achieved our midterm growth targets over the last 5 years despite the severe crisis since, 2009. The quality of the sales growth is very important, and during this 11 years period, the EBITDA margin remained at a very high level, with a peak of 28% in 2009. 
With both sales growth and operating margins, we are outperforming the construction sector. Investments, intangible assets, research and market development lead to different levels of return on capital and, therefore, create different amounts of value. This slide is showing that we are investing on average CHF 100 million of CapEx per year at a stable return on investment capital rates, which exceeded 30% for the first time last year. 
On top of these investments, we massively increased our marketing budget over the last few years from CHF 58 million in 2007 to CHF 84 million in 2013. The R&D budget was constant around CHF 50 million. We aim to achieve both sales growth and an attractive return on invested capital. 
We have significantly outperformed the Swiss market index over the last 11 years and have returned more than CHF 1 billion to our shareholders over the last 3 years. Our coherent payout ratio policy is between 50% to 70% of net income. At the end of this year, I will step out of my CEO role, and Christian Buhl will take over this beautiful responsibility. Christian Buhl is a Swiss citizen, 40 years old, he studied physics at the ETH in Zrich.
