And I think that we obviously have in the pipeline some new lease/consortium models that we feel good about that are taking advantage of some of the client relationships that I talked about earlier when previous questions were asked. So we think that the pipeline continues to give us visibility that the center targets that we have for 2014 are in line.

---

: Gary Bisbee (Analysts)
I guess, let me just first follow up on 2, quickly, on 2 questions that were asked earlier, and probably too many people are asking about the lease/consortiums. But if you continue to grow that as a percent of the mix, at some point in the future, does this make the business at all more volatile, like if the economy turns down, given that those sheets [ph] aren't all accounted for? Or is that really you're not expecting that much different than the rest of the mature base?

---

: David Lissy (Executives)
Well, I think, Gary, to a degree -- I mean obviously, the place where we're more vulnerable in a downturn when you look at the sort of overall portfolio of the business is the centers in which we have P&L responsibility for, and that's what we experienced in 2008, 2009, '10 time frame in that class. I think that the key for us is that the centers, obviously, combine both community, back-up and corporate sponsorship in them. So we're not -- we still remain, I think, with this model less exposed than sort of a straight retail model would because of the corporate sponsorship and because of the back-up business. And again, I think we'll continue to grow other models, too. So maybe on the margin slightly. But I still think many of the -- I would still anticipate that overall, the way the company performed during the last downturn is probably indicative of what we might expect, should we experience something similar in the future.

---

: Gary Bisbee (Analysts)
Okay, great. And then, on the whole universal pre-K concept, you talked about Georgia and Florida. Can you just give us a commentary, are your margins the same despite probably getting the lower state fees for part of the week, as they are in the rest of the business?

---

: David Lissy (Executives)
Yes, I think our margins are in line in those states with the rest of the business. I think, again, the key there is that we are wrapping around whatever the reimbursement is in those places in order to complete essentially a view of what our tuitions would average in those areas when we take what's paid for, what we -- sort of what's subsidized or what the parents would have to pay to wrap around for care for whatever hours they're going to wrap around.

---

: Gary Bisbee (Analysts)
Okay. And then, just last one on -- any updated thoughts on leverage and the leverage target? I know you brought the leverage down a lot with the IPO. It hasn't come down a lot since then, obviously, with you investing all of your cash flows through the M&A and the internal investment. But would you be comfortable just having the leverage come down going forward, just from the growth of your cash flow and continue to invest all of excess cash flow? Or any thoughts on how we might think about it over the next couple of years?

---

: David Lissy (Executives)
Yes, I'll let Elizabeth, in a second, Gary, comment on the specifics of kind of what we see on that and what we expect in '14. But I would say broadly that we believe that first and foremost, to the degree we can find acquisitions and/or new center of growth opportunities that meet our investment thresholds or return thresholds, that's probably the best way we can drive value for everybody with the cash that we generate in the business. To the degree that we're in a situation in the future -- and that's what happened this year, we were able to do that, essentially deploy all of our cash, end with a little bit of cash, but not much and not really have anything on the revolver. And we did see some modest deleveraging just with growth. We'll continue to see that, as Elizabeth can add color to. But I think going forward, if we find ourselves with the sort of high-class problem of not -- having too much cash that we generate, more so than we can invest with good investments back in the business, then I think we would look at the 3 options that would exist there, whether that be a dividend, a buyback plan or paying down some debt. The caveat on paying down the debt is we feel very good at the 4% rate that we have now, that that's a pretty -- it's efficient. It's efficient for us at that level. So if it stayed that way going forward, it would be more likely that our choice would be either a buyback or a dividend.

---

: Elizabeth Boland (Executives)
Yes, I agree and I think that we're ending the year at under 4% or 3.75% without even considering the full year contribution that we would get from the acquisitions that done mid-year. So by the end of this year, we'll be close to 3 turns on our adjusted EBITDA, and we feel like that's very comfortable to just continue to grow into it with our natural -- the natural deleveraging that occurs there for the short foreseeable future.

---

: Jeffrey Silber (Analysts)
Just a real quick one. Elizabeth, that $29 million, you mentioned in acquired revenues, was that all of the full-service center segment?

---

: Elizabeth Boland (Executives)
Yes, it is. And I just -- to clarify a question that came through earlier, so our back-up in that advisory growth in the quarter was a neighborhood of 1.5%. And so full-service organic growth is just over 7% growth, and then there's closures against that, that bring it down to around 5%. So that was just the full service on business, not the other organic growth. So I think that we're out of time.

---

: David Lissy (Executives)
I agree. Yes. Appreciate everybody's time. And thanks for the questions, and we'll be talking to you, I'm sure, in the near future. Have a good night.

---

: Elizabeth Boland (Executives)
Thank you.

BP9DL90.eventHeadline: Industria de Diseno Textil SA, 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 19, 2014
BP9DL90.transcript_text1:
Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex results for fiscal 2013. I am Pablo Isla, and here with me are Ignacio Fernndez, CFO; and Marcus Lopez, Capital Markets Director. 
The results for 2013 show the global reach of our business model. Inditex continues its ongoing multi-concept, multichannel growth. We operate a highly diversified business platform with a strong growth potential. 
2013 has been a year of strong expansion for Inditex. We have achieved satisfactory sales growth. The year has been marked by a tight control of operating expenses and significant investment in the expansion of our business through the addition of prime retail space globally. 
Our financial performance allows us to propose a significant increase in shareholder remuneration for fiscal 2013. We have finished the year with operations on 5 continents through 8 formats, 6,340 stores globally, and an online sales presence in the most relevant markets. We have reinforced significantly the differentiation of our key global flagships. We start 2014 with a unique platform that can access growth opportunities globally. 
I would like to highlight some key points of these results. In 2013, Inditex continued expanding its operations in a very significant way. Like-for-like sales grew strongly at 3%, on a very demanding comparable of 6%. Additionally, space growth was plus 9%, in line with long-term targets. We are also operating an online platform in 25 markets with a wide geographical coverage. We have also increased the prominence of our key global flagships, and have achieved a strong differentiation of our retail base. Additionally, the Board of Directors is proposing a 10% increase in the dividend to be paid in relation to this result. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio, who will provide you with some detail behind the headline numbers, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

In 2013, Inditex achieved net sales of EUR 16.7 billion, EBITDA of  EUR 3.9 billion, and net income of EUR 2.4 billion. I would like to highlight that all the lines of the profit and loss account, showed double-digit growth rates on a 2-year compound basis. The regional sales has been satisfactory, with 8% growth in our local currencies. These numbers have been achieved against very demanding comparables. 
Sales growth is 10% on a 2-year compound basis. Like-for-like sales grew strongly of 3% in 2013, retail space increased 9%. Space contribution, adjusted for the store optimization program, was 7%. The translation of sales in currencies different to the euro has deducted 3 percentage point from reported sales. 
Reported sales growth reflects the strong comparable currency translation and store optimization program. Over 2015, Inditex's retail space grew 9% to 3.4 million square meters. We have seen a strong expansion of our selling area and prime locations. We have added 281,000 square meters of space to our retail base over the year. The ongoing expansion of our group have led to a global sales platform, with a presence in 87 markets on 5 continents, both in the Northern and Southern Hemisphere. 
Regarding the gross margin, we can say that we are satisfied with the evolution in 2013.  Inditex gross profit increased 4% to EUR 9.9 billion. The gross margin has reached 59.3% of sales, as a result of the solid performance, flexible business model and sustained commercial policies. 
Operating expenses are tightly under control. They have grown 7% in the year, reflecting the strong like-for-like sales performance, and the significant addition of new retail space. This line includes all the start up cost for new space and the rollout of online sales. All the components of working capital continued to show tight control, reflecting the flexibility of the business model. 
In 2013, funds from operations reached EUR 2.9 billion. I would like to highlight the strong investment made in 2013 in order to ensure future growth. Capital expenditure was EUR 1.24 billion, and it is continues to show a strong financial position. Net cash is EUR 4 billion. 2 important investments over 2013 have been development of the product department of Zara and Zara Home, Arteixo, La Corua and the new distribution center for Pull&Bear in Cabanillas, Guadalajara.  I will now hand over to Marcos, who will further share the details further into the performance of the concepts.

---

Growing the capacity of a business model to reach global growth opportunities, Inditex has opened stores in 61 markets over the year to reach 6,340 stores worldwide. Over 2013, the concept has increased the sales platform and deepen their global penetration. As you can see in this chart, Zara continues to represent approximately 2/3 of Inditex's sales, while the younger concepts account for 1/3. 
Zara sales in 2013, reached EUR 10.8 billion and EBIT EUR 2.1 billion. On a 2-year compound basis, both lines grew 10%. The store optimization program for Zara was largely completed in 2013. Reported numbers reflect the strong comparable, currency translation of the store optimization program. Taking as a whole, the concepts  have grown sales of 10% over the year. Regarding the younger concepts, I would like to highlight the strong progress made by Zara Home, Massimo Dutti, Pull&Bear and Oysho over the year. 
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

Before closing, I would like to elaborate on the number of strategic points. In 2013, Inditex added 281,000 square meters of retail surface to reach 3.4 million square meters. This builds on very strong growth in space over recent years. In total, we have added 1.1 million square meters of prime retail space to our commercial base in just 4 years. Inditex online operations have seen a rapid rollout in recent years. Our business model allows a swift expansion of our online sales platform globally. The different launches have allowed us to cover practically the whole of the Northern Hemisphere in just 48 months. This presence provides a base for strong growth. We will continue to roll out online sales progressively in all the markets in which we are present with the stores. 
Over 2012, 2014, we have continued to increase the differentiation of our retail proposition. We have enlarged or refurbished most of our key global flagships, and are rolling out the new image into all new openings. The average size of new stores has also increased. This program is now largely completed and we are starting to see the results. 
As you can see, our business model that combines stores and online is highly productive. In 2013, we have achieved a strong like-for-like of 3%, on very demanding comparables in the previous years. Let me point out that over the last 4 years, like-for-like sales growth has been 17%. We believe that Inditex is in an excellent position to take advantage of global growth opportunities. We have a strong potential to continue expanding profitably in the coming years. 
In Europe, we continue to see huge growth opportunities in both Western and Eastern Europe. It is an area of growth for all our formats and we have an online sales presence in 21 markets. We see great potential to continue expanding profitably in Europe.
